text:
This is a really good one!!!  Definitely double the sauce.  Here is what I did differently.  Used lite soy sauce to cut the salt, increased the garlic, used 1 tsp. minced fresh ginger.  A lot of reviewers said to half the amount of sugar but I tasted it and felt I needed to add more but not the whole amount.  Since I doubled the sauce, I used 1/2 c. brown sugar and 1/4 c. white sugar.  I lined my pan with heavy duty foil then poured most of the thickened sauce over bone-in thighs (skin removed) and some boneless breasts but reserved a little.  Cooked, covered with foil for 30 minutes, removed foil, poured remainder of sauce over and bake another 20-30 minutes.  Wow.  Really good! Update: I made this again using slices of tri tip and it was great.  Fantastic with salmon.  I had a large fillet and basically baked it the same way but reduced the oven temp. to 375 and baked for a little less time till fish was flakey.

Absolutely wonderful! The recipe didn't mention it, but I decided to cover the pan with foil to help keep the chicken tender. And I used lite soy sauce too. I think I may decided to line the pan with foil too the next time I make it--otherwise, you have a sticky, black mess. Delicious flavor, and the chicken was so tender. Will definitely make again.

text:
Excellent. After reading several reviews, I did make the following changes: Doubled the sauce. In the doubled recipe, I doubled the garlic (fresh pressed), reduced sugar by half and used packed brown sugar instead of white sugar, used lite soy sauce (I always use lite, regular is TOO salty), rounded the tablespoons of cornstarch, used fresh ground pepper (five pepper blend), and I had boneless, skinless thighs. I baked at 375 degrees, 25 mins covered with foil, then 15 mins uncovered (total 40 mins). I did not baste, but just covered the thighs with the sauce. Would've used fresh ground ginger if I'd had it. Cleanup was a breeze as long as I soaked pans right away, it washed right out. With these changes it was scrumptious and got rave reviews from my family. Great with thighs, would also try breasts or other cuts. Definitely a keeper! Thanks Marian!

city:

country:

text:
I make this recipe in a slow cooker and it is simply fantastic. I just put the chicken thighs in, cover with the sauce (exact recipe)and put it on low for at least 5 hours.  The longer the chicken cooks the more savory the dish, and the chicken just falls apart (shreds) in the sauce.  About an hour before I'm ready to serve I throw in some chopped green pepper, carrots, celery (or whatever vegetables I want to get rid of in the fridge), and then 20 minutes before serving I throw in a can of drained pineapple chunks. The pineapple removes the saltiness and the dish is perfect spooned over rice.  Absolutely amazing! I find this recipe foolproof --today I tripled the sauce (made 20 thighs), dropped the bowl and lost most of the sauce all over myself and the floor (GOD what a mess!) and was too lazy to make more so just used whatever was left.  It STILL came out perfect!!  And if the sauce is too thin I just remove some from the crockpot, add a little cornstarch paste and/or Veloutine gravy thickener, microwave it till it boils and thickens and mix it back in with the rest. Too easy!  Thank you for an unforgettable recipe that everyone loves!

text:
Fantastic!!! This has become a favorite in my house. The only changes I make is using boneless skinless chicken breasts and I do cut the soy sauce down a bit and I substitute some of the white sugar for brown sugar to cut down on the saltiness because my husband thought it was a bit too salty. Also,do cut the temp down on this. I go 375 for the first 15 minutes or so and then down to 350 for another 20-25 minutes. Continually baste to get that yummy glaze. Terrific recipe!!! Definately 5*'s!!!

text:
What a great homemade teriyaki sauce! It has a much richer taste, than many bottled. The only thing I changed was I used a "low-sodium" soy. To make a meal, I added fresh snow peas, sliced water chestnuts, squares of yellow onion and green pepper, and fresh pineapple chunks. We put over white rice. It was as good as a very good oriental restaurant's! We did not like the chicken thigh dark-meat with the bone in much though, so next time I will make with chicken breast,BONELESS,SKINLESS thigh meat, shrimp, or pork. Thank you Marian, this sauce is a keeper!

text:
This is a great recipe.  I split the sugar into half brown and half white sugar like someone else.  It was so good I made up more teriyaki sauce, bought chicken when it was on sale, and froze the chicken in the teriyaki sauce so it would marinate as it froze and thawed.  Then I cook in the crockpot on low for most of the day.  I like the chicken so tender it falls apart.  Cooking in the crockpot eliminates all the mess others have talked about.  And since you cook the chicken right in/with the teriyaki, you have the hot teriyaki sauce to serve with the chicken.

text:
The is the second time I'm rating this, and it's STILL 5 STAR!  Since I've used this recipe as an hors d'oeuvre and now as a main course I think I get to rate it twice! hehe
Main Course 5 Star Rating ---
Ditto to ellygirl's 5/21 rating/review.  Use boneless, skinless chicken breasts cut into 3rds. DOUBLE THE SAUCE! Yum! I used fresh ginger.  I stirred the chunks of meat into a bowl full of the thickened sauce before putting it all into foil lined pan.  Poured the remaining sauce over the meat in the foil lined pan.  Baked 375° for 15 min. Turned meat over...baked another 15 min. Done to perfection.  IF IF IF IF I was to change one thing it would be to use low sodium soy sauce next time.  It was just on the verge of too salty, but still very very VERY good!! I tend to prefer chicken thighs, but this was great with the breasts. 

Hors d'oeuvre - 5 Star Rating - 
YUMMMMMMMY!! I tweaked the recipe just a bit. I used chicken wings (tips removed). I **BAMMED* it up a bit by doubling the fresh garlic. I only basted twice during the baking. Bake 350° 50-55 minutes.  I made an extra batch of the Teriyaki sauce on the stove top while the wings baked. When cooled I mixed in a dollop of sour cream, and served that mixture for a dipping sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DO NOT COVER YOUR CHICKEN! Lol. I followed some other members advice and it was all wrong. If you cover your chicken in the first half of baking you end up with a pan full of the juices from the chicken. It thins out your sauce and it takes a good hour or so for the juices to evaporate. Also the sauce would not stick to the bottom of the chicken. I ended up throwing them in the broiler for a while and that helped. If you insists on covering your chicken, drain the juices out of the pan half way through. It will save you LOADS of time and effort. I didn't have ginger and I didn't miss it. The sauce was delicious!

text:
The sauce sounds delicious & I plan to try the recipe ASAP, using both thighs & bone in skinless chicken breasts. A couple of comments, 425F with a sauce containing sugar, is much too high, & would very quickly burn. 325- 350F would be better, & even at the lower temperature, baking for an hour  might dry the chicken or burn the marinade. Best to check  with an instant thermometer after the first 30 minutes. to judge the additional  length of cooking time.

text:
Great dish, worth the 5 stars!  I made this today for a dinner party, tripling the sauce amount, and making the following adjustments recommended by other reviewers: 12 boneless, skinless breasts, cut in half cross-wise, fresh ginger, reduced sodium soy sauce. Brushed chicken w/ sauce, turned over and brushed again, then poured remaining sauce over breast pieces and did not turn/brush during baking time.  Had two large baking dishes to fit in the oven, so I baked w/ convection oven at about 380F/195C for approx 25 minutes.  Served chicken on a platter, and accompanied with hot stir-fried veggies (broccoli, snow peas, sliced water chestnuts, yellow onion, julienne carrots, zucchini, red and green pepper, and fresh pineapple), loads of rice, and remaining sauce from the baked chicken (and a tossed green salad for good measure.)  Got rave reviews from my guests; will definitely make this again.

text:
I made a few small changes to improve the flavor of the chicken. I used reduced salt soy sauce, brown sugar instead of white, increased the garlic, used fresh ginger and increased the amount and increased the amount and I threw in some chopped green onions. I made the sauce early in the morning and let it cool a bit before I poured it over the chicken so it could marinate all day. I think that was what made it so good--that it sat in the sauce all day. 350* for about an hour and it was good to go. I'm glad I doubled some of the ingredients, especially the spices and used fresh ginger and green onions. It really helped this recipe really taste awesome.

This smells wonderful when it is baking!  I read through most of the previous reviews and took some advice. I made this before but didn't rate it til now. This is my second time making this and something in the back of my mind said that the last time I made this I should have marinaided this longer. So with that in mind I did warm up the sauce so that the sugar would melt then poured the juice over the chicken pieces in a marinaide bag and left in the fridge overnight. Total time was around 17 hrs. Then I cooked it the way the recipe said. Hubby raved about it. Our friend said that some pieces had more flavor than others so next time I might tenderize the chicken to see how that works. Otherwise this was a great meal and I'll make this again!!

text:
I've made this recipe several times and the family has loved it everytime.  I have found that if you use about 1/2 the sauce at first, bake for 30 minutes....then, remove from oven, pour off most of the excess water that has formed in the pan, and then add more sauce, the chicken glazes over much better.  Turning and basting about every 10 minutes towards the end helps too!

text:
What a FABULOUS recipe!  This is just outstanding!  I did make one significant change, based on previous experiences with roasted chicken: I reduced the temperature to 350 F (and even with this 75 degree difference, an hour-- at least in my oven-- was just about right).  I only had six thighs (I left the skin on for roasting), and the amount of sauce specified was perfect.  I made the sauce ahead of time, and marinated the thighs before cooking them. Many thanks to the reviewers who advised to line the pan with foil-- it made for an easy, painless clean-up.  I garnished the dish with toasted sesame seeds, as another reviewer suggested, and it was the perfect finishing touch.  I served this over brown rice simmered with a bit of soy sauce, seasoned with garam masala, and tossed with some minced green onion, which turned out to be a great flavor complement.  My RM, who is not overly fond of chicken, RAVED about this recipe (and I didn't even have to solicit his opinion, as I usually do).  As for me-- dare I admit it?-- I actually LICKED my PLATE clean!  No doubt about it, this is going to be a featured favorite at our house, and I can hardly wait to make it again.  Thanks for the awesome recipe!

text:
This recipe works just fine and the flavours are intense. I challenged two of my studens to prepare and enhance since we try to avoid white sugar and brown sugar is mainly molasses. The first substituted raw cane sugar and increased the acidity by using white wine vinegar and the heat by subsituting jalapeno chili for garlic and also avoided the pepper. The second used melon sugar (available at Asian markets) reducing the amoun to 1/3 C and also substituted the vinegar by using Mirin and retained the garlic. We did a blind test in the class and #2 was held highest but only by a slight point. However, the recipe presented above works fine.

THIS IS A KEEPER - BIGTIME.  I made this recipe exactly as stated and loved it.  I recommend that you make a double batch to pour over the chicken once it has baked as the original sauce you pour over the chicken while baking becomes diluted with the juice that drains from the chicken.  

I loved it, my husband loves it, his colleagues love it and my mother loves it.  Excellent.  I will never purchase Teriyaki sauce in a grocery store now that I have this recipe.

text:
Wow we just got done eating this for dinner. Very Very Good! 
I would have needed more sauce if I used 12 pieces. I made almost exactly like the recipe calls for, but I could only fit 8 pieces of chicken in my baking dish. The amount of sauce was perfect for that amt of chicken thighes. I used bone in and skin on..Because it's all about the flavor baby. What I do is trim the flap of skin that goes under the thighe and just leave what's on top. I added 1/4 green bell pepper (small slices) I had in the fridge. Mixed it with the sauce. I cooked at 400 for 30 minutes w/foil on top after basting both sides, pulled it out removed foil, turned pieces over and basted heavily. back in at 400 for 30 more minutes. Out of the oven and there was plenty of wonderful sauce all over the chicken. I could not see why to baste every 10 min. Also that would probably keep dropping the temp down in the oven. Put over a bed of white rice with a little bit of the juices sprinkled in the rice. Wonderful flavor just like my favorite chinese restaurant. I don't give out 5 stars very often, even when I like something. But this got 5 stars. A keeper for sure. This old single Dad thanks you very much for this recipe. Oh and I did line the dish with foil then sprayed with pam.

text:
I changed the recipe just a bit by cooking it in the slow cooker.  

Instead of doubling the sauce (per some reviewers), I made the sauce with 3/4 c. brown sugar (instead of white), 3/4 soy sauce, 1/4 c. vinegar, 2 cl. garlic minced, 1 t ground ginger and 1/2 t black pepper and poured it over 3 lbs. of boneless, skinless chicken thighs and 1 coarsely chopped onion.  I cooked it on LOW for about  6 hours, then turned the crock pot on high.  Added 1 can pineapple chunks (drained) and 1 chopped orange pepper, 1 1/2 T. cornstarch mixed with 1 1/2 T. of the leftover pineapple juice and cooked on HIGH for about 1 hour.  

Served over rice (and it had plenty of sauce) and my family LOVED it!  I will definitely make this again!

text:
I have made this twice and I think I got it right this time.  The sauce is excellent, that is, until the chicken juices dilute it in the pan and make it all runny.  My solution is make about four times as much sauce and use half of it for cooking the chicken, the other half to pour over it when it's done.  Strange I didn't read about anyone else with this happening to them, but that's my take on it.  My family ate this right up, the three-year-old even went for thirds!  This will become a very regular dinner for us with those revisions.  Thanks, Marian.

Really good, going to give it an "A".  the reviews are very helpful, I with Valerie'sKitchen & doubled the sauce, including the sugar but went with 3/4 cup brown & 1/4 cup white.  With regular soy sauce, it needed it for me.  Next time will try either light soy, or using water in place of some of the soy, approx 1/4 cup.

text:
This one was so good, my boyfriend kept sneaking into the kitchen to swipe a little sauce while it was cooking!  I cooked the chicken as directed and was very pleased with the results.  I doubled the sauce and, as others suggested, substituted the sugar for 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white, and also used 2 very large cloves of garlic.  I also added the tiniest pinch of red pepper flakes--it didn't make the sauce spicy but did add a lovely warmth in the background!  I served the chicken sliced over rice with more of the sauce and garnished with sliced scallions. Too good! I can't wait to make this again!  UPDATE: I made this a second time--again, recipe doubled--but used low sodium soy. I didn't notice any difference at all in the taste! I also took another suggestion and lined my pan with non-stick aluminum which made clean up far too easy! This is still a favorite in our house!

Great quick and easy dish!  I used 1 1/2 tsp minced ginger (from the jar) and 3 cloves garlic.  I browned boneless, skinless chicken thighs, removed from pan, made sauce and returned chicken to pan to bake.  I turned the chicken 3 or 4 times while it baked. Display Name:
Feed my hungry family

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! I made this today for my family. Everyone raved and not a bite was left over. Based on previous reviews, I doubled the sauce using 1/2 cup of pineapple juice reserved from a can of pineapple chunks in their own juice and 1/2 cup of dark brown sugar in place of the 1cup white sugar equivalent. I also used a low sodium soy sauce and boneless chicken breast I had cut in 1/2 thickness wise. I coursely chopped 3/4 of a red pepper, 1/4 of a large sweet onion and spread 1/2 a can of pineapple chunks on top of the chicken. I poured the sauce on top of all of this in the baking dish and let it marinate in the fridge for 5 hours. Baked at 375 for 30 minutes, flipping the chicken 1/2 way through. I removed chicken to warm plate and changed oven setting to broil, and let the sauce, onion, pepper and pineapple broil 5 minutes until it was thick. It was perfect to drizzle over the chicken. I served it with white rice. This is a new FAVORITE for my family.

This was awesome! I read previous reviews and lined the pan with foil sprayed with Pam, doubled the sauce part of the recipe, and covered the chicken with foil.  I agree that it was not too sweet or salty.  I had regular soy sauce, and used the advice of one reviewer with 1/2 c. brown sugar and 1/4 cup of granulated sugar. I almost forgot to double the cornstarch. 
I also used some of each cut of chicken ~ thighs and breasts. I believe the thighs were the absolute best! Covering the chicken with half of the sauce, baking it for 30 mins., then turning the chicken and putting the remainder sauce over the chicken was the best idea!  This was so much better than the bottled sauce! 
I paired it with some homemade cole slaw.
Thank you for such a good recipe.  It's a keeper for me!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a wonderful teriyaki chicken recipe.  I have to admit, I was overwhelmed with all different cooking instructions in the thousands of reviews, and every time I read another one, I forgot what the previous one said; finally, I settled on brown sugar instead of white, basting and baking at 375 for 30 minutes, turning and rebasting at 20 minutes, and baking for about 15 minutes more (45 minutes total baking time).  I used boneless breasts, pounded a bit and cut in half.  It was simply delicious.  When I tasted the sauce before I used it, I thought it was much too salty, but when it baked into the chicken, the flavor was perfect.  Every one of my 15 dinner guests (from age 3 to age 65) loved it.  A keeper~~thanks so much.

text:
Mmmm Boy!  That's some delicious Teriyaki sauce.  I'll be using that for grilling too.  I used boneless skinless chicken thighs.  If you do, cut the cooking time to 35 or 40 minutes. Put it in the pan pretty side up and don't turn and baste often. Double the sauce but don't change anything.   I have to disagree strongly with many reviewers that say cover with foil.  All you do is trap the steam and ruin that wonderful gooey coating that forms in the heat of the oven.  DO NOT COVER WITH FOIL!!! Delicious, thanks for sharing.

text:
These were good, everyone liked them and raved about them.  Instead of basting them every 10 mins, what I did was pour all the marinade in, and flipped the pieces every so often, much easier.  I didn't have cider vinegar, so I just used plain vinegar and it worked fine.  The skin was great, but the meat itself was rather plain and I did marinate them for 4 hours.  However, I enjoyed them more when I dipped them in the marinade from the pan.  I think next time, I'll double the marinade so I can have some for dipping.  Will be making again, thanks.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was just looking for a quick way to prepare some boneless skinless chicken breasts and this looked like a good idea. I admit I wasn't expecting much, just another home made teriyaki sauce, but oh my, was this one GOOD! I prepared it as written, only reducing the sugar to 1/3 of a cup and using seasoned rice vinegar. My soy sauce was low sodium. I put the breasts on a rack on a foil lined tray and baked at 350 for about 30 minutes, basting several times throughout. The sauce formed a beautiful sticky and delicious 'crust' on the outside, while the inside remained juicy and tender. This recipe will be my standard teriyaki basting sauce from now on. I had lots of leftover sauce, and 1.5 breasts left as well. I used those leftovers to make a quick and delicious stir fry the next day.

text:
This was fantastic! I used chicken breasts instead of thighs, Splenda in place of the sugar, and low sodium light soy sauce. I also cut the cider vinegar in half. It came out sooooo well. I marinaded the chicken in the sauce for 6 hours and then baked covered in foil at 375 for 30 minutes. I didn't find it necessary to double the sauce... there was more than plenty for two of us. It really stuck to the chicken breasts and made a thick glaze, which is what I liked best. I will be making this again!

text:
This is a great recipe. I doubled the sauce, but otherwise stuck to the recipe ingredients. I did change one thing in the way I cooked it.  I cooked the chicken thighs for about 20 minutes first, then I drained the liquid that the chicken threw, put the sauce on and continued following the recipe from there.  The first time I made this it never got super sticky because I didn't know to drain the water from the cooking chicken.  Thanks to my mom for telling me to cook it this way.  I have referred several of my friends to this recipe and will continue to do so!  Thanks, Marian for a GREAT recipe!

text:
Great recipe. I subbed half the sugar with brown sugar and used light soy sauce to reduce the sodium, and left everything else the same. I cut the chicken leftovers into bite-sized pieces and served it over rice the next day. I think we liked this even better.

Update:  An alternative to baking, and heating the kitchen is to mix the sauce ingredients and set aside without cooking. Cut the chicken into bite sized pieces and sauté in a large skillet in a small amount of oil. When chicken is done, pour sauce over meat and simmer until sauce thickens. Serve over rice.

text:
I have been using a recipe very similar to this for years on chicken wings.  They go over GREAT at parties, etc.  I do not baste the chicken pieces, though.  I pour all the sauce over them and occasionally turn the pieces while they are baking.  One hour does the trick but, prepared this way, you can bake longer and the sauce really sticks and caramelizes.  Yum!

text:
Very easy and good. Made these adjustments: doubled sauce recipe, used white wine vinegar instead of cider vinegar (b/c I didn't have it), used almost 4 lbs. chicken breasts cut in half, baked at 350 and up to 375 near end for almost 1 hour, did NOT simmer sauce before baking and did not cover while baking and it turned out the perfect glazy consistency. I did baste often, which is necessary - really creates a great glaze. Definitely use less sugar - my 4 year old thought it was too sweet! - It didn't taste bad at all, but my preference would be less sugar. Great recipe overall.

As other reviewers have suggested, this is a tasty and easy to prepare chicken recipe. I halved the recipe for 8 deboned chicken thighs (there was plenty of sauce), and substituted fresh for the ground ginger (1 tsp of fresh for the halved recipe). Even without reading the reviews, I cooked the chicken for 1/2 hour turning at 15 minutes and basting at 10 minute intervals - but figure the recipe initially was for boned thighs. Great recipe and a super sauce that can be used for other meats.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/17.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure what all the fuss is about, as we all thought it tasted exactly like bottled teriyaki sauce. It seems like alot of people are using chicken breasts instead of the thighs, so of course you would have to reduce the cooking time and/or temp. I couldn't fathom cooking chicken breasts at 425 so I reduced to 375. I doubled the sauce as recommended, but it was kind of a waste as I personally wouldn't pour bottled teriyaki sauce over rice so this was the same. I am glad I followed the advice of other reviewers and used lite soy sauce, this recipe calls for alot (1/2 cup!) so it definitely would be salty with regular. For those of you who mentioned the black on the bottom of the pan, it is because of the high heat. There were also people mentioning that the sauce is on the thinner side, well, it is, but if you cook at a high temp for that long it thickens because it is almost starting to burn, I would recommend instead if you want a thicker sauce to add a little more cornstarch, then you can cook at a reduced temp. Our chicken was not dry but I did watch my time, just cooked until they were done (used meat thermometer). It isn't the best smelling sauce either, because it contains cider vinegar (which on it's own smells like stinky feet!) I guess if you really like bottled teriyaki sauce, then you'll really like this recipe, for us, it was not worth the effort. Sorry to lower the rating, but I won't be making this again.
Review:

5

text:
My husband is a HUGE fan of teriyaki, so to impress him was going to be a real challenge.....until I found this recipe.
Ever since I've made this teriyaki, he tells everyone he'd eat mushrooms if they were dipped in this sauce (he HATES mushrooms).
I probably make this at least 6 ot 7 times a month-it's a true "regular" in our home.
I just throw all ingredients into a pot, boil until it thickens, pour all of it over chicken breasts, then bake COVERED at 375 for 30 minutes.

I then cut up the chicken and serve over a bed of rice pilaf-don't forget to save the juices!
My husband's favorite thing is the extra sauce for dip :)

text:
This recipe turned out great!  I  doubled the teriyaki sauce but only used 1/2 cup of white sugar and 1/4 cup of brown sugar.  I purchased bone-in chicken thighs with skin  because they were less expensive and took the skin off. I marinated  the chicken overnight.  I cooked it at 400 degrees for about 45 minutes with foil covering the pan.   This made it more like hawaiian style shoyu chicken.  It was so juicy and almost fell off the bone. Next time I will try to cook it covered with foil for the first half and remove the foil for the second half.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making this recipe tonight and it will most definitely be a staple in our household! Teriyaki chicken has always been a favorite in our house, but store bought marinates just cant compare to this homemade mix. They key was definitely to have the patience to let the sauce thicken up.The directions stated to allow an hour for prep, but if you have everything layer out, it only takes about 30 minutes from the time you get it all in the pan, til it finally bubbles and thickens.  I poured a thin layer of sauce in the bottom of the pan & continued to baste/brush the sauce over the chicken throughout the baking process. I also turned the breasts over several times to really soak up the juices and added chucks of pineapple about 1/2 way through so that they too could take up the flavor of the sauce. AMAZING flavor!!! Yummy!  :)

text:
YUM. I have used the sauce on steak as well as chicken thighs and oh so good. I've also subbed truvia for sugar and it was just as good, better for you too. To make with chicken thighs, I didn't baste that often, I just turned them over partway through... laziness. Also, I read reviews that advised doubling the recipe. But that was unnecessary for me. In my baking dish (foil lined of course) I ended up with so much extra sauce, and that's with the chicken pretty heavily coated. I also halved the recipe once to use on 2 smallish steaks - half for marinade and half for basting. Marinating wasn't really that effective, probably I didn't tenderize the meat enough... I am not so good with steak... but on chicken I will definitely make this over and over. Cheap and good to impress people with. Great with rice and pretty much any vegetables.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/908502.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so easy and yet it turned out to be better than restaurant quality!  I'm so pleased.

Used boneless, skinless chicken breasts.  Doubled the sauce, as everyone else mentioned.  Used 1/4 c. white sugar and 1/2 c. brown sugar.

Lined dish with foil and cooking spray.  Put 1/2 of sauce on to the chicken, covered with foil, and cooked at 375 for 30 minutes.

Took out of oven, turned pieces over, drained some of the extra liquid, and added rest of sauce.  Baked, uncovered, at 350 for 20 minutes.

Chicken was so moist and tender, it was falling apart!  Will definitely make again!

text:
This was absolutely delicious! I will say it was a bit on the salty side, but that was mainly my own doing because I seasoned the chicken before I put the marinade on. I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs and doubled the sauce. I poured half the sauce over the chicken and then put in the oven for 30 minutes covered in foil. I then took it out, flipped the chicken and poured the rest of the marinade over the chicken, returning it to the oven this time uncovered, for an additional 30 minutes. It was falling apart! And it was so delicious!

text:
I can't believe how good and easy this dish is!! I doubled the recipe for the sauce otherwise I would've had enough. We love ginger and garlic so I added about 8 cloves of fresh garlic ( smashed and minced ) and 2tbsp of ginger paste. I also did 1/2 cup white and brown sugar.  I spooned part of the mixture over the chicken, turned the meat over and spooned more on the chicken. Covered with foil and baked at 425 for 30 min, then uncovered the dish and spooned the rest of the sauce all over the chicken and put back in the oven for an additional 10 min.  It was perfect!!!

text:
Simply wonderful! I made this without any changes the first time through and it was just fine. Then I made it with doubling the sauce, and putting it all together, covered - this resulted in the sauce getting too thin. So I made it again - doubling the sauce, increasing the cornstarch to 4 Tablespoons, adding 1 teaspoon of crushed red pepper flakes for zippiness, covered it for half the time, and left it uncovered for the other half of the time. I also turned each piece during the 2nd half of the cooking time to get a nice teriyaki coating on it. Served it each time with coconut rice, and there aren't any leftover to be had! Thanks for the recipe - it is a keeper!

This was awesome and I made it in my slow cooker!  I slow cooked the chicken (5 large chicken breasts in plain old water) on high for 5 hours and made the teriyaki sauce (which I tripled so that the chicken would be saucy).  I drained off the water and shredded my chicken, poured the sauce over the chicken and turned to 'warm' setting for the rest of the day.  I served it over steamed jasmine rice. city:

country:
None
text:
This is my favorite teriyaki chicken recipe. The first time I made it exactly as the recipe said, and it was great. The second time I reduced the sugar, added extra garlic, and added a half teaspoon of chili powder. It was the perfect kick to balance out the sweetness, and my fiance liked it much more the second time. I always have this sauce in a bottle in my fridge- I make a quadruple batch a couple times a month. I chop up boneless chicken breasts and mix with the sauce in a bowl. Then I let it marinate for about a half hour, or even overnight for a quick dinner the next day. I heat a little oil in a frying pan then cook the chicken and sauce until the chicken is done. It's fabulous poured over rice!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/296438.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made modifications as I went: I prepped as directed but added 2 tbls. of brown sugar and 1/2 cup pineapple juice to give it a sweeter, less soy-sauce taste. To keep the chicken REALLY moist and tender, I waited to thicken my sauce until the end, which allowed the sauce to completely soak through the meat while basting and baking. I did like some others cooking for the first 15 minutes at 400 degrees F then lowering to 350 and cooking 25 minutes longer. After that, I removed the chicken from the oven, set the temperature to BROIL, sliced up my boneless skinless chicken thighs, basted with my newly thickened sauce, and popped in the broiling oven for 5 minutes. After these little tweaks, my chicken wast SO moist, sliced and super flavored like in a teriyaki bowl at a restaurant, and perfectly sweet, not salty.

This was excellent.  I used 9 boneless, skinless thighs in a pan lined with non-stick foil - no mess to clean up!  I used low-sodium soy sauce and half brown & half white sugar.  I also poured the sauce over the thighs & baked till done.  The sauce does thin out due to the chicken juices, but that was OK for me.  We poured the sauce over rice.  My husband, who doesn't like garlic, said he really liked it.  I probably will never buy teriyaki sauce at the store again; this is just too easy & good.

text:
We love this recipe. It's great and very kid friendly…well for my picky eaters. However, I do use chicken breast and cut it into bite size pieces. After I bake it with about half the sauce I drain the extra juices and coat the chicken pieces with the rest of the sauce and bake it until the sauce is warm and nice and stuck on the chicken, usually 5-10 minutes. We love this dish for baseball games in the spring. We use the plastic cups and put rice in the bottom of the cup and top it off with the chicken. The kids always come looking for seconds and it gives my pitcher a chance to grab a bite during down time.

text:
I made this sauce for the first time tonight.  My family is trying to lose weight, and we're eating a lot of chicken and fish.  I made a few modifications so that I can stay within the parameters of the diet.  I substituted Sugar in the Raw for the white sugar, and I substituted 2 tbsp of almond/coconut milk for the cornstarch.  Instead of letting it simmer, I allowed it to come to a boil and then cook down to thicken.  Just make sure to keep stirring and keep an eye on it, because I almost cooked it down to nothing. Finally, I used this as a stir fry sauce instead of for baking the chicken.  It was excellent and better than any teriyaki sauce that I ever bought off the shelf.  You must try this recipe!

userID:
2865806
Display Name:
scopingforyou
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good flavor.  I like a lot of extra sauce to be able to use for rice, etc., so I tripled the sauce.  It definitely was not too much.  I used half brown sugar for the sugar and went just a little light on the sugar, cutting it by maybe 10%,  because of the other reviews (and am glad I did.)  I also used low-sodium soy sauce because of the crazy amount of sodium in the regular, and it was still salty enough and quite flavorful.  

I used breasts and flattened them a bit in a ziploc (to keep the juices from splattering everywhere) because I don't like a thick piece of chicken. I just adjusted the cooking time a bit shorter due to using breasts and due to flattening them. 

You really don't have to keep basting them.  With the sauce I made, basting didn't make any difference; it was staying on fine anyway.  

I did however cover the pan with foil for the first half of each side baking.  In other words, for the time period before turning the breasts over, I had the pan covered half of that time; and for the time period after turning the breast over (halfway through cooking), I had the pan covered for half of that time.  Covering it for the first half helped keep it very juicy; while uncovering it for the second gave it a nice and barely crusty glaze.

Awesome!!!  I did what some of the other viewers recommended. I doubled the sauce, used brown sugar instead of white sugar, ginger powder instead of fresh ginger and garlic in a jar.  I also used lite soy sauce and organic apple cider vinegar. Used boneless chicken breast instead of thighs. This is a good basic recipe.  Like others, I made changes based on personal preference and taste.  I used a Japanese soy sauce that is lower in sodium.  Baking takes a lot out of garlic, so I initially put 4 cloves in the doubled sauce recipe.  Once the sauce was heated and reduced, I put in a couple more.  I also reduced the amount of cider vinegar and replaced the amount with Sake, something I never leave out of any Asian sauces.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy recipe.  First, I doubled the sauce like a few others suggested.  I had ran out of ground ginger after only 1/4 tsp.  Luckily, I had some fresh ginger on had and just minced it to make up the difference.  I only used 4 chicken breast (large breasts) then sliced them into strips.  After my sauce started to bubble, I turned the temp to simmer and put the chicken strips into the sauce itself.  I then let the chicken cook like that.  Not only did it lessen the cooking time by making them into strips, it also allowed the sauce to flavor the chicken all the way through instead of just being brushed on top.  The chicken and sauce were placed on top of hot white sticky rice with a side of veggies.  Will make again and maybe will try the way the recipe calls for, I was just pressed for time so changed things up.

text:
My modified recipe: I used 1/4 cup brown sugar instead of 1/2 cup white. I baked 8 skinned thighs at 425 for 40 minutes ( the thighs were still partially frozen- very cold). I poured 3/4 of sauce on thighs and baked for 25 minutes then poured remaining sauce on and baked for the last 15 minutes. I did not baste. I cut the meat from the bone in slices and served with white rice. It was delicious, everybody ( including my 5 kids) liked it! I would double the recipe if I was making more thighs, but for 8, the recipe yielded the correct amount of sauce.

I made this with the restaurant style fried rice recipe and it was a hit! We ate it two nights in a row! The kids cleaned their plate and asked for seconds! The only thing I changed was I pre-seaoned the chicken and when the sauce was done I poured the entire thing over the chicken, covered with foil and baked 35-40min as described by other reviewer. Extremely tender and delicious! The only thing I would recommend is to be sure to let the sauce get thick as it is simmering as it sticks to the chicken better. I didn't let it get as thick the second night but it was still delicious! Definitely a keeper!

text:
DELICIOUS!! i have made this COUNTLESS times. its the near perfect easy and delicious dinner when you dont have lots of time, or the will to make a complicated dinner. even a 12 yr old can make this. very easy and delicious! like others, i used brown sugar instead of white, extra fresh minced garlic and fresh garlic, and rice vinegar b/c i didnt have cider vinegar. after rinsing my chicken wings, i patted and squeezed extra dry, dry,dry with a paper towel. i baked at 375, the first 25 mins covered with foil (the foil is the part that makes it so delicious), then the last 15 mins uncovered. theres no point in basting it every 10 minutes- waste of time. when i take off the cover after 25 minutes i just spread the sauce around and turn the chicken pieces over. Delish!! end result is so juicy and smooth and fragrant! i could go on about this easy chicken recipe forever!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor was good other than being a bit salty even after using low-sodium soy sauce.  I made it with boneless, skinless thighs.  I doubled the amount of sauce but reduced the white sugar to 1/2 cup for that amount and added 1/4 dark brown sugar. Freshly grated ginger replaced ground.  As per the "Most Helpful" review, I covered the pan with foil for the first 30 minutes and held back about 1/3 of the sauce for basting.  Upon uncovering the chicken after the initial baking period,  the chicken was swimming in liquid and the center pieces were not evenly cooked.  I repositioined those pieces along the perimeter, covered it again & baked for another 10 minutes.  At that point, I uncovered the chicken and baked for another 10 minutes.  The appearance of the chicken was nothing like the sample photo but more of a braised appearance - not what I was hoping to achieve from the photos.  I decided to grill the thighs and baste them with the remaining sauce.  I would recommend grilling rather than baking if at all possible with this recipe.

text:
This is a definite go to recipe on those days when chicken is for dinner but you aren't sure what to do with it. I've been making this for about a year. Made it just like the recipe states and it was wonderful. Life got busier so I modified now for time. I use lite soy sauce like most and boneless skinless breasts since no one in my house likes dark meat. I add all ingredients to a saucepan then when done, just dump it all over the top of the chicken. Cover with foil and bake for 20 minutes or so. Uncover and spoon the sauce over the top and finish baking uncovered another 20 minutes or until done. Works great in a slow cooker too!

text:
I would easily give this 4-1/2 stars!  I followed the recipe with the following changes - I used brown sugar instead of white sugar and 1 tsp fresh grated ginger in place of the ground ginger. Everything else was as stated in the recipe.   I did add 1 big squeeze of Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce - we like it spicy!  I used boneless skinless chicken thighs and cooked them at 375 for 40 minutes basting every 10-15 minutes.  After 40 minutes I basted them one last time and broiled them for 3-4 minutes to get a carmelized top.  Yummy!  Definitely will be adding this to my recipe box!

Prepared this while dressing for church yesterday.  Delicious easy lunch with brown rice and broccoli/cauliflower mix. Liked because: 1. Easy to prepare 2. Simple ingredients and not too many of those. 3.Taste yummy.  My favorite kind of recipe since I have been cooking almost 50 years, I don't want  to work too hard. lol  I always try to follow a recipe the first time as written after reading the reviews.   If I don't have all the ingredients, I go to the grocery and get them. Pet peeve: people who leave out or change half of the ingredients and then say how bad it was! I did use wht/Splenda brn sugar, 1 tsp garlic powder instead of fresh. Cooked at 375, covered for 30 min., turned the meat and uncovered and cooked for about 15 min. more.  The sauce was like a thick pancake syrup, which I really liked. Will try chicken breasts and maybe add a little crushed pineapple to the sauce next time.

text:
OMG! I made this last night for my family and it was a hit! My changes...I doubled the glaze to begin with (you can always freeze any leftover). I used seasoned rice vinegar since I was out of apple cider vinegar. I also used brown sugar per other reviews, the change made sense to me with the combined flavors. I substituted lite soy to cut down on the sodium (a must). Also, I added a can of crushed pineapple. If you add the pineapple, cut back on the sugar. I had chicken breasts on hand and threw in some chicken legs for the kids (all skins removed). ***MAKE SURE you line your pan with aluminum foil! I'm still scrubbing my stovetop with oven cleaner because of spattered glaze. I can only imagine having to clean an entire pan! I served with steamed rice and broccoli for sides. Better than any restaurants at a fraction of the cost. Thanks for the recipe... SO easy and delicious!!! :)

text:
Really nice recipe, got rave reviews from family. I used chicken breast cut in halve and also substituted fresh ginger and rice wine vinnegar. I basted the chicken lightly and baked for 10 min on 400, flipped and baked for another 10 mins. Then added the entire sauce to the pan and baked for remaining 10 min....just until sauce bubbles and thickens.
Top with toasted sesame seeds.

text:
The only thing different I did was cooked it on about 375 and I didn’t brush it every 10 min.   I put the entire sauce in the dish, let it marinade for a few hours then just turned and brushed the chicken 3 times in an hour.  The last few minuets of cooking time, I put it on broil to get the glazed effect on the chicken ~Turned out perfect!!
I made an extra batch of just the sauce then sautéed and stirred in an onion, green, red and yellow peppers and served it over rice.  Perfect meal as is, no side dish needed.  Will make again.

text:
The flavour of this dish was okay, but it wasn't outstanding. I used drumsticks which were moist. I lined a pan with foil and covered with foil for the first 30 mins. The problem was that I expected the sauce to be coated on thicker leaving a sticky saucy coating. The juices from the chicken turned the sauce very watery so that it could not adhere to the chicken meat. They hardly looked cooked because of their pale, milky colour. I'd recommend using this marinade over a grill or where the chicken will not sit in its own juices.

text:
I have made this a couple of times and really enjoy the flavor. I use boneless chicken breast which cook on 400 in about 20-25 minutes. I also highly recommend lining the pan with foil and spraying that. Also don't skip the first step. I tried it the first time without thickening the sauce and it is not nearly as good. I usually thicken on the stovetop as directed but add a little more cornstarch. I also prefer using brown sugar to white. It gives it a richer flavor. Basted often and served with a slice of baked pineapple over brown rice and steamed broccoli on the side. Yummy!

text:
This was really great.  I followed the recommendations for one of the reviewers that used 4 skinless/boneless.  I used an 8x8 pan lined with renolds release tin foil (so I wouldn't have a messy pan to clean).  I added some chopped green onion, pineapple slices, water chesnuts, and slices of an orange bell pepper.  I baked it at 400 for 25 minutes and raised the temp to 425 for the last 10 to get the glaze to thicken and stick to the chicken breasts.  I also basted every 10 mins as suggested.  I served it over white rice with steamed sugar snap peas and carrots.  This one is a keeper and I plan on making it when my mother-in-law visits next week.

userID:
814336
Display Name:
My4NonBlondes
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/667211.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tweak this recipe a bit to be more like the teriyaki chicken you find in restaurants.  I like to use boneless skinless thighs and slice them into bite size strips, then saute them in a bit of olive oil.  Pour the sauce over the top and simmer until the chicken is supertender and shreds easily with a fork.  The sauce gets a little bit watery this way, so once your chicken is cooked, remove it from the pan and bring the sauce to a rapid boil to rethicken.  You can also add a little more cornstarch mixed in with water to help thicken the sauce.  Stir in a splash of vinegar at the end to make the sauce tangy again.  Serve over jasmine rice with steamed broccoli.  YUM!!

text:
Delicious and simple to prepare for high impact! The sauce was perfect, didn't change a thing. The amount of the sauce was just enough for 8 chicken thighs. I browned the chicken thighs in a dutch oven with a little olive oil, then transfered the browned thighs to a greased  glass 9 x 13 pan. I cooked the teriyaki chicken  covered with foil at 375 degrees for about 45 minutes, basting every 15 minutes. I used the dutch oven to make fried rice. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Great recipe. 1st time I did it, I followed everything but it was ok. The sauce was a little to much. 
2nd time I made it, I added a lot of garlic, added more water, a little more ginger, did half white/half brown sugar, shorten the cider vinegar, add more cornstarch since I did it in a crockpot.  I followed someone else review & added pineapple chunks & poured in almost half of the juice from it (the last hour).  I cooked on high I think about 6 hrs. Soooooo tender & delicious. My kids was asking for more.
By the way, I used a big pack of chicken thighs with bone & triple the sauce mix to cover it in crockpot.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken is excellent.  I've tried making it at 350 degrees instead of the 425 called for.  Don't do it.  The high heat is essential for caramelizing the sauce onto the chicken.  I've also questioned the amount of sauce used, because it just barely covers the chicken.  Don't do that either.  The chicken juices render out and make good basting liquid, and the amount of sauce ends up being perfect.  No extras for rice, though, but I made fried rice and didn't need it.  The chicken ends up incredibly juicy and the outside turns a pretty dark brown color.  Will make again and again.

text:
This is an excellent recipe! The first try was awesome. The second time around, I doubled the sauce. I added a bit less sugar and supplemented with honey. 

Also, the oven temp is better IMO around 375/400 degrees, less burning that way. Use a pan that the chicken fits snugly in so the sauce can't spread out and burn.

A definite favorite in my house! Oh, and PS: My picky 2 year old loves it!

text:
Oh, I so loved this recipe! Made no modification, and it turned out just so wonderful!! I was really appreciative that I could make the Teriyaki Sauce from the scratch.  This one was not too rich or too sweet to me.  I don't like the store-bought Teriyaki Sauce in general as they tend to be too sweet, too rich, or simply missing something.  I didn't need to wrap with the foil, with 30 min each side along with every 10 min brushing of the teriyaki sauce did a great job, it was moist and tender when they came out from the oven. The top side of chicken was very well looked like the typical teriyaki chicken with thickened teriyaki sauce on top, and the other side of the chicken was moist, as the juice from the chicken was about 1/3 of the baking dish and kept the another side well moist, so this side, the sauce was a bit thinner looking, but the sauce was already well absorbed in the chicken, so no downside as to the taste.  This recipe will be definitely part of my routine dinner meals :)

text:
Tried this recipe once and it was a hit with my husband! I made a few changes by doubling the sauce, low sodium soy sauce, 3/4c white sugar, used white wine vinegar(b/c that's what i had), 6 boneless skinless chicken breasts cut in half(making them thinner) and 4 gloves of garlic. Placed them in the oven with the sauce brushed on the top and bottom at 350 degrees conven bake for 45 minutes. I basted 2 times (once mid way through and once more at the end. The chicken came out sooo moist and tender! I gave it 4 stars because the juices from the chicken made the sauce thin again. I will remove that text time in mid bake. Still was really good.

text:
This is a delicious recipe. I was worried because I am not a vinegar fan, but all the ingredients just work together for a tasty wonderfulness. I did make a few changes to make it fit our lifestyle better: I doubled the recipe and used low sodium soy sauce, (8) boneless-skinless chicken thighs, 2 rounded tablespoons of cornstarch, 1/2 cup of Splenda granules, and 1/2 cup of Splenda brown sugar blend. It did not taste weird from the sugar substitutes at all. It was simply delicious! We also like spicy, so I rounded the ginger and black pepper spoonfuls. I could definitely pick out the ginger taste, but the pepper only gave it a hint of spiciness without making it taste peppery. This is going to be a new "go to" recipe in our household!

Served with chinese fried rice (also from this website) and green salad.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really Good Teriyaki Chicken. I didn't change the fundamental recipe much, but I did add some things.  First I doubled the sauce as others suggested.  I used low sodium soy and fresh garlic and ginger - I added some hot red pepper flakes to the sauce to add a little kick. I covered the chicken with foil for the first 30 minutes and again for the last 5 minutues because I used skinless, bone-in legs and thighs; even though I basted them, I didn't want them to dry out. I served with regular long cook rice and stir-fried brocolli, carrots and pea pods.  I added a bit of teriyake to the veggies thinned with a little white wine and chicken broth.  It was all really awesome and went together well. Thanks for the great recipe Marian!

text:
Picky husband loved it!! Like most people I did do some changing... my husband can taste any type of vinegar from a mile away so I left that out. I doubled the sauce and so glad I did! I used skinless, boneless breasts and lined my baking pan with foil, laid the chicken on that, covered with sauce and then baked till done. I served with rice and steamed veggies. This will be in the monthly rotation - and this would be a great sauce to use for a lot of dishes.

Edit - I now make this sauce every month to keep on hand. I double it, cook it up and put it in a jar. My family eats a lot of stir fry and rice throughout the month and they love this sauce. Keeping some in the fridge makes it easy to use whenever anyone wants some Terriyaki sauce. Much better than store bought!!

text:
i used chix legs boneless w/ minimal skin that was easy to trim. i actually did not double for sauce; there was plenty!
i didnt baste throughout cooking. 25 mins foil covered then 15 min uncov at 375 ,,
when the chix was done, the sauce wasnot glazy or thick. 
the meat was just a sheer tan color.
but the sauce was delicious!!!
i also used brown sugar (w/a splash of white sugar) but used a whole garlic clove ..
by the way, i "calculated" the recipe for servings of 3 (just me & my hubby)
so if youre expecting a thick dark molasses type glaze burnt on your chix, it wont happen.
but, this dish was DELICIOUS & i will make it again!

I definitely changed it up a bit with chicken breasts--- AMAZING... i hate eating boring chicken all the time, and I took this and instead of cornstarch, used self-rising flour, i used white distilled vinegar, and took 2 thick chicken breasts, cut them in half to shorten cooking time, so it was 4 breasts in a dish, covered the chicken with the sauce (which was still a little watery) and put it in the oven without covering it for 30 minutes!! text:
Flavor was great but my chicken was dry.  Used sliced chicken breasts.  And used 1/4 c White Sugar and 1/4 c Brown Sugar.  I lined my pan with foil for easy cleanup.  Covered with foil for first 30 minutes at 375 degrees, then removed foil and reduced heat to 350 degrees and cooked another 30 minutes.  The whole time brushing with sauce.  Would like to try the sauce with salmon.
Made this a second time with no changes and loved it!  So increased my stars from 3 to 4!

text:
I gather others' review, marinated my bone-in, skin-on chicken pieces overnight and lined pan with foil before baking. I reduced amount of sugar, soy sauce and cider vinegar (roughly by 1 tbsp each) to suit personal taste, and increased the lack amount with water instead. Meanwhile, I doubled the amount of ginger and garlic (to make it spicier) and baked at 425 degree for 1 hour (1/2 hour covered and remaining ½ hour uncovered). Chicken DID NOT stick to foil like others and they taste GOOD… very much oriental-style…tender, juicy and yummy! Thank you for this quick and easy recipe.

Good recipe! I doubled the sauce, marinated the chicken in it overnight in the fridge, then dumped it all in the crock pot in the AM and cooked on low all day. Meat fell off the bone and the chicken had a thick layer gooey, yummy teriyaki sauce from sitting in it all night. The only way this would have been better is if I'd have grilled the chicken first to give it that grilled teriyaki taste, but I didn't have time!

This is one great baked chicken recipe! I've been making a variation of this recipe for years,but my old recipe just got replaced by this one:) The sauce was very easy to make...I substituted brown sugar for the white sugar,added a little shot of Teriyaki just bacause I had some,and a few sprinkles of chili powder.I,like some of the other reviewers,did not baste every 10 minutes as the recipe called for. Scaled this down to 2 portions and used it as a sauce for tofu, yellow bell pepper and green salad onions. Used fresh ginger, honey and sherry vinegar as that is what we had in. Marinaded the tofu and veg for about half an hour and then stir fried them, added the sauce and voila a lovely meal as good as a bottled sauce.

text:
I am a novice cook so I am always looking for easy recipes... other than the constant basting, this one was easy and my fiance loved it.  I made no changes to the recipe itself, but I did only cook it for 40 minutes (uncovered) and it turned out great.  Again, I am a novice, so maybe it cooked quickly because I only had 6 chicken thighs instead of the suggested 12 but other reviewers seemed to also reduce the cook time...  Agree with other reviewers too... definitely coat your baking pan with foil... it makes clean up much easier!

text:
I used boneless skinless chicken breasts and added a little honey to the sauce. IF you use chix breasts too make sure you reduce the baking because breasts cook fast! I baked mine at 375 for about 25 min (flipping them 1/2 way through) i had fairly large chicken breasts which i also pounded.  I doubled the sauce so that I could use the reserve to stir fry with bok choy and frozen stirfry veggies (snow peas, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, carrots etc courtesy of Trader Joes) Served it over brown rice. VERY good.

text:
A moist, tender chicken dish in a thick, flavorful sauce. We loved it and I'll DEFINITELY make it again! I made the recipe exactly as stated, except that I used chicken tenders instead of the bone-in thighs and reduced the baking time to 20 minutes. Any longer and I think the glaze would have begun to caramelize and burn. Next time I'll use reduced-sodium soy sauce, as the teriyaki came out a bit salty for my taste. I served the chicken with baked sweet potatoes on the side; I'd definitely double the sauce if planning to serve it over rice.

city:

country:
None
text:
Definitely a keeper!  I used some other reviewers suggestions: half white/half brown sugar for the sauce; doubled the sauce for extra goodness; used chicken breasts cut into thirds in lieu of thighs (for lower fat content); marinated the chicken in part of the sauce (maybe 1/4 to 1/3 of my doubled batch) for 30 minutes; lined my pyrex dish with foil for easy cleanup.  I didn't bother basting every 10 minutes since the marinade was sufficient coating.  However I did flip my chicken pieces over after 15 minutes and let them cook for another 15. They came out great!  NEXT TIME:  We like thinner pieces of chicken so I plan on thinning the breasts by cutting in half widthwise.  This of course will shorten the cooking time even further.  And in the summertime we can envision grilling the marinated pieces out on the BBQ.  YUM!  Thighs, of course, would be absolutely juicy and super tender.  But you pay for it in the fat :)

text:
Excellent recipe! Probably my favorite asian dish to cook now that I have perfected the recipe to our taste! I add some pineapple (YUM!!) for the last twenty minutes since we love pineapple in our asian dishes, and use boneless skinless chicken breasts instead of thighs. Also, it is very important to continue brushing the chicken with the sauce every ten minutes, so the flavor can soak into the chicken, otherwise it will be a little bland.

text:
The sauce in this recipe is quite good, but there's not enough. After I coated both sides of the chicken, there wasn't enough left to baste the chicken with at the 10-minute intervals. I would at least double the sauce recipe. You can't have too much of this sauce so don't worry, you can use it with rice or tofu as well. Yum! Also, be sure to check the done-ness of the chicken well before 60 minutes. Mine was done in only 40 minutes.

text:
I will never buy another bottled sauce again.  I made slight modifications.  First, double the recipe!  I used chicken brsts which I cut into chunks.  I lined my dish with foil (highly recommended).  I used 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 1/4 cup of regular sugar.  I used 4 cloves of crushed garlic.  I used Lite soy sauce.  I cooked the sauce on the stovetop, and had to add a bit more cornstarch to thicken.  I poured it over the chicken chunks and baked uncovered at 385 degrees for 40 minutes.  I served with wild rice and steamed broccoli, and I added a grilled piece of pineapple to the top. Absolutely the best!

text:
The whole family (including the 2 and 4 year old grandkids) loved this chicken! I used lite soy too, and poured some sauce in the baking dish and some on top, then as it thickened in the pan I turned the chicken periodically, but not every 10 minutes. Also baked them uncovered. When serving I scooped some of the thickened sauce out of the pan and made sure each piece was covered. I just made baked potatoes and steamed brocolli on the side (kid friendly). Next time I plan to make some kind of rice and an oriental salad with mandarin oranges. Easy and good. I also think we would love it using chicken breasts. Remember to take the skin off whatever cut you use...you don't want to miss any of the sauce!

I made this but put it all in the crockpot, on low for about 6 hours. I also added carrots, green pepper, and celery. text:
Please, oh please do the basting! It made such a difference. It was juicy, and the sticky glaze made me want to cry tears of joy. I have made this before and doubled the sauce to avoid basting. Don't. Unless you plan to use the sauce over rice or something, don't bother. Still good for sure, but just not the same. Having less sauce made sure it caramelized just right. I did use low-sodium soy sauce which helped with the saltiness others complained about. I will definitely make this again.

userID:
10423369
Display Name:
Peregrinus
isPro:

2

7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it exactly as indicated, (I'm not a big fan of reviewing recipes which one has substantially altered.)Next time I make the recipe, I will make 3 changes, which I am certain will raise it to 'OMG I want the best teriyaki ever right now!' status. First, the sauce, though almost perfection, doesn't need as much powdered ginger. I'd use 1/4 tsp. Second, I'd double the amount of sauce, because it's so darn good people are going to want it for passing with the rice. Third, a 425 degree oven for 1 hour is way too long and way to high for boneless, skinless chicken thighs. Next time, I'll brine bone-in, skin-on pieces, place them on a wire rack and bake for 45 minutes at 400. I know I'm sounding super-critical, but I actually loved this recipe! Just needs a few small tweaks...

text:
Awesome!! The sauce was so easy to make and much better than any bottled sauce. I cooked 6, bone-in thighs and kept the sauce amount the same. I cooked them bone side up, (at 350 in a glass pan) for the first 30 minutes then flipped them over for the last 30 minutes. In a smaller pan, I didn't even have to baste it. I sprayed my pan with cooking spray for easy clean-up. With steamed rice and a crisp salad it was a great meal!

text:
This was very easy to make and I added a pinch of chili flakes, pineapple chunks, red pepper chopped in cubes and roughly chopped onions. I also sprinkled the green of the green onions over top when it came out of the oven. Make sure to use tin foil to line your pan and spray well with oil. I cooked my boneless skinless chicken thighs at 400 for 40 min., basting twice, and let cool for 10 min. before serving.  Excellent!

text:
Really enjoyed this!  I'm glad I didn't listen to the reviewers about doubling the sauce.  I used 6 thighs and 6 drumsticks, and the chicken was swimming in the sauce by the end.  Definitely no need to have more.  The only changes I made were to triple the garlic and cut down on the sugar (1/4 C brown instead of 1/2 C white).  Baked covered at 375 for 30 minutes, turned and basted, and cooked uncovered for 20.  The chicken was awesome.  Even my incredibly picky 4 year old ate it!

text:
Fabulous recipe!  The sauce is rich, complex and delicious.  Definitely double up the sauce, and if you like spice, season the chicken with a bit of garlic powder and ground pepper before adding the sauce on top.  After pouring about 75% of the sauce on the chicken, I covered the pan with foil and cooked at 375 degrees for 25 minutes, and then added the remainder of the sauce and cooked uncovered for 15 minutes. The chicken is very tender, flavorful and by adding quinoa and carrots, this made for a delicious meal.

text:
I made this recipe as written, except my thighs were not skinless. I liked the idea of using the various ingredients, instead of buying bottled teriyaki sauce, but found the end result less than hoped for. While a lot of folks use a timer to tell them when something is done, it's much better to use a thermometer. I found the chicken got to an internal temp of 165 (perfect), long before it had been in the oven for 60 minutes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, I only gave this recipe 3 stars. It was far too sweet and we don't like chicken thighs.  However, with a few changes, this recipe is 5 stars and the whole family loves it.  The changes I made were, using boneless skinless chicken breast, cutting the sugar in half and subbing brown sugar for "half of the half", used low sodium soy sauce, a little bit of red chili flakes for some spice, tablespoon of peanut butter and a little sesame oil, and baked the chicken for only 30 minutes.  This is on the weekly rotation now.  If you like a lot of sauce to put over rice, double all sauce ingredients.

This recipe is fantastic! I use it over boneless skinless chicken breasts and it is amazing. Took it to a church group one night and a friend tasted it them promptly invited herself over whenever I made it again. Best teriyaki sauce I've had, restaurant or otherwise. I generally do it without the cornstarch and water, then let it cook a little longer to thicken up. Baste the chicken and set the remaining sauce on the table to use as needed. I serve this over Garlic Rice from this site and it is a meal that never fails to please!

text:
This recipe is awesome! I doubled the recipe and had 4 smaller chicken thighs (boneless). I cooked covered with foil for 30min then flipped them and cooked covered still for 30 more min. Covering it made the meat so tender! I made the sauce before baking and let the thighs sit in it for about an hour. Think about doing that. Low sodium soy sauce would have been better, I just didn't have it, but I cut the regular soy sauce in half with water. This is so yum! This would be great to make in bulk for a party. I served over  brown rice.

text:
Thank you for such a great recipe, I marinated the chicken over night in the sauce.  I used brown sugar instead of white sugar.  I also omitted the ginger and added a few sprigs of rosemary, which added a totally different flavor to the sauce.  If you marinate in the sauce overnight or for any length of time, you can reuse the sauce if you put it in a pan and bring to a boil for about 10 minutes to cure the sauce of any bacteria from the chicken, etc.  Either way, this was a wonderfully different recipe.  Thanks!  There is no limit to what you can use this for, sweet and sour, add hoisin and make it a little peppery, very great recipe, thanks again!

text:
Even if you don't want chicken, you really should make the sauce for this, and double it, if you want a good teriyaki sauce! This stuff tastes way better than than the mix/bottles you get at the store, and so much better for you because you can control the salt (use lower sodium soy sauce) and other ingredients (no high fructose corn syrup or some gobblygoop sounding ingredients here!). Definitely use fresh ginger though, not ground...it makes a difference!

text:
Add a another 5 stars!  I also prepared this recipe using 1/3 cup soy sauce as suggested by other viewers.  I had 3 large boneless chicken which I pounded flat to about a 1-inch thickeness.  I poured all of the sauce mixture over the chicken breasts and topped with pineapple tidbits and and coarsley chopped red pepper (that I had on hand) and sprinkled with a few red pepper flakes.  The chicken baked for about 35 minutes at 350 degress and was done perfectly....moist and tender. I did baste the chicken with the sauce twice during the baking period.  Brown rice and a green vegetable was served with the chicken...delish!  I will be preparing this recipe again!!

Display Name:
TJ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
5 stars with a couple changes. I used equal parts white sugar, light brown sugar and dark brown sugar (if you double the sauce use 1/3 cup each). This was to enable it to caramelize the sugar without too much molasses flavor. I also used rice vinegar instead of cider. 
Tthe 2nd time I made this I sauted the chicken with a little of the sauce until it was browned all over and the sauce had caramelized. Then I added the rest and simmered it for about 30-40 minutes until the sauce thickened. The result was awesome! I do recommend using reduced sodium soy sauce if you do this or it will be a bit too salty after the sauce reduces that long.

text:
Update:  I used brown sugar, all of what was called for and it was divine.  We ate it with brussell sprouts.  

Definitely cut down on the sugar - WAY too sweet!  And double the sauce.  I used fresh ginger and next time will use lite soy sauce.  I covered the chicken with foil for the first 30 mintues and while it was cooking, I stir-fryed some chopped bell peppers, an onion and some sliced mushrooms for about 3-4 mintues.  Then for the last 30 minutes of cooking, I took the foil off and tossed the veggies in the pan and covered everything with the rest of the sauce.  Cooked it uncovered & served t with rice.  If it were not for the dish being too sweet because of the darn sugar, it would have been perfect!

userID:

Display Name:
ValleyLily
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was good. I listened to a lot of the reviews. I doubled the sauce recipe to baste the chicken. I only had sodium soy sauce, so I added the amount posted (because I doubled the recipe) and then added more to taste. I used brown sugar instead of white sugar (doing the same thing with the brown sugar as I did the soy sauce). My chicken was partially frozen so I baked for 30 minutes at 375 covered and then 30 minutes at 350 uncovered and turning every 20 minutes. The chicken was a little drier than expected and I think basting every 10 minutes might be excessive. I think you can baste every 20 minutes and be all right. The flavor of the sauce was good even though I'd never heard of using vinegar in a teriyaki sauce. I think if I make this again, I might marinate the chicken in the teriyaki in order to add more flavor.

text:
Mmmm, yummy! Made as directed but subbed dried minced garlic & fresh ginger. I didn't bother to thicken the sauce prior but rather poured it over the chicken to marinate 2 hours. The sauce thickened well enough on it's own while it was baking & the more I basted the more of that yummy glaze built-up on the chicken pieces & I am telling you don't ignore the advice of others & DO double the sauce recipe. You'll want to keep dipping your chicken into it as you eat & will probably want to pour a little over your rice as well! De-licious!

text:
We LOVE this recipe.  It's delicious, lowfat, and does not make a mess of the kitchen like a lot of asian dishes can.  I used fresh ground ginger (the bottled kind you keep in the fridge).  If you 1/2 the sugar like some suggest, it's WAY too salty. Perhaps start out with half and add more to suit your tastes, but it's teriyaki! It's supposed to be sweet.  Definitely double the sauce, you'll regret it if you don't.  The only thing I add is a splash of sesame oil.  Fabulous!

text:
I made this exactly as written with the exception of I hate basting so I poured half of the most wonderful sauce on my leg quarters. I first had them skin side down.  I then baked (350) them for 30min. then turned them over skin side up and baked the last 40 min after pouring the rest of the sauce over them. I also used a small aluminum pan. Easy clean up! Toss it! WhooHoo! Regardless of skin on, off we like skin on with all parts of the fat removed. This was the best ever tasting chicken. I can't wait to use this on a whole baked chicken. Then I will have to baste. Love this!

text:
I didn't care for the taste of the sauce at all in the beginning.  Even after reducing and thickening, I was thinking to myself "blech - I hope this turns out".  And turn out it did - I couldn't get enough of it!  I was only cooking for 2 of us, but I made a full batch of sauce and cooked each chicken thigh in individual ramikens (covered with foil for 35", then without for 10).  I let them rest for 10 minutes and when we were ready to eat, they were fall of the bone tender.  We ladeled the sauce cooked with the chicken over steamed rice and were in heaven.  We'll be trying this grilled, on skewers with pineapple, and - oh, I have 20 different ideas!  Thank you so much for recipe - a real keeper!  So happy I made a full batch of sauce as we'll be using the rest as a marinade later on in the week.

userID:

Display Name:
ninny

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazing! My husband, toddler, and I all loved it!  I used different information from other users' comments to come up with my creation.  I doubled the sauce, which I think is a must.  I used  1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar. I covered the chicken for the first half hour. I baked the chicken at 350 degrees for 1 hour.  I brushed them with sauce about every 10 minutes and turned over the pieces after 30 minutes. 
The one thing I did differently than everyone else- I think- is I used only 1/4 cup regular soy sauce and 1/2 stick of unsalted butter.  The butter took away the excess saltiness and gave the sauce an amazing taste. I'd read somewhere a long time ago that adding butter or some other fatty substance to your cooking can take away saltiness.  Worked for me and made an amazing sauce!

text:
This was delish!!! I made some changes so that it would be healthier. I made my own soy sauce by boiling then simmering 3 c's water, 1/4 c red wine vinegar, 1/4 c honey, 1/4 tsp black pepper, 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp ginger, 1/4 tsp garlic for 30 mins or untiI had about 1/2 c of soy sauce. Instead of the sugar I used 1/2 of honey and added 1/2 tsp of salt. It came out awesome! My bf loved it and wanted more. Next time I make it though I think I will cut back on the garlic. I think it offset the flavor a bit. Otherwise 5 stars!!

text:
LOVED this sauce!!! Even my EXTREMELy finnicky-eater grandson ate TWO thighs, and requested left-overs a couple days later. When I heated him up one, he asked for the other as well...you just don't know how hard it is to get him to eat anything!! For those reviewers who said to cut the sugar...I say DO NOT mess with this recipe!! It is WONDERFUL as written. The only thing I did different was to turn and coat every 15 minutes rather than every 10 minutes. Since I used skinless thighs (didn't want to, but had no choice...), I did cover the pan the first 30 minutes. THESE TURNED OUT FANTASTIC!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/631672.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is definitely a favorite now.  I do agree with other reviewers who say the sauce should be doubled.  I only used 6 thighs and the original amount of sauce and it worked out fine.  If doing more chicken, however, it would not be enough.  Also, I did not have cider vinegar on hand so I replaced it with white wine vinegar and the sauce still tasted delicious.  I also used a mixture of white AND brown sugar instead of only white.  You can definitely amp up the heat a little when cooking the sauce if it is taking too long.  The cooking time for the chicken is perfect.  I didn't find any need to change that.  You can get away with brushing the chicken every 15 minutes if you find every 10 is too tedious.  I also poured the remaining sauce over the chicken once there were only 10 minutes remaining.  A little time consuming but definitely worth it !!

text:
Great recipe! Since my first post, I have made this 2 more times. The first time I added the sauce to fish and it was ok (no fault of the sauce, I'm just not that into fish).  The second time I made the recipe as written and the only addition I made was adding crushed peanuts at the end.  It was delish! As written, the sauce becomes a yummy glaze.  The last time I made this I added a pint of fresh diced mushrooms and baked the chicken with the mushrooms, it was great too!  The mushrooms definitely made it more liquidy, but it was perfect over rice.  Glaze or with the mushrooms - both are great,  I will definitely make this my go to teriyaki.  Can't wait to try it on meatballs, burgers and more.  Thanks!!!

text:
I followed the davice of others and doubled the sauce except I used 1/2 cup suagr and 1/4 cup brown sugar and only 3/4 cup soy sauce.  I added a little extra garlic.  I cooked 4 boneless skinless breasts with all the sauce at 375 for 25 minutes covered with foil.  I then took the foil off, turned the pieces over and brushed with sauce and cooked uncovered for an additional 15 minutes,  They turned out better than I expected.  I will definitely make these again.

I am the only big teriyaki fan...well was years ago, but I guess I am still looking for that "Happy Teriyaki" thickness and flavor...(it's a resturant chain in WA)

I covered the dish with foil (because I used brown sugar instead of white and I figured the dish would get crusty), and baked it at 375 for about 40 minutes. I served it over brown rice and I'll definitely be making it again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-08-11T20:34:45.543
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
4557504
Display Name:
sweetfanatic
isPro:
False

favoritesCount:
