photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/449713.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! Tasted soo good! What I did differently was used chicken breasts, and cut them into cubes. That's how I usually eat teriyaki chicken at restaraunts. The chicken baked at 30 minutes (maybe cause I was using cubed pieces of chicken?). One reviewer said that her sauce didn't thicken.. mine thickened like honey! You should turn the heat up a little bit when cooking the sauce.. after it boils, set it aside to cool down a bit. It won't thicken while it's on the stove.. it needs to cool down. If you used the cornstarch, then it should thicken, no doubt! Luckily I had some extra sauce which I poured on the chicken after I took it out. If you don't have extra sauce, cook up some more! The chicken is not the same without the extra teriyake merinade! Remember to NOT use the leftover water/juice from when the chicken was baking! It can really make you sick!

text:
Sauce never really thickened for me, but had great flavor. I doubled the sauce recipe per other's suggestions with the exception of the soy and Ginger. Additionally I used lite soy sauce and jarred minced garlic (all I had). I also took the suggestions of others and lined the pan with foil and covered with foil while baking. I used bonless skinless thighs and baked for 30 min at 400 with half the sauces poured on top. Then I flipped the chicken, poured the rest of the sauce on top and baked for another 30 min at 400. The chicken was super tender and clean up was a breeze. I served with steam Asian veggie medley and white rice.

text:
All gone! The whole family loved it. I did not change the recipe but I did change the way I tackled it. I don't have time to sit in the kitchen and brush/baste every 10 minutes. I made the sauce early in the day, let it cool slightly and put it in a gallon ziplock bag along with the thighs. It marinated in the fridge all day. When I was ready to cook, I poured everything into a glass pie dish (to keep the juice almost covering the chicken for moistness) and turned after 15 minutes. Only took another 15 min to cook thoroughly (30 min total). SO GOOD and much easier.

text:
Chicken was pretty good. At first I was afraid the vinegar might be too overpowering but it turned out just fine, adding just the right bit of zing to the flavor. Like other reviewers, I added less sugar and a bit more garlic. I did not have a problem with the sauce thickening and made the amount of sauce the original recipe called for which was just enough. I'm not sure if I would call it teriyaki chicken though because it doesn't taste like the traditional japanese teriyaki chicken I've had at restaurants. If anything my own concoction of soy sauce, sugar, and rice wine tasted closer to the latter ( I might add this recipe to the site later so stay tuned) . I also took other reviewers' suggestion of baking the chicken for only 35 minutes which came out just right. I would make this again.

country:
None
text:
Pretty good! My fiance thought this was too sweet, but happily ate it anyways. :) I've had this recipe on my "to try" list for some time. I needed a quick-fix meal last night, so I decided to give this a try. The fact that, start to finish, this took under an hour to prepare AND called for basic ingredients I already had on hand, made this a winner! I pretty much followed Marian's directions exactly except for two changes. First, I used a package of three boneless, skinless chicken breasts (I HATE dark meat!) and low-sodium soy sauce (I was afraid that regular would be too salty). I lined my 9 x 9-inch baking dish with a double-thickness of aluminum foil for easy clean-up. I ended up baking first at 375 degrees for 15 minutes, basting/turning, then reducing the temp to 350 and baking for another 20 minutes, basting/turning every 10 minutes as directed. My only gripe is that my meat was a tad dry, but I don't blame that on the recipe (after all, I DID use breasts). Served with basmati rice, sugar snap peas and iced green tea, this was a decent Saturday night meal. Thanks for sharing! :-)

text:
Although I make this at least every other week(BTW, my husband normally hates chicken but he loves this recipe) I don't bake it. I make the sauce, marinate the chicken in it for about 20 min. or so in the fridge while the grill warms up and then grill it. I don't baste the chicken on the grill. I disguard the sauce once I've put all the chicken on the grill.  I agree with everyone about doubling up on the sauce. I also serve the chicken cut up over a bowl of white rice. DELISH!!!!

text:
I made the sauce exactly as the recipe states and my husband and I both thought the balance of sweet/tangy was perfect.  I put 6 thighs in a glass dish, basted with sauce, covered with foil and baked at 375 for 20 minutes.  I removed the foil and basted again, baked for 10 minutes uncovered.  In the last 10 minutes, I upped the oven temp to 400 and basted twice.  The chicken came out perfect and clean up was a breeze.  Paired with white rice and some broccoli, this was a fantastic weeknight dinner.  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
I don't see how people can say to use chicken breasts and to dump in all the sauce before you bake.  I tried that the first time and was left with bland chicken which while not bad, wasn't memorable.

This time we used thighs and brushed sauce on the meat every 10 minutes and it made all the difference in the world.  This is one case where the recipe is better left untouched.

The one thing I agree with from the comments, put some foil paper in your pan before you bake this.  Otherwise you are left with a mess of burnt sauce.

I made this with chicken breasts and doubled the sauce.  We had leftovers, so I made teriyaki chicken wraps. I used 1 Tbsp. melted butter and added a package of crushed ramen noodles and 2 Tbsp. sesame seeds.  Baked them in a 350 oven for 10 mins.  Then made the wraps by using chopped teriyaki chicken, shredded cabbage, and the noodle/sesame seed mixture.  Put them in a flour tortilla shell and topped them off with a little extra teriyaki sauce.  Absolutely delish!

text:
fantastic teriyaki sauce!  We don't like dark meat chicken, so I used boneless skinless breasts.  I used low sodium soy sauce and did not have a problem with it being too salty.  After taking the sauce off the stove, I stirred in a SMALL amount of toasted sesame oil.  As some other reviewers recommended I doubled the sauce, and I also added some cut up FRESH (not canned) golden pineapple to the chicken in the dish before pouring the sauce over all.  Chicken was very tender! Next time I am going to use the sauce for beef.  Thinly slice some top sirloin, and lay the slices out in a baking pan, drenched with the sauce, and bake till tender.  Will be delicious folded up in some flatbread with sauteed green peppers and onions.

Awesome dish! My wife and I enjoyed it. I made the recipe exactly as written, just doubled the quantities so I had left overs. I had bone-in thighs, so I had to remove the bones. Whew! Next time, I buy the boneless thighs and save myself some time. This is a keeper, and has been added to the recipe book. 

Have made some notes though. DON'T use lite soy sauce b/c I can taste the difference from regular soy sauce. Use half brown and half white sugar. Use ground garlic so that it dissolves in the liquid better. Otherwise, that's it. 

EXCELLENT RECIPE!! THANKS!

text:
This was awesome. Used chicken breasts cut into 1 3/4" strips. I followed a few tips from several of the reviews. I doubled the sauce recipe and still only used about half the sugar; it was still quite sweet. I added a few dashes of red pepper flakes to give it a subtle kick. Also, the tin foil lining for the baking pan is a must!!!! I placed the chicken in the foil-lined pan and poured all the sauce over the top so that the chicken was pretty much engulfed. Baked for 30 minutes at 425 degrees, turned the chicken, removed the foil and baked for an additional 15 minutes. I am going to make it again for sure!!!

text:
This recipe far exceeded my expectations! I followed the recipe except I added 2 heaping tablespoons of garlic chopped, halved the soy sauce, and added 3/4 cup of unsweetened apple sauce. I put thighs and legs in the crock pot, and I wanted a little more quantity of sauce so it wouldn't burn, so I added the apple sauce. It worked great: didn't dilute the flavor of the sauce, and kept it from burning. Cooked in crock pot on high for 5 hours and served the sauce over brown rice on the side. AWESOME! Can't wait to make it for company.

text:
Tried this today, and so glad I did!  I doubled the sauce as others mentioned, using 1/2 dark brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar, and spooned it over chicken pieces to start, then basted once before turning, and twice after turning. I did not cover, but did bake about 15 minutes longer (in my unpredictable 1954 oven!) and they came out delectably tender. As I am serving them tonight, I have placed chicken and sauce from the pan into a large ziplock bag in fridge till later - I hope this might allow the teriyaki flavor to permeate the chicken even more, as it has EXCELLENT flavor. Just the right amount of sweetness for our tastes. PLEASE DO line pan with HEAVY-DUTY foil...I did, and so glad others mentioned it!

text:
1,089 reviewers can't be wrong. The only substitution I made was using Splenda instead of sugar. My only complaint is that I should have doubled the recipe. We served it over steamed rice and having more of that incredible sauce to pour over the rice would have been great. Loved it. Thanks.  That was over a year ago. Yesterday I decided to make it again, but read some of the newer comments. This time I did double the sauce, but also added a can of drained pineapple chunks, sliced water chestnuts, a handful of snow peas and chunks of green bell pepper to the sauce as I cooked it. I lined my pan with parchment paper and cleanup was a snap. Then I poured all of the sauce with all of the chunky things over the chicken and baked uncovered for about 45 minutes. Served over rice. All I can think to say is OMG. It was incredible. Deserves more than 5 stars.

text:
Terrific sauce! I dissolved the cornstarch in the cold water first and once it was gloppy i added 3 TBSP of orange juice. I used 1/2 a cup of brown sugar and 1/2 a cup of white sugar, i substituted rice vinegar for the apple cider vinegar.  double the amount of garlic, used dark soy sauce instead of regular soy sauce. And a splash of lemon juice. Instead of baking the chicken breast, I dry rubbed it with a little seasoning, chopped into chunks and then I sauteed it on a griddle with seasame seeds and and green onions basting the chicken with the sauce about every 5 minutes until it carmelized.  served over authentic chinese rice with stir fried broccoli,water chestnuts, bean sprouts peppers, and mushrooms.  My boyfriend loved it and so did the baby, she started kicking all over the place. Way better than any teriyaki i've had, esp. since I usually pay $10 at the one in the mall since they were always my favorite.

This is a tasty, easy recipe, but if your using chicken breasts to cut the fat and calories, I'd suggest lowering the temp. to *375.  Chicken breast really dry out at the higher temp in the recipe.  I usually serve this with coconut rice and a veggie.  Kids love it!

text:
My family enjoyed this, but I have to say I made a few changes.  I added more cornstarch as the sauce was too thin, I substituted brown sugar for the white sugar and I cooked this on the stove top.  Made the sauce in a non stick, heavy stock pot.  Browned cut up thigh pieces in a dutch oven in hot EVOO, drained the meat, returned it to the dutch oven and poured the sauce over the meat.  Simmered for about 10 minutes, added broccoli and thin, diagonally sliced carrots and green onions and cooked for 5 more minutes.  I served it over fried rice and it was great.

So easy and so delicious! #1 thing to do is line your baking dish with foil! This is very necessary otherwise you will be scraping away at sugar that has been burnt onto the glass. I made a revision that changed the taste and made it sooo much better than it already is. I toasted three tablespoons of sesame seeds (easy to do, heat pan on high toast seeds for two minutes each side) and mixed it in when the sauce was done cooking. Delicious! Thank you.

I found this recipe while looking for something to do with the chicken thighs I bought on sale at the grocery store.  My husband doesn't eat anything that sounds Asian since he claims not to like it, so I just didn't tell him that this was "teriyaki" chicken and he really enjoyed it!  I made the recipe as directed except I left out the ginger since I'm not a fan.  I also skinned the thighs.  I baked it in an oven bag - clean up was easy and I didn't have to keep brushing the sauce over top.  This was moist, yummy and is now in regular dinner rotation in my house!

helpfulCount:

userID:
891842
Display Name:
SUNNYRUTTER
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
22
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the best teri sauce I've ever made, which is saying a lot as I live in Hawaii and have made A LOT of teri sauce!!
My changes were:
1/8 c. brown sugar, 1/8 c. reg. white sugar & 1/4 c. Splenda (cooking kind). Used white vinegar as I was out of apple cider vinegar, BUT... stirred in 4 oz. apple sauce for that flavor. I only use 'low sodium' Aloha shoyu (soy sauce). And I used 1 inch fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated. I didn't add the cornstarch until later. I mixed up the sauce, used it to marinate my raw chicken for 6 hrs. Then, while they were grilling, I brought the marinade to a boil for 2 mins. (you must do this to kill any bacterial from the raw chicken). Then I added the cornstarch that I had mixed cold water into, making a 'slurry'. Turned down the heat and stirred constantly until correct thickness. Removed from heat, covered & served with grilled chicken & 'sticky white rice' (made with Calrose rice... the way we like it over here)and kernel corn on the side. 
Amazing! Thanks for this winner of a recipe!

text:
Not only is this teriyaki chicken the best I've ever had, it is fairly simple to make and the ingredients are all things I generally have in my pantry.  The chicken turns out so flavorful and so juicy that you can eat it all by itself.  I used boneless chicken breasts instead of thighs and baked them for 30 minutes instead of an hour with the sauce poured all over them.  I turned and basted them every ten minutes.  They could not have turned out better.

text:
This sauce is amazing although I made a few tweaks. I added 1 cup orange juice to the sauce (scaled to serve 3, added a little more corn starch to thicken it, 3 cloves garlic and used 2 chicken legs. I found the extra liquid was perfect and added a great flavour to the chicken. 425 was way too high in my oven to cook the chicken so I turned it down to 350.  
Fantastic sauce! I will definatley try it with pork chops next time!
Thanks for the great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
In a word, delicious.  The sauce was exceptional.  I used red wine vinegar, lite soy sauce, granulated fructose instead of sugar (used about 3/4 of a cup for the double batch of sauce I made instead of a full cup), made a double batch of sauce, set the oven to 375, lined the pan in foil, added a couple of extra skinless thighs, and the recipe was done in 50 minutes.

I served brown rice with this and spooned the sauce over the rice.  I also boiled some delicious corn cobettes.  We also had a little cottage cheese on the side - overall, a very hearty and delicious meal.  Thanks to all who offered additional suggestions - they were all worthwhile.

While I did brush sauce on the chicken every ten minutes, I wish more of the sauce had penetrated inside the chicken.  Maybe that's to much to ask without marinating.  Next time, I will serve individual sides of sauce which would be used to dip the chicken for added flavor.  The sauce is clearly the highlight of this recipe.  Good stuff Maynard.

text:
This was SO good! We need more than five stars here! The sauce was delicious and it doubled easily (recommended). What a delicious combination of flavors. My only substitutions were to use regular vinegar and lower-sodium soy sauce, and it turned out great. I pour the entire amount of sauce on at once and let it bake until the chicken is done - so easy this way. Be sure to line your pan with a double layer of foil for easy clean-up. I serve it with sticky rice and broccoli - the family LOVES this and requests it often.

text:
I only made slight technique changes, everything else was right where it should have been. The sauce had a great balance of sweet and tangy. I chose to marinate 6 skinless chicken thighs in a 1/4 cup of the prepared sauce overnight. I cooked as directed. Marinating allowed the flavor to really penetrate rather than just having a surface flavor. Also I would NOT recommend covering as other posts suggest. This sort of dish really benefits from the build up of the layers of caramelizing sauce to bring out the proper flavor profile. Awesome recipe, thanks!!

text:
The recipe is really for a Teriyaki marinara sauce that works for the oven or for a grill.  But it gives a sweet soy sauce type flavor.  I followed the instructions and cooked in the oven since it was my first time making it.  Setting the oven at 425 ensures the chicken will be done, and it was not overcooked.

I served it with fried rice, but I'm sure it goes good with anything.

What I really like about the instructions, is that tells you exactly what to add and how long to cook.  Just follow the instructions and it will turn out great!!

First of all, this is quite delicious and the whole family loved it. I made one BIG change (as someone mentioned in their review) and just added everything to the crock pot. Placed the chicken in first then blended all the ingredients and poured over. Cooked about 4 hours on low then added in 2 cups of frozen Asian style veggies, and a small can of pineapple tidbits (then let that cook for about an hour). Served over rice, and it was simply wonderful

text:
I make this more than any other recipe on AllRecipes so I figured I should probably rate it.  It is excellent as-written. I don't change a thing. I have never made double-sauce and I have never felt that it needed it.  I usually do try to baste the chicken with the sauce/juices a few times while baking, but I have forgotten to do this on some occasions (and I rarely do it every 10 minutes as suggested) and it still turns out great.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very easy to make and would give 100 stars.  Perfect base sauce for any meat.  Made it exactly as was listed with only a slight variation to the cooking method.  Instead of basting every ten min., I double the sauce and dipped the chicken to coat. Then poured sauce over the chicken.  Covered and cooked for 30 min. Then took chicken out of oven turned chicken and turned heat down to 375(started chicken at 400). finished cooking uncovered for an additional 30 minutes. Absolutely delish.  The only thing I will change when making this again will be to cut chicken into strips.  I will make this often. **For a side I made lo mien noodles. Cook noodles according to package and set aside.  For the sauce  I used 1  cup chicken stock, 1 tsp soy, 1 tbsp. sesame oil, 1tbsp corn starch, 1 tbsp. water. and a pinch of ginger.  cook until thickened and pour over noodles .  I added steamed veggies and added to noodles.

text:
I had five boneless, skinless thighs, but kept the sauce amount as stated. I used half brown sugar and half white. Using an 8x8 foil lined pan, I put most of the sauce over thighs, reserving some. Baked at 400degF for 20 min, then put reserved sauce over them and baked another 15 min. They came out so moist, and the sauce was excellent. May try the sauce with salmon, cooking at reduced temp for shorter amount of time, as another reviewer mentioned. Thanks for the recipe!

My husband loves this dish!  I use chicken thighs that I have skinned and removed the fat from.  I make the sauce exactly as listed EXCEPT I add a teaspoon of red pepper flakes. I bake at 425 degrees for 30 minutes and then turn them and bake for another 30 minutes.

text:
I followed JAYZGURL77's suggestion and made this recipe in the slow cooker....made the sauce per the recipe and poured it over the chicken in the slow cooker.  I wasn't ready to eat after 5 hrs. so it cooked for about 6 1/2 hrs on low.  Also I threw in some  fresh vegetables (string beans and broccoli--because they were on hand)  with about an hour to go, and  I only had to prepare some noodles to serve dinner. The chicken was VERY tender, and the sauce had a delightful flavor.   Such a simple meal.  I'll be making it quite often.

text:
I love baked teriyaki chicken and rice. I made this with the sauce, and it was great. However, I  have to say, I am also finding a lot of really delicious bottled teriyaki glazes and baking sauces on the market lately that are just as good and save time. I think boneless chicken thighs not breasts work best and I usually garnish my teriyaki chicken with toasted sesame seeds and chopped green onions. I also usually cook the thighs plain for about 10 mins then drain off fat. I baste with the sauce after that. You get the richer thigh flavor but minus some of the fat.

text:
**side note: for those that feel it's to salty instead of using regular or lite soy sauce you could try Liquid Aminos (I use Bragg Liquid Aminos or Coconut Aminos. Tastes just like soy sauce w/out the salt.  Gluten Free & non-gmo. 

We all loved it! Made the sauce according to the recipe (minus the cornstarch and water. We have to be corn free) Doubled it though.  Used boneless skinless chicken tenders and cut the time in half and lowered the temp to 400. While the chicken was baking, I sautéed red and green bell peppers and onion in a pan with a little butter. Threw some broccoli in the microwave.  Served it all over brown rice. Definitely hit the spot!

text:
I love this recipe! It is one of my family's favorites. I tweaked it a little though. I  substituted the white sugar for brown sugar, I cut up my chicken thighs into 1" pieces. I lined a shallow baking dish with foil, seasoned my chicken lightly, then poured the entire mixture over the chicken and baked for 20 minutes. Spoon over your choice of rice and enjoy the deliciousness. This method cuts down on cooking time.

This was great with the modifications by Valerie's Kitchen. I could even go with a tad less sugar than she used but not quite as low as others recomended. When I reduced the sugar by half, the salty soy sauce was too pronounced. But by using 75% of the sugar, it was great. I might go down to 67% of the recommended sugar instead. We grilled the chicken first to give it a nice flavor and drizzled the sauce over the chicken. The kids loved it with broccoli and brown rice. I plan to bake salmon with the sauce next. Yum!

text:
From reading the reviews, I get all kinds of good ideas.  I've made this recipe several times, as boneless, skinless chicken thighs are so affordable.  I pour half of the sauce over the chicken thighs - to heck with "brushing". I do not cover them. After 30 minutes, I drain the juice from the pan, turn the chicken pieces over and pour the rest of the sauce over them.  Bake another 30 minutes and it is absolutely perfect!  The sauce becomes sticky and totally yummy!

text:
This recipe is really good. The only thing I did differently is I cooked mine in the slow cooker like someone else suggested. I did not change any of the ingredients, though. In the future, I will likely cut down the sugar a little. I found it to be a little too sweet, even though it was tasty. Not the healthiest of recipes but a nice treat.

text:
This is a great tasting recipe. Definitely double the sauce. I mixed all the ingredients except water and cornstarch and marinaded the chicken for a few hours while we were at the pool. When we got home I drained the marinade into a pan and mixed in the cornstarch and water. After it thickened I basted the chicken while it was cooking. We used chicken breast and thighs and only baked for 20 minutes before turning and basting, then another 20 minutes. Big hit with my family. Thanks for posting.

text:
This is a foolproof recipe and is so impressive! I actually don't cook the sauce beforehand I put the sauce and chicken all together in an ovenproof pan or casserole dish and then keep turning it every 10 minutes.. the sauce gets just as nice and thick and gooey. I've used this recipe with breasts also turns out great. Throw some green onions and or sesame seeds on it and serve over rice with broccoli! 

Also i cut the chicken into chunks then mix around in the sauce.

text:
Great recipe for the crockpot, easy to put together before work in the morning. I doubled the sauce ingredients except sugar (used brown and only 1.5x), used light soya sauce and extra cloves of garlic. And a Tbsp of minced ginger.  Put the chicken in and ensured it was coated in sauce,  and put it on low for 10 hours. Turned out I should have used the full amount of sugar, it tasted a bit vinegary, but I added a can of pineapple tidbits with some of the juice but not all, and it was perfect. Served over rice

text:
Whenever I crave teriyaki chicken, I use this recipe.  I agree with other reviewers that if you love sauce, you should double to portion listed in the recipe.  I find that at 425 degrees, my chicken is done in 25 minutes (I use an older gas stove).  You should definitely use a thermometer to check your chicken so it's not overcooked.  The last time I made this, I added mushrooms in the last ten minutes of cooking (that's the way I grew up eating teriyaki chicken) and it was fantastic!

text:
I tried this tonight. I used brown sugar instead of white sugar and used a little less of it. I did the same thing with the low sodium soy sauce. I used this recipe for 6 thighs. Had just enough sauce. Basted them every 10 minutes. The last twenty minutes I did not base them but the last 8 minutes I added a quarter each of red and green bell pepper and a pinch of sesame seed. I cooked some broccoli and carrots and white rice to go with this dish. It came out perfectly! Not too sweet and the thighs were moist. Very good! My husband enjoyed this too! I will make again.

text:
Fantastic sauce! I used it with tofu. I made the sauce and heated it over medium heat until it started to bubble and thicken. I sauteed the tofu slabs in sesame oil until lightly golden while the sauce thickened. Then, I poured the sauce over the tofu and turned the heat down to low to finish cooking while I made some veggies for the side. This was amazing! I did cut the sugar down to about 1/3 of a cup and it was still great! Thanks for sharing!

text:
My family loved this! I added a teaspoon of red pepper flakes and it added just enough of a kick to the sauce! Like one reviewer suggested, I poured half the sauce over the boneless thighs, covered and baked for about 30 mins at 400 degrees. Then I uncovered and baked 30 mins longer, basting every 10 minutes. The sauce thickened up nicely and the chicken was delicious over a bed of steamed jasmine rice. Thanks for sharing, I will definitely make this again!

text:
I made this tonight and doubled the recipe. Used brown sugar instead of white since it's all due to preference. Instead of using thighs, I used chicken tenders. Baked it for 20 minutes then turned on the broiler for 5 minutes to get a nice glaze. The sauce was nice and thick. Not as sweet as I'm use to. The cider vinegar did calm down a bit after you cook it but you could still taste it. I'll make it with rice vinegar instead for more sweetness next time. Otherwise, my son and husband liked it. I thought it was ok as is but when I drizzled sriracha sauce over mine, it was better for me since I like my teriyaki spicy and my family doesn't.

Delicious! Made exactly as the recipe except I used drumsticks instead of thighs (that's what I had on hand).  Everyone thought it was wonderful and I will definately make again.  I cooked at 400, but my oven always runs hot.  I found the cooking time fine, since I removed from oven to brush on more sauce every 10 minutes.  This is not a "toss in the oven and let cook" dish, but well worth the effort of basting every 10 minutes.  Served with fried rice, steaned carrots and green beans.  Yhanks for the great recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! This is a new favorite. What I love the most about this recipe is that it seems very flexible. All I had on hand were two chicken breasts and I cut them up into tidbits to make them go further. I followed the sauce exactly as stated but with low-sodium soy sauce because that is all I had on hand (it was salty enough and I think it might have been too salty if I used regular soy sauce). I lined an 8x8 pan with foil based on another reviewer's suggestion and poured the sauce over. Soon after putting it in the oven I found out my husband would be late so I just turned the oven down low to 300 degrees and let it cook for well over an hour. I stirred it around every now and then. Moist, tender little tidbits of chicken in delicious sauce came out. If I were using the full amount of chicken, I would double sauce because it is so good and I'm not even a big teriyaki fan.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
14255673
Display Name:
Cweaver
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe using a technique I use on beef, chicken, & fish. From a recipe called Cook steak Like a Chef...preheat oven to 450. Combine all the ingredients for the sauce. Set aside.  Rinse and pat  Chicken breast dry. I used 4 breasts. Add spices to chicken if desired. Using an oven proof pan heat over med-high heat. When hot spray with non-stick spray. When the pan starts to slightly smoke add the chicken. Cook for two minutes. After two minutes lift each piece and place back down on the same side. Cook one more minute. After the one minute turn the chicken and immediately put on the lowest rack in the oven. Bake for 8 minutes. After 8 minutes take the pan out of the oven ( use mitts...very HOT!) pour the sauce over the chicken and put back in the oven for two minutes. Remove the pan from the oven and place on the stove. On med-high heat, heat the sauce. And chicken till sauce thickens. Let sit for 5-10 minutes. Serve with rice. Mmmmm.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe. Don't be afraid of high temp and I didn't cover with foil. I had 6 skinless, boneless chicken thighs so  I cooked 15 minutes less.  I made sauce almost excactly, but I subbed orange juice for half of the cider (my kids are very wary of vinegar, so I needed to tone it down with oj, or pineapple juice.   I also ran out of soy sauce, and only had 3/4 the amount called for and used garlic powder because I didn't have garlic.  Instead of brushing sauce on I just poured spoonful of sauce on each side and every 10 minutes I would pour spoonful more on chicken.  After chicken done I sliced it into strips and put it bake in baking tray and mixed it with the glazed sauce then put it on top of steamed rice. It looked just like a terryaki bowl from a restaurant.  My family loved it, even my son who is not very fond of chicken.  You can double sauce and stir fry some broccoli for a yummy healthy meal. Thank you for this recipe!  God bless

I made this recipe and then realized I had no ginger, so  tossed in just 2 dashes of Tabasco.  I have to make this recipe doubled to make enough sauce so that my family, and the assorted girlfriends, "adopted" children and other drop-ins, can have enough to mash into the rice I usually serve with the chicken.  We've even done it on the grill and it was fantastic, just make sure you put the sauce on near the end of cooking so the sugars in the sauce don't burn.  Excellent recipe.

text:
Very very good!! I used brown sugar instead of the white, doubled everything except only used 3/4 cup brown sugar, 3/4 cup soy sauce, and a little less then half a cup vinegar. I also added 1 T honey and poured all the sauce over 3 chicken breasts cut into strips. I baked at 350 for 15 min then turned and basted and cooked an additional 15 min, basted one more time before turning on the broiler for about 5 min. Carmelized really well and tasted amazing! Served with steamed broccoli and brown rice, will be making it into the monthly rotation. Thanks for the recipe!!!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not a huge fan of this sauce.  It's only okay because the sauce has too much vinegar and is only edible after marinading chicken then grilling it.  It doesn't work as a sauce to use afterwards and is much too tart.  As a marinade for grilling, this does work pretty good but not for baking.  Instead, I use a similar sauce made without vinegar or white sugar.  Use 5 tablespoons of brown sugar, one tablespoon honey, 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger, 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/4 cup of cold water and the rest of the ingredients listed.  This turns into a great teriyaki sauce for dipping or drizzle.  Use this one listed as marinade and the other as your dip, drizzle, baking or teriyaki rice bowl.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had high hopes for this simple recipe but I was disappointed. Something seemed missing. The flavor was okay but needed more punch. I added 1/4 tsp. of red pepper flakes (my only tweak) but this didn't do enough. The coating did not stick well to the chicken, either. Most of it pooled in the bottom of the pan so we used it for dipping to eke out more flavor. I don't understand why it slipped off as I dried the chicken well and the coating cooked up nice and thick at the start. 
Also, the baking time is too long. I temped my chicken after 50 minutes and every piece registered at well over 175 F. The coating was beginning to burn by then so I stopped the baking.

BIG thank you to the reviewers who suggested lining the pan with foil first! You saved me lots of scrubbing as the coating tends to stick to the pan(not to the chicken sadly).

text:
I think this definitely needs low sodium soy sauce.  I only had regular and it was a bit salty for me and I love salty!  I didn't double the sauce recipe because I was making only two chicken breasts and it worked out fine, but I would definitely double it if I were cooking more chicken. I browned my chicken first and set it aside.  Then, I made the sauce per the recipe's instructions, but left it a bit thinner and baked the chicken in the sauce using a small covered casserole dish @350 degrees.  I had no issues with the sauce burning or sticking to the dish.  This was yummy served over steamed rice with some fresh green beans.

text:
So easy and authentic.  I fried wings and used the sauce to coat before putting in oven to set.  I made some changes, I added additional water because whenever I make any recipes that has soy sauce, it always tends to be too salty so, I added about a total of 1/4 cup of water, a tablespoon or so at a time to thin it out and make less salty.  Because I added the water and lessened the flavor, I added about 2 tablespoons of honey which really didn't change the flavor that much.  It was really good before adding the honey.  I will make this again and again because the flavor was so good and because it was so easy.

None
text:
I was skeptical at first, but desperate for a new spin on chicken. It was so good!  I ran out of soy sauce (used tamari) so I had to use 1/4 cup soy and then 1/4 cup Bragg's Liquid Aminos (similar to soy sauce). 
I used thighs and one breast cut into thirds so the pieces were roughly the same size as the boneless thighs. I dumped the sauce over the chicken in a sprayed Pyrex, turned it to coat both sides, covered it with foil,and then baked it at 325 for an hour and twenty minutes- removing the foil after about 50 minutes. It was really really good and flavorful. I'd love to try it on beef and salmon. Thanks, Marian!

Simply Deelish.!!!!  Unlike others who altered this highly ranked recipe I did NOT.  I followed the instructions exactly as listed and the result was out of this world. It is def not too salty or sweet, simply put its perfect as is.  I did make extra sauce though, and simply doubled the ingredients.  It turned out great.  My wife, and two fussy daughters had seconds and said it was excellent.  I will def add this to may favorite meals list.  Easy to prepare and clean up, as I lined the baking dish with foil first.  Would not change the 425F temp as it helped crisp up the chicken tighs at the end....they were tender inside and fell apart when served.  A++++.

My first time writing a review for any recipe.  This was great! I couldn't believe that my home-made teriyaki sauce tasted better than most of the bottled sauces out there.  My picky eater daughter kept talking about how good it was even the next day and my 21 month son keeps saying yummy. My husband was amazed. I took the advice of others and tripled the sauce and other ingredients because I was cooking more chicken. I lowered the heat to 375 degrees and cooked each side for about 45 minutes. I didn't have to baste much because the chicken was fully marinated and swimming in the sauce. Thanks for this wonderful recipe. I'll substitute the sugar with honey next time to see how that turns out. Will let you all know.

text:
This sauce is amazing: dark, rich, and smoky. I followed the other reviewers by reducing the sugar 'cause I'm not fond of overly sweet meat sauces. Because I doubled the recipe, instead of using a full cup of white sugar I used 1/2 cup white and 1/4 cup brown (also recommended by a reviewer). I would have preferred to give this recipe 4.5 stars, only because the meat came out swimming in sauce, so it was wetter on our plates than it looks in the photo. But nevertheless, this recipe is very, very good, and it's the only sauce I would ever use to make teriyaki.

text:
Made this for dinner, and added extra garlic as suggested by one reviewer. I used the same amount of ingredients but for only 6 chicken thighs. Tasted the sauce after heating and thought it was too "vinegary," so I added 1/4 cup of agave nectar (just to finish up the bottle of nectar in my fridge ). I followed another reviewer's suggestion and foiled the baking dish before baking at 400F. After 30 mins. I removed the foil, added more teriyaki sauce and baked for another 30 minutes. The chicken thighs were wonderfully tender and tasty! I served the chicken over rice and stir fry veggies. I used a reserve amount of sauce (about 1/4 cup) for my  veggies, and it made them even tastier! Will definitely make this again!

text:
Best chicken I have had in a long time. This sauce is the best homemade Teriyaki! 

I made the sauce as directed except I cut back the sugar by 1/8 cup). I cooked 6 skinless bone-in thighs. I lined my dish with non-stick foil, covered for 30 minutes at 375 degrees then uncovered til done (about 45 minutes total). I served with rice and sauteed zuchinni with onion). My very picky husband said I could make this dish anytime.  I told him I would like to try the sauce with baked Salmon and he was on onbard with that. Will make again routinely. Thank you!

userID:
2007528
Display Name:
Goldana
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/32932.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for dinner and it was so delicious that I had to come here right away and write a review!
Previously I had a go-to recipe of balsamic glazed chicken that was somewhat similar to this recipe, but this one definitely trumps my old one! Sorry, balsamic glazed chicken, you are being replaced!
Everyone in my family loved it. I didn't have cornstarch at home, therefore I thickened the sauce by first making a roux. It worked great and didn't alter the taste at all.
I used large skinless boneless chicken breasts in place of the thighs, because I enjoy that cut of meat better.
The only other very small alteration that I made was to the ginger. No one in my family likes ginger, therefore I substituted a small amount of ground cloves and nutmeg instead. Ohhh, it was yummy! I highly recommend trying this to anyone who is not a ginger lover. Simply add SMALL pinches of each spice, until you have reached your desired taste. Remember, you can always add more, but you can't take it back if it is too much!
This recipe is truly superb and much easier to make than my old one (which required you to stand at the stove constantly stirring). I threw the breasts into a casserole dish, topped with the sauce on both sides, and let it bake. I only had to open the oven a few times to turn the meat.
I served it with white rice and a broccoli/cauliflower mix. Thank you Ms. Collins for this wonderful recipe which will be going into my favorite recipe box to be used over and over again!

text:
This recipe is wonderful! The sauce is delicious and my chicken came out very moist and flavorful. I actually added about 1-1.5 extra tablespoons of sugar to the recipe (I was using regular soy sauce, so it helped cut down on some of the saltiness). I covered the chicken with foil and didn't baste every 10 minutes. I just set the oven on 375F, poured the sauce on, cooked for 30 minutes, flipped, basted and cooked for 20 more minutes. I took the foil off and cooked for 5 more minutes. Wonderful!

text:
TRY THIS IN THE CROCKPOT! I doubled the sauce recipe, then added another two tbsp. of corn starch. I whisked the sauce ingredients and poured into my crockpot, placed two chicken breasts in and turned on LOW for 3 hours. The last hour I turned it up to HIGH to get the sauce to boil and thicken. IT WAS DELICIOUS over white sticky rice. My husband said this tasted better than any other teriyaki sauce he has had. He told me never to buy marinade again.

text:
easy recipe to make! I double the sauce and make it with just 6 thighs. Leaves plenty of sauce to pour over white rice with the meal. Made it several times, everyone loves it. Didn't have meat left over and someone still wanted to take home the left over sauce just to eat with rice. I do marinate it, I make the sauce in the morning before i leave for work and throw it in a ziplock bag with the meat in the fridge. Then I come home and dump the bag into a dish to bake it in turning them over every 10-12 minutes while I make the veggies & rice. Just a wonderful recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is OK as is, but I followed my mom and really modified the recipe.  First of all, you must double the sauce - there's no other way around it.  And no veggies?  Really?  I had never heard of teriyaki chicken without veggies, not to mention pineapple.  So we add sliced carrots (or baby carrots), sliced mushrooms, chunks of sweet onion, and a can of pineapple tidbits.  I reserved the juice and added to the sauce.  The best part?  Letting the chicken marinate in the sauce overnight.  That makes a HUGE difference.  And you will need to cook it longer depending upon the type of chicken you use.  I had to look for 90 minutes using bone-in, skinless thighs.  Next time I will use half boneless, skinless breasts and half thighs.

text:
More than loved this recipe!!! I would definitely double the sauce especially if you want some for dipping purposes. I almost use boneless skinless breasts, but instead I chose to stick true to the recipe and I am SO GLAD I did! My boyfriend LOVES this chicken. The sauce is so easy too that you could use it for other recipes that call for teriyaki sauce. One thing I do feel like I have to complain about is that it ruined my baking pan somehow. The sauce got burnt to it pretty badly. I would use a glass dish or cover your pan with foil. Other than that it was the absolute BEST teriyaki chicken I have tasted. Thank you for sharing!

text:
This was excellent. I seldom make a meal that all 4 of my kids like -- let alone fight over what's left! (Note to self: make more than one package of thighs next time!) Per other reviewers, I doubled the sauce, tho I had extra left over so I don't know if it's necessary. It also made for a messy cleanup so next time I will line the pan. But easy and delicious!

UPDATE: I have made this recipe many times and have determined that using foil doesn't give the same caramelizing that a glass pan does. The recipe is 10x better when not using foil. Unfortunately, the clean-up is 50x worse!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
6974221
Display Name:
ConkyJoe
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/703426.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good flavor, and chicken was very moist. Doubled the sauce as suggested by several reviewers. Baked at 375° F for 45 minutes. I wanted a ‘sticky’ sauce that clings to the chicken but it wasn’t as thick as desired in spite of basting several times. Prior to making this recipe, the suggestions to foil the top of dish for about half the baking time seemed like a good idea for retaining moisture (more important for those using chicken breasts, and a lesser issue for those using thighs). The undesirable consequence is that the sauce doesn’t get as sticky thick when the moisture is trapped by covering the dish. The wide range of appearances in the 124 photos as of this date reflect the many different times, temps, foil/no foil, oven bake vs. grill, and other cooking variations being employed. Next time, I’ll use a roast 'n broil pan w/ rack so that the chicken doesn't sit in the drippings . . . or cook in a Big Green Egg. With trial and error adjustments, this recipe has the potential to be 5*.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe appealed to me as soon as I read it.  I appreciate the other reviews which mentioned the excess saltiness so I was able to cut down the amount of soy sauce, not having any of the low sodium variety. I also cut down on the amount of sugar. I also had some boneless thighs to use up and used some boneless breast meat to use as well, so I was glad of the guidance from the others suggesting the reduced times and reduced temperature.  I added the thighs first and gave them 10 minutes more than the cut up breast meat and basted all at the 10, 20 and 30 minute mark with just another 5 minutes to coat all before serving over rice.  I normally salt my rice but in this case let it cook without based on other reviews mentioning the saltiness.  It did the trick.  Thanks, Allrecipes and readers who offered their reviews.  :-) I have enough left over for another meal for the two of us and will definitely use this recipe again.

text:
My family loves it. I use a package of boneless skinless chicken thighs that usually has 12 thighs. I double the marinade. Only cuz I'm lazy, I dump a bunch of marinade on the chicken in a bowl, stir it around, then arrange on a broiler pan. Then every 15 minutes baste and flip til you hit the 1 hour mark. I serve with rice and sauteed teriyaki greenbeans. I did run out of minced garlic one time and substituted with garlic powder. Worked very well too.

text:
I gave this recipe 3 stars because it has potential.  I found it to be way too sweet and so did my husband! 
1.) I doubled the sauce (next time I will NOT double the sugar & might even half) also, had to add extra water/cornstarch mixture to get the thickness I like.
2.) Poured all of mixture over chicken thighs and it covered them all perfectly
3.) Lastly, I cooked on 375 for 25 minutes.  DO NOT cook at 425 for an hour!!  Your chicken will be totally dry.    So, I will try this recipe again but will use the changes that I stated above.  Think it will be much better next time.  Oh, and brown rice takes longer but the flavor of the rice is way better with this dish (and most) over white rice.  Plus, it's healthier!

This came out fantastic after a few changes based on other reviews. I used 4 boneless skinless breasts cut in half. Line the baking dish with foil for easy cleanup. Definitely double the sauce! I don't think it would have been enough sauce if I didn't double it. Used 3/4 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white. Baked at 375 for 25 minutes, flipping once and dumping more sauce on the chicken. This recipe is amazing! Here's what I did differently. Instead of bone in thighs, I used boneless. Switched out the soy for low sodium, and instead of cider vinegar I used a red  wine vinegar. userID:
7945137
Display Name:
Canadiangirl
isPro:

1

7

104

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe 4 times now.  The only thing I omit is the ginger and I do double the sauce recipe.  Quick trick, don't cook the sauce in a pot, make your sauce and pour over chicken arranged in the pan, about an hour before cooking.  I put my thighs skin side up until ready to turn on the oven (maximum 390f).  When I turn on my oven I turn the chicken skin side down for half hour of cooking time, then flip to skin side up for last half hour.  That way the tops get a nice glaze to them and the meat absorbs the flavor.  The house smells amazing and the chicken looks professional.  We love this recipe and use it on pork, chicken and meat balls to be served with rice.  Yummy thank you! 
Clean up is easy as this is a sugar based recipe, occassionally I will line my pan with parchment paper but it's not really needed. Tin foil rips off when serving because the sugar is sticky and glazed, and ultimately makes a bigger mess.  Soapy hot water cleanup is all you need.

None
country:
None
text:
This was good. I used BLSL and more or less immersed them in sauce. I uncovered and only basted them the last 15 minutes so as not to get my brush unsanitary. I do think the key to this recipe is to simmer the sauce so it gets nice and thick, because the chicken will water it down so you want it nice and thick going on. If we liked chicken with skin on it, that would be better too because the sauce will stick better to skin. I served this with plain brown rice and some peppers/onions/pineapple that I stir-fried. Thanks for sharing!  NOTE: I used 3 BLSL breast halves with this amount of sauce.

country:
None
text:
The sauce-absolutely WONDERFUL. My family has asked for me just to make the sauce in bulk to give to them. 
The reason I gave the recipe 3 stars, it doesn't say to cover the chicken before placing it in the oven. It makes a huge difference. Cover it with aluminum foil or wax paper, and pour most of the sauce in with the chicken and then cook it.
If you try to bake it uncovered and just brush it lightly with the sauce, it is extremely dry. 
COVER  BEFORE YOU BAKE IT!!!!!!
Other than thatm its great!

text:
This was pretty good. I made changes due to what was in the house and hubby really liked it. I thought it was good but I didn't think it tasted like true teriyaki sauce. I doubled the ingredients and used brown sugar instead of regular sugar and chicken breasts and tenderloins instead of thighs. I halved the ginger per my personal preference. I made the sauce and then marinated the chicken in it for 3 hours. Finally, I covered the pyrex with foil and cooked at 400 for 30 minutes. I'll make it again.

text:
Absolutely wonderful.  I followed some others suggestion and doubled the sauce, used lower sodium soy sauce and used half brown and half white sugar.  I dumped all the sauce over the chicken at the start and baked 110 min. at 375.  I covered with foil the first half, then removed it. I did turn them half way through and basted the tops about 5 minutes before they were done. I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs cut in half because I wanted smaller pieces and I had also put a couple of chicken breast tenderloins in to see what tasted better.  The thighs win hands down.  

My son ate his over rice and I made a stirfry of red and green bell peppers, celery and cabbage which I put the chicken over.  It was great!  Can't wait for the leftovers!

text:
Delicious sauce but DOUBLE it! The stated amount is good for about a pound of chicken. Would be GREAT w/ wings!! I made w/chick breast b/c thats what I had on hand. Used 1 tsp grated ginger and increased the garlic. Used brown sugar instead of white, decreasing it just a tad but not much. #Keeper. UPDATE 8/3/12 I made these with wings yesterday and they were AWESOME!! My 10 yr old son is obsessed w/Zaxby teriyaki wings and this is the first time I came close to their high rating lol. I baked them at 400. Doubled sauce and poured half over wings before baking, then basted every 10 min roughly until wings were done and sauce was gone. Finger licking good!

When I made this recipe I doubled it and made the following substitutions: used 1/2 cup Kikkoman Soy Sauce, 1/2 cup Kikkoman Teriyaki Marinade & Sauce (because I didn't have enough Soy Sauce), 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar. Before I even got it onto the chicken I was sampling it and thought it was amazing. Based on my experience with this recipe, I think it would take great even if you didn't make any changes. Definitely a recipe worth trying.

The sauce from this recipe tastes just like a local teriyaki place. We added a little bit of red chili flakes to spice it up, and I needed a bit of extra cornstarch to get the consistency I wanted. Otherwise, used this as is... cut the soy sauce with water to dull down the salt a bit, and used white vinegar instead of cider because we didn't have any. Will be making again & trying on the BBQ at some point. :D

userID:
5825413
Display Name:
Foodie25
isPro:

followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0

30
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2411077.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used to make this one regularly, until my family got tired of it. I did 1/4 brown sugar and 1/4 white sugar, used 1/2 lite soy sauce to reduce saltiness, subbed potato or tapioca starch for the corn starch, put it on 350 degrees. For step 3, I don't brush it on - I just pour the sauce over because I don't have a brush, and don't want additional cleanup. I listened to reviews and doubled the sauce so that it can be paired over rice. I also baked it covered with aluminum foil to retain moisture because without the foil, I think it'd be pretty dry and nasty.  Not my cup of tea but my friend's kids liked it. I give it 3 stars because of all the alterations made, and that it's something you can easily get tired of if you make it regularly, despite all that sugar.

HAILBUZZY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great homemade teriyaki!  The family gobbled it up served with brown rice & pan fried asparagus.  Unlike other posters I found there to be exactly enough sauce without having to double the recipe or anything like that.  I basted every 15 minutes.  However, a word of caution, do not leave in the oven for much longer than instructed!  I turned the oven off and left it to caramelize slightly as there was literally no caramalization... just a nice thick sauce.  No more than 7 minutes later, the sauce had separated and sugars had burned.  Chicken itself was still excellent but next time I'll leave it be, or drain off the sauce before trying to caramelize!

text:
5+++++++++++ stars!!!!!!!!!!!!! My husband loves good Teriyaki so I decided to try this recipe! I was skeptical at first because when I started cooking the sauce it smelled like it would have too much of a vinegar flavor.. but after it was cooked all of the flavors evened out perfectly to make the best Teriyaki sauce I have ever had! My husband raved about it All night saying it was the best he ever had, and even said it could be at a fancy stake house! 
I did a couple changes to it... I put 1/4 brown sugar and 1/4 white, and I left out the ginger because I didn't have any. Also I used boneless skinless breasts and cut them up small so the flavor would get all around! I will be making again, thank you Marian for sharing! :)

text:
This is a number one favorite at our house! So juice, tender, and delicious. The only thing I do different, and boy does it make a difference, if make a double batch and I marinade my chicken in a tightly closed zip lock pack (flipping over periodically) for 2 full days. Then I cook it exactly as the recipe calls for. I have tried this recipe with and without marinading the meat and I have to say that when it is marinated, it is 10 times better! Thank you so much for this recipe! We love it with steamed broccoli and carrots with a little sauce added after the steaming process and some homemade fried rice. Delicious!

text:
I was excited to try this recipe after seeing so many great reviews on it.  As I was simmering the marinade, the vinegar was SO pungent, I started to hesitate, but it came out GREAT!  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs and cooked 20 min, then flipped sides, and cooked another total of 25 minutes. I don't think it needed that, but I flipped it often to try and get a good caramelization on the chicken.  There was too much marinade for what I made, but it came out DELICIOUS!  My kids LOVED it.  I also did what others did, used lite soy sauce, and also microplaned ginger, since I didn't have ground ginger.

text:
This is the first time that I had cooked teriyaki chicken using a recipe card(I usually use just bottled teriyaki sauce) and I had to say this is the best teriyaki chicken I ever had.When I started preparing it I allowed chicken to marinate in sauce for a few hours(8am-2pm). I did a minimal change to the recipe, in that I only used half of the soy sauce the recipe card called for and replaced the other half with teriyaki sauce. I cooked chicken at 425 degrees uncovered and loved the color of chicken after it was done cooking. I did not see a need to baste chicken every ten minutes, but I allowed chicken to cooked 30 minutes on each side. Instead of whole chicken I used chicken wings. I really enjoyed this recipe and I am looking forward to cooking it in the near future!!!

I really liked this recipe.  As a southern gal who frequents Houston often, I can be picky with my mexican food. I used about 3 cups of beef broth rather than the beef bouillon and because I needed more liquid so as to eat like a soup.  Lastly, I cut the cream cheese in half because DH is not a fan.  Turned out delicious!  Cant wait to cook again!

Well, this is my first attempt at writing a review, so here goes:  I thought this sauce had excellent flavor and was a beautiful color.  We are "sauce" people, so since I was using boneless, skinless chicken breasts (5) instead of thighs, I thought I should make extra.  I tripled the sauce mix and was GLAD I did! When I try this again (which will probably be awhile since there are a million other receipes), I will definitely make even more sauce.  This was excellent with rice and stirfried veggies. text:
This sauce is AWESOME!  This is my first time making this and the chicken is in the oven as I type.  The sauce is better than any bottled teriyaki sauce. It's thick, bubbly, glossy and delicious.  I doubled the sauce but used 1 heaping tablespoon of ginger because it gives it a nice kick.  I can't wait to taste the chicken and then I'll be back to write a second review.  Btw, we used chicken thighs and drummets.  Next time, I'll try chicken breasts. I'm also definitely going to try this on Salmon, then put the salmon over an Asian salad (recipe on here also).

country:
None
text:
Really yummy.  I changed it a tiny bit, but I suspect it would have been delicious originally anyway.  All I did was use half white sugar and half brown sugar, and I almost reduced the soy sauce to half (I doubled the recipe and used a little less than 3/4 of a cup).  Yes, it's essential to double the recipe.  I used 3 chicken breasts (sliced in half to make 6 servings), and I grilled them and put the sauce on them 3 times.  There was a tiny bit left over, but my husband thought it could have used a little more sauce still.  And that was doubled.  I have no idea how this could be enough for 12 thighs!  Oh, and it is NOT too salty with regular soy sauce.  I think if you used lite soy, you'd have to add some salt to it to get the true teriyaki flavor.

None
text:
WOW! This was pretty darn good! My boyfriend and I LOVE the sauce! The only thing is, as others have said, 425 degrees is much too high- You can turn down the heat to 400 or even 375 degrees and it will come out great. The sauce burned badly (no surprise, as it contains sugar) and it took me ages to get the black mess off my pan. Definitely line your pan with foil just in case! I've used this sauce with chicken drumsticks and wings as well and we're always licking our fingers afterwards. I like to place the sauce and chicken in a ziploc bag and let it marinate for at least a couple hours. Yumm-y!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2336882.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous recipe!!!  I loved the teriyaki sauce recipe, but I prepared my meal on the stove top.  I made half the volume of sauce and poured it over ~1 lb of chicken breast that was cut into bite-sized pieces.  I let this marinade overnight in the fridge.  The next day, I poured off the marinade and cooked the chicken in a non-stick pan (no oil added).  The chicken was very tasty but a bit tough when prepared this way.  Just for fun, I made another half-volume of the sauce and poured it into the pan after the chicken had cooked through, then thickened it with a bit of cornstarch and water.  WARNING:  When cooked this way, the sauce is a bit intense.  Next time I'll leave the sauce off, try reducing the amount of vinegar, or I'll actually bake the chicken as directed by this recipe. :)

text:
Proof that good teriyaki can also be easy! I used 5 thighs with 1/4 cup brown sugar instead of white (some may want more if they like it sweeter), low-sodium soy sauce. Cooked at 375 for 30 minutes, then lowered to 325 for 30 minutes. Basted twice every 15 minutes for the first half hour, then just poured on the rest and let it ride. I'll use bonless skinless breasts next time since the thighs were a bit oily for my taste, but the sauce is a keeper! Thanks!

text:
This was the easiest and most amazing chicken dish. I was gloating the whole time that I made this sauce from scratch. I normally buy the teriyaki sauce, but not this time! I had people over and I tried this dish as soon as I received the email from allrecipes. It tasted like restaurant quality. My picky children loved the taste. The guests loved them and of course my husband did too. My family ate them the next day too and my daughter took a dish to her friend's house. I didn't change anything in the recipe or I would be rating my own! I only added a bit more of each ingredient as I did the whole leg cut up into two pieces each. That made 24 pieces. I didn't double the sauce, just a few tbsps more. I didn't find ginger powder so I used ginger paste, but past experience taught me to just put a tiny bit. So I used just as much as a pea size for the whole thing which didn't do much. I am telling you, try it and you will NOT regret it. My kids asked for it again for next weekend!

Display Name:
Carolyn Caraloopy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1334713.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any cornstarch....so...I skipped it and the water. Into a 1/4 cup measuring cup I put 1 tbsp. brown sugar, 1 tbsp. white sugar, about 1.5 tbsp. molasses, and filled the cup the rest of the way with honey. Used 1/4 cup soy sauce, 1/4 cup plain vinegar, extra garlic and fresh minced ginger root. These amounts made more than enough to coat 2 leg/thigh combos. Without the cornstarch it was a little slow to thicken; I ended up adding in a little flour and heating the sauce over a slightly higher temp in order to get it going but once it did it thickened nicely. I did end up adding another tablespoon of soy while it was thickening because it was a smidge too sweet but the end result was great. I will definitely make this again. Absolutely delicious.

Wonderful flavor hot and made a terrific salad when cold. I did use half brown sugar, half white. Also added about 2 tsps sesame oil.   As to the foil, I seldom use it to line pans. If you lightly grease your pan with shortening (Crisco) or butter, there's really NOT much of a clean up. Just fill the pan with water right away and let sit a little while. Cleans off easily.

Everyone loved it! From my picky four year old to their grandma. My six year old said "You have to make this again. "the best" from 4yr old. It was an easy recipe to make. I made it for a larger group using thighs, wings, and drumsticks. I used a spoon to add the sauce to the meat then flipped them over. At 1st I thought I would need to season the meat prior to adding the sauce as I have done with pre-packaged marinades, but it was really flavorful. I made rice and green beans as a side dish. This is the best teriyaki I've ever had and I will be making it again and again. I can't wait til summer to try it on the grill. Thanks Marian!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, will probably cook again, followed the recipe practically to the letter. Changes I will make in the future though, will probably go about half and half white and brown sugar, and 10-15 less minutes in the oven, was just a touch dry for my taste.  I also used skinless breasts instead of thighs, and 2 tablespoons of flour instead of cornstarch. The flour may have been responsible for the glaze on the bottom side of the chicken becoming runny, if you still choose to substitute flour for corn starch, I would recommend 3 tablespoons.

region:

country:

text:
Tasty! We used whole chicken legs (both thighs and leg portions) and doubled the sauce. Instead of using the whole amount of soy sauce, we substituted half for "Mama Sita's" bbq marinade. I used another reviewer's method cooking; lined my glass baking pan with aluminum foil and poured the sauce over the chicken pieces. Covered and baked for about half an hour; uncovered and added the rest of the sauce then baked another half an hour. It might seem like alot of sauce at the end of cooking, but you'll want to slather your vegetables and rice with it! This would be great on salmon too, and maybe a bit of whiskey thrown in to kick it up a notch.

The recipe was exactly the "base" I was looking for.  My previous and favorite teriyaki sauces have had citrus in them.  My family thinks I took this over the top by my addition.  I did double the recipe as other cooks did, except as another cook, instead of doubling on the white sugar did half in brown sugar; as many other cooks, I recommend the "light" soy sauce 2 1/2 tbls (or if not doubling 1 1/4 tbls) cornstarch and added the zezt and hand squeezed juice of one small orange. Yum, yum, yum.

text:
This is really good.  Many have issues with the amount of salt or sugar...here's how you fix both problems. Don't bother with only making a single serving of sauce unless it's for only one or two people. Double the sauce with the amounts specified above, and here's the kicker...add one cup of water for each batch ( 2 cups if you double it ). It will still thicken up just fine.  Don't bother with the 1 tbsp. of water...just make it a cup. It will even everything out, without making it bland...I got rave reviews.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight and it was FANTASTIC!  Made a bit of changes. Instead of cider vinegar I used 1/2 cup sake 1/4 cup mirin  Used 3 heaped tablespoons of brown sugar instead of white sugar.  Also, I grated about a tablespoon worth of ginger and only used the juice I squeezed out of it.  I layed out the chicken on a baking dish and coated everything with the sauce. Then I covered the dish with foil and put it in a pre heated oven for 30 mins. After 30 minutes, i took out the dish, removed the foil, turned over all the pieces of chicken and poured in the remaining sauce. I baked the chicken uncovered for another half hour.  It turned out so well! Initially i thought the teriyaki sauce was WAYY to salty but it somehow turned out just right. The chicken was so moist and tender. Definitely a keeper! =)

text:
When we moved from Washington state to North Carolina we thought we would never have good chicken teriyaki again in our lives.  I have tried bottled sauces and none of them even come close to the little teriyaki joints that are all over the Puget Sound area.  I am quite pleased to say that this was EXACTLY what we have been missing.  Give it a try, it's a great recipe.  

*Makes a great sauce for teriyaki burgers too.  I make mine half beef, half pork, top with sauce, grilled pineapple, and swiss cheese on a Hawaiian sweet roll bun.  Yum!*

Super delicious! Used skinless, bone-in thighs. I followed the ingredients, but eye-balled everything as I usually do. I did add more garlic than called for. Also, following another suggestion, I marinated the chicken pieces in the sauce for a while in the fridge - about an hour or so (good tip!). Baked at 375 for 40 minutes. Sprinkled with toasted sesame seeds, and served with basmati rice, broccoli and carrots. Yummmmyyyy!!!

text:
Definitely adding this to the weekly repetoire.  I made the recipe as is only with 4 bone in chicken thighs for my little family of 3.  I wish i had more chicken because everyone was asking for 2nds (including my 6 year old) and leftovers would have been nice.  Perfect amount of sauce for the 4 pieces. We drizzled it over brown rice.  When i make it again with more chicken i may double the recipe just to have more sauce.  DEFINITELY use foil on your dish for easy cleanup.  Also my thighs were on the small side and i don't think they took the full hour to cook.

text:
Yummy.  Very, very salty - but we all went back for seconds anyway.  While I'll use a lower-sodium soy next time I make this, the high salt content didn't seem to deter anyone from eating every bite of this.  I doubled the sauce and reduced the sugar a bit, using 2/3 of a cup instead of a full cup.  1/3cup brown sugar, 1/3 cup white sugar.  Used 8 chicken thighs, that I de-boned and removed the skin from before cooking.  I covered my chicken with foil for 30 minutes while cooking, then baked uncovered for another 15 minutes.  Served on top of Fried Rice and Soy-glazed mushrooms.  Delicious, take-out quality meal.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Teriyaki sauce is a simple sauce; a balancing act of salty (soy sauce), sweet (sugar), sour (vinegar) and consistency (cornstarch), and the key to this recipe is to find own balance. With a little trial and error you will be a funambulist (not sure if that's a word...) in no time. I doubled the sauce but with two tsp of ginger, 1 1/2 cup of sugar, 1/2 cup cider and 1/2 cup rice wine vinegar, and used low-sodium soy sauce. cooked half the time for each side since I was making breasts (breasts cook faster than thighs). Thank you Marian for the wonderful recipe.

Display Name:
Chris686

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stuff is AWESOME!  Great on baked chicken.  I like to add a little more cornstarch to make the sauce thicker, but that's it.    As for the chicken, I've added the sauce two different ways.  The first time I simply poured all the sauce on top.  It came out great.  The second time I followed the directions here and turned the chicken over multiple times, hitting it with the brush.  My conclusion?  It actually came out better pouring the sauce on top of the chicken.  The sauce seems to permeate the entire breast/thigh this way.  I didn't get as good of a taste turning it over constantly and brushing it, and it took much less effort.    Note:  I still turned the chicken over at regular intervals.  After experimentation, I'm thinking I may try dipping the entire breast or thigh in the sauce and then baking it, maybe dipping it in the sauce once more in the middle and putting a little bit of sauce on the bottom of the pan.  When I baked it IN the sauce, it had a nice brown color on top where the sauce caramelized a bit (Due to the sugar I guess).  Dipping the whole breast or thigh in the sauce will probably have this result on the entire piece, resulting in a very nice looking and great tasting piece of chicken.

text:
I really liked the recipe and i also turned it into a freezer meal. i mixed all the ingredients in a large ziplock bag and then added the chicken. I removed all the air in the bag and put it in the freezer. on the day i wanted to cook it, i just  thawed it completely and added a little extra (3T or so because you loose some moisture when you freeze) liquid and baked it as directed in the sauce. it was great. Thank you for submitting this recipe :)

Rating:

userID:
912585
Display Name:
BUZZY1966
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for my daughter's school pot luck day.  I decided to make chicken wings out of the recipe and used my crock pot to bake them.  Here is what I did: 1. First I doubled the sauce recipe and used a 3-lb bag of frozen chicken wings. 2.In crock pot combine all ingredients except chicken wings and stir to combine.   Add in frozen chicken wings. Cook in crock pot on low for 6-8 hours 3.Turn oven to low Broil. 4.Line cookie sheet with foil and coat with non-stick cooking spray. Take chicken wings out of crock pot and lay them on the cookie sheet 5.Put the cookie sheet in the oven under the boiler for 5 minutes.   Take the cookie sheet out and turn the wings over and return to oven and broil another 5 minutes. (I sometimes take cookies sheet out again, turn wings over and broil another 3 minutes on the first side.) Take wings out of the oven. 5.While the wings are cooking, pour the remaining sauce from the crock pot into a saucepan, over low heat, add additional cornstarch and use a whisk to stir the sauce until it is a nice thick consistency. 6.At this point you can either just put the wings on a serving plate and brush on some of the thickened sauce and serve and put the wings back in the crock pot and brush on the thickened sauce and put the crockpot on warm.

As another suggested, this sauce would be great with beef.

text:
Edit >>>  I am a huge fan of this recipe and I make it often but I have to add some detail - I usually make this with half tamari and half soy and it is 5 stars this way.  I made it recently with all soy (low sodium) and found it to be a bit too salty.  If I am out of tamari again, I will reduce the soy for sure.  >>> Original review: 5 stars: This is my first ever review, but I had to comment on this recipe.  My daughter absolutely adored this chicken.  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs, and cut them horizontally into about 3 pieces, removing any visible fat.  Placed in a shallow baking pan and covered with sauce.  Baked at 375 for about 30 minutes, turning once after 15 minutes.  I had about 9-10 thighs and did not double the sauce; there was plenty.  After the chicken was done, I drained off most of the sauce and thickened it on the stove with 1 T cornstarch to serve on the side.  This recipe is similar to chicken teriyaki we get at our local mall, but much much better.  I used half regular soy and half tamari and it was perfect.  Served with vegetable fried rice that had lots of good veggies and extra water chestnuts for crunch, and I think this may be my daughter's new favorite meal.  Thanks so much for posting this - I will be making it often.  So easy and sooooo good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this 2 times now, and both times there have been no leftovers.   I line a casserole dish with foil, put the chicken in, then i brush the sauce on both sides of the chicken. I'll re-brush with sauce every 10-15 minutes or so, but i reserve a good chunk of sauce for after the chicken is cooked.   When the chicken is done, i chopped the breasts into bite sized pieces, then add the remaining sauce and mix it all so the chicken pieces are evenly coated.   I serve over white rice.   *I use grated fresh ginger *I use chicken breasts *I double the sauce recipe  I almost recommend making a HUGE batch of the sauce, then bottling it and keep in your fridge. It's quite tasty!!

text:
Wow, this was great!  I used boneless skinless breasts rather than thighs.  Made the recipe's amount of sauce for 6 pieces.  I followed one reviewer's advice to just dump the sauce on and bake, and next time I'll baste it, as the juices thinned the sauce out.  I ended up broiling these for about 8 minutes, turning halfway thru, to thicken the sauce.  Served with rice and steamed veggies.  Will definitely make this one again.

text:
What an awesome recipe!  It was so easy and had WONDERFUL flavor!  I made some little changes to mine. I cut the chicken in long strips, melted a little butter in the pan, then brushed the strips with browning/seasoning sauce as they browned.  I replaced the cider vinegar with balsamic vinegar. I added the remaining chicken juice, butter and browning sauce from the fry pan to the teryaki sauce and let it all thicken together before pouring over chicken to bake.  I only baked the chicken for 1/2 hour, since it was somewhat cooked already. The chicken came out moist and delicious and the sauce was perfect! We ate it over brown rice served with broccoli. My husband kept raving about it!  I can't wait to have this again!

text:
This sauce was amazing. I used it a little differently then explained in the recipe. I cut up boneless, skinless chicken breasts into bite sized pieces and cooked them in Pam on the stovetop. While the chicken was cooking I made the sauce just as described. Once the chicken was done cooking I poured the sauce over the chicken and let it simmer for about 5 minutes. I served it over white rice. It smelled so good and my boyfriend LOVED it! He said it tasted just like something you would order at a restaurant. I will definately be making this again!

text:
I took other reviewers' suggestions and substituted brown sugar for white sugar, and doubled the sauce.  I made thighs, because my husband and I love dark meat.  I just dumped all the sauce over the meat, and cooked it covered for 30 minutes, then flipped the pieces over and cooked it uncooked for another 20ish minutes.  Served it over rice.  The meat was SO TENDER!  YUMMM!  My husband thought the flavor was a bit odd, and I'm not sure if it was the ginger or cider vinegar or brown sugar, but I loved it!  I also just used some of the leftover sauce:  I pan-fried some onions, mushrooms, and yellow squash (I didn't have any zucchini, or I would have added that, too) and then poured the sauce over it and heated it through.  It would have been even better if I had marinated the veggies.  Served it over rice.  It was a delicious vegetarian meal!
