text:
The teriyaki sauce was fantastic.  I followed the instructions for the sauce almost to the letter except I used 3 to 1 brown sugar rather than all white sugar.  I didn't have any thighs so I used chicken breasts instead and they were very moist and juicy (400 for 35 minutes, uncovered).  Like a lot of others I just poured the sauce over the top and turned half way through the cooking time.  I think next time I'll follow the suggestion of draining the juice half-way through so that it carmelizes a little bit better.  Lastly, I added in some sliced onions just because I like them.

text:
Oh my gosh!!!  I am not a fan of teriyaki but wanted to get rid of some thighs I had in the freezer.  I couldn't stop eating this. I love this recipe...and I had all the ingredients on hand!

text:
Really good and so simple...that combination always gets a 5 in my book.  My pan juices did get really liquidy as the chicken cooked but I had reserved much of the sauce and was basting every so often so I eventually just moved the chicken to a different pan and continued basting and by that point no more juice was being released from the chicken so the sauce stayed thick and stuck to the chicken.  I used low sodium soy sauce, brown sugar instead of white, and fresh ginger.  And, I used boneless, skinless thighs and cooked at 400 for about 45 min.

Very, very good. Now one of my Wife's favorites. Ordinarily, I highly disapprove of folks rating a recipe with a dozen or more of their own alterations. A recipe should stand on its own merit. In this case, I made an exception. With the cider vinegar (brown) and the soy sauce (brown), I felt it just naturally called for brown sugar. Not that it make a huge difference, but it adds a subtle richness that I prefer.

text:
I really enjoyed this Teriyaki chicken recipe. I did make a few changes: I used boneless/skinless chicken breasts and baked them in a foil lined pan + covered them with foil at 400 for 30 minutes. That was perfect - they were juicy and tender. I used about 1/10 cup of brown sugar and 1/10 cup of white sugar, reduced the soy sauce to cut back on the saltiness and I used balsamic vinegar instead of cider vinegar. It was excellent and very flavorful.

text:
I used only 6 bone in, skin on chicken thighs but made the full amount of sauce, retaining some of it to put on the rice.  I baked mine at 425 like the recipe says, but the chicken was done after 40 minutes so keep an eye on it!  I used normal soy sauce and the glaze seemed super salty to me but I think it was perfect on the chicken.  The chicken turned out wonderfully and the reserved sauce was amazing on the rice (though you only need half a tablespoon or so for a whole serving).  I'm going to try making this again with skinless chicken, and also try with reduced sodium soy sauce.  Thanks for the great recipe!  UPDATE:  I have made this with skinless chicken and it's only half as good.  Kinda watery and nothing spectacular.  Make it with skin-on chicken!  It's the only recipe I buy skin-on chicken for.

text:
SUPER EASY!! This will be my Teriyaki sauce from now on.  This recipe is delicious! I took some of the advise from the reviews and doubled the sauce. I used a heaping teaspoons of corn starch which help make the sauce thicker. I used 1/4 white sugar and 1/2 brown sugar, also I only had regular soy sauce AND since I doubled the sauce I diluted half with tap water to make a cup and it was not salty and it was still WOW! I used what I had, (10)chicken wings and a couple of chicken breast in freeze that I threw in. I also seasoned my chicken with cayenne, pepper flakes and onion powder and poultry seasoning to my family's taste for extra flavor and kick before baking. My six year old licked the ready sauce off the spoon. I will make again and again. Ps. and yes, use Real Ginger if you can.

text:
Awesome! What a super easy recipe. One of the best chicken recipes I've ever tasted. I doubled the garlic and next time would maybe triple it. I love garlic! I also used half white sugar and half brown to get that nice dark color. I am sure it would be even better with fresh ginger too. I baked it for 30 mins and turned it over and baked for another 25 mins and basted every 15 mins with the sauce. Had a nice carmelization and didn't dry out one bit! I didn't even have to cover the pan with foil, I just stuck it in the oven and it came out great! Served it with white jasmine rice and sauteed green beans. Wonderful..thanks for sharing!!

userID:
2535388
Display Name:
Dee
isPro:

followersCount:
0

8
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/113063.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe for teriyaki sauce.  The amount of sauce in the recipe is actually good for 6 pieces of chicken and extra sauce to use for rice, potatoes etc, so since the recipe calls for 12 pieces, you may want to double the sauce.  I only gave this a 4 because I didn't cook it exactly as directed.  Make sure that you mix the cornstarch with the cold water first before adding it to the saucepan with the rest of the ingredients to ensure that it dissolves nicely. I placed the 6 skinless chicken thighs in the baking dish and poured the sauce over all of it basically smothering the chicken.  I cooked the chicken at 400 degrees, covered w/foil for 30 minutes.  At 30 minutes turned the heat off and let the chicken sit in the oven an additional 5 minutes before removing and placing on the stove to cool. Chicken came out very juicy and tender. Make sure to tranfer the chicken and sauce to a servish dish or other dish so you can clean the baking dish right away.  The sauce will not stick if soaked asap.

text:
This recipe was excellent.  I used chicken breasts instead for a healthier version.  I doubled the amount of garlic and ginger because my husband and I love a lot of those flavors.  I actually just poured all of the marinade over the chicken and baked while turning the chicken over once halfway through instead of brushing every ten minutes.  This was delicious.  The breasts had a candied coat on the surface and were juicy on the inside.  These were in the oven for fifty minutes instead of the full hour.

text:
I only followed this recipe's instructions as far as the teriyaki glaze, since I used boneless chicken breasts and cooked the chicken on a pan lined with aluminum foil for only 25 minutes.  The glaze is great!  Great tangy flavor, very easy to bring together; perhaps I will use a little less sugar next time, since it did seem a little overly sweet for me.  I used low sodium soy sauce, just because that's what I prefer.  This also makes a LOT of glaze -- since I typically never make more than four chicken breasts at a time, I'll probably halve the recipe next time.  Overall very good!

text:
I decided to try something new for my "Chicken Fried Rice" recipe. I used 3 boneless, skinless chicken breasts instead of the thighs. I used brown sugar instead of white, and I baked them in a 8x8" pan. Had I not been cutting this chicken into chunks and mixing it in my fried rice, I would have had to give this recipe 3 stars. The chicken was very tough, I'm not sure if it was the sauce or something else. I followed the instructions exactly, so I don't know what happened. The flavors in the sauce were great, and it was very easy to make. I will make this again, but only for my fried rice.

Wow this recipe is amazing. So far I have found 4 deliciously incredible recipes that I will make again and again and this is one of them. text:
LOVED IT!! What can I say...the whole family loved it.  Even my most pickiest eater had seconds, actually thirds(3yrs..so u may know how that goes!). I did not have enough soy suace to double. So after reading a few reviews I made a few adjustments that worked out GREAT thanks to other members (had enough to spread over rice): 
-mixed 1 1/2 tablespoons of cornstarch in 1/3 cup cold water
-lite soy sauce soy sauce
-3 tablespoons of rice vinegar
-1/4 teaspoon of ginger
I used skinless breast strips covered with foil first 30 min, uncovered for 15. Yummy. Tasty and tender! Enjoy!

text:
hi everyone! just wanted to say there is no need in doubling the sauce. the primary ingredients in this recipe are the sugar, soy sauce and vinegar. very powerfull stuff!! so i did things differently. first off, instead of 1 tablespoon water i disolved 1 1/2 tablespoons of cornstarch in 1/3 cup cold water. i used regular soy sauce, light brown sugar (white would have worked fine) and 3 tablespoons of rice vinegar. i have been told that cider vinager is stronger than rice vinegar so i definetly think it would be smart to use less. i used 1/4 teaspoon of ginger and this worked great for me. very strong sauce even adding all that water!! i think it all depends on what your using it for, i wanted to use the sauce but if its just a glaze it would probably work fine just as it is written. good luck! dont be intimidated by the recipe you can play around with it! thats why i give it a 5. if you use it exactly as written, just brushing the chicken it will come out fine following the recipe :)

text:
This is definitely a keeper!  My husband is Asian and makes his version all the time.  I generally think his has too much soy sauce or something, but this was just pleasantly right.  I did not change a thing from the original recipe.

I had 10 pieces and skinned half of them (hubby likes skin), put them in a corning ware dish for 1/2 an hour (too much liquid in the dish) and then transferred them to a cookie sheet with foil for the remaining 1/2 hour.  

Turned out perfect!  The chicken pieces with skin were somewhat burned(skin only), but the skinless ones were not burned at all.

Even dear hubby thought these were very good!

text:
I have been searching quite a while for the right teriyaki sauce & I have to say I found it. YOU MUST double the recipe & its a good thing I automatically did just that my first try out... none was left even after a double recipe! Okay I tweaked it slightly I used the first half cup of white sugar but on the second half for the double I used brown. That came out great. Now believe it or not I ran out of ginger and had to use my pumpkin spice for a substitute but I tell ya you hardly tasted the cinnamon. So even that way it was so good. ( I didnt use much pepper as it calls for but thats my personal choice I used 1/4 for the total didnt double up) You really have to try this one it will save you money and headaches searching. Also I used chicken breasts with about 5 cuts across on top to allow the sauce to fall in between. Serve with broccoli and white rice mmmm so so good!

Display Name:
joy-of-jesus-smileymom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/194174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I believe the flavor of this depends on the use of good soy sauce. Choose LITE (less sodium), and avoid one with caramel color, which has a very inauthentic/odd taste. I made several batches of sauce, varying the ingredients each time. The recipe made exactly as directed was very sweet and *extremely* spicy-- was it the pepper or the ginger? I finally settled on the combo of LITE soy, FRESH grated ginger (world of difference!!), rice vinegar (cider v. wasn't awful, but rice was better), and half the sugar for the most pleasant taste and aroma. Added a bit of red pepper flakes for zip. Thighs had the best taste and texture, tenders were next, and boneless breasts came in last. Glad I used foil, 425 baking temp. WAS perfect, but next time, I will dry chicken very well, and baste as directed instead of dumping all the sauce on (too soupy).
Review:

5

text:
I have made this a couple of times, the first time I followed the recipe & thought it was just ok.  The second time I made some changes & thought it was really good.  I used brown sugar instead of white & rice vinegar instead of apple cider.  Instead of thighs, I used a rotisserie chicken that I cut up into bite-size pieces.  I coated the chicken with just enough sauce (don't use too much!)  & baked it at 425 for 20 minutes, until it caramelized a bit.  It turned out so good.  I sauteed some veggies & combined them with the chicken & served it over rice.  My husband doesn't normally like teriyaki sauce, but he really liked this. This would be a great way to use leftover chicken.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so easy.  A lot of people changed things, I didn't change the ingredients with the exception of using low sodium soy sauce since I'm pregnant.  My husband commented on how much he loved that it was not a real salty sauce so I will probably always use low sodium.  It was delicious and one of the best teriyaki sauces we have ever tasted!  I used chicken breasts instead of thighs because that's what we prefer and it turned out great.  I also tenderized them down to about 1/2 inch and cut them in half if they were large so they would cook faster.  The chicken really did cook  in 30 min which was great and I also put the heat to 400 degrees instead of 425.    I used foil to cover the pan (9X13 glass, only thing big enough!) instead of greasing it but it did not keep my pan from getting the sticky teriyaki sauce baked on but that's totally ok.  This will definitely be made again in our family!

text:
I usually do not review any recipes, just read other people's reviews, but I just HAD to on this recipe!!  This was the best recipe I have ever made and was the best teriyaki chicken I have ever had!!  I followed other reviews and adjusted this way:  Changed the white sugar to 1/4 c., and added 1/2 cup of brown sugar.  I used boneless chicken breasts, and while I was cooking sauce added meat to saucepan, so it was soaking up all that marinade.  I cooked in oven about 375-400 degrees, and covered with foil for 20-25 min., and then uncovered for 15 minutes.  I am a single parent of 2 children and both my kids devoured it!!  We absolutely will make this time and time again!!!  Thanks for the fantastic recipe!!

This was really good although I did things a little differently.  First of all, I don't like my teriyaki so sweet so next time I might use a little less sugar.  Second of all, I wanted more of a stir fry so I cooked the chicken first, cut it up in to pieces and then made the sauce as directed.  I put the pieces of chicken, some mushrooms, a bag of stir fry vegetables (thawed), and some cooked brown rice in the pan and simmered covered for 10 minutes. It was a hit!

OH MY GOSH.  I followed this recipe to a T, and it came out SO GOOD!!!!!!!!  (Wait... I used Low sodium Soy, and 6 thighs instead of 12.)  Ok, first, I don't really like chicken thighs, but it's all I had.  I nuked some frozen broccoli and tossed it in the leftover juices.  WOW.  It's so good.  I really recommend this recipe to anyone.  I hate too many ingredients and using too many dishes and this one was so easy.  I put foil in the bottom of the dish and cleanup was a snap.  Don't get discouraged if the chicken and glaze looks to watery.  By the 45-60 mins, it starts glazing up.  SO GOOD!!!  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
This chicken recipe is awesome!  The entire family loved it - even my picky son, the "non-meat eater" in our family.  I followed previous reviews and covered the dish during the first half-hour of cooking,and it was perfect - the chicken nice and moist, but he last half-hour uncovered gave the sauce time to carmelized and thicken.  

The amount of sacue is perfect for one package of boneless thighs, but make sure to baste the chicken every 15 minutes, if not more.  It really helps.

text:
Very easy and sooo delicious.  I marinated chicken tenderloins in the sauce, then baked but at 375 degrees and for only 20 mins. so as not to dry them out.  Served over rice w/ extra sauce.  This would work well w/ larger boneless breasts or bone-in pieces in a crock pot, too, I think.  I may have to try that.  Might be good w/ pineapple chunks.  Love the sauce!  Great meal!  UPDATE:  Made double batch of this amazing sauce...before cooking/thickening, I marinated 8 boneless pork loin chops for 4 hours in 1/2 the sauce, then grilled them.  Simmered/thickened remaining sauce on stovetop in small pot.  Served sauce over grilled chops...amazing!!

None
country:
None
text:
I thought the flavor of this chicken was really tasty. I took some suggestions from other reviewers by greasing the pan with sesame oil, doubling the sauce, using half white and half brown sugar and adding 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon to the doubled sauce. I also covered the baking pan for the first 30 minutes of cooking. Yes, the pan was a mess and took some scrubbing, but I avoid having aluminum leach into the food I serve my kids whenever possible - as it is a known neurotoxin. The chicken thighs came out juicy and delicious - and I reserved some of the sauce to drizzle over the rice I made with it. Will definitely be making this again.

text:
I've made this recipe multiple times and everyone in my family loves it! I use boneless skinless chicken breasts. It is delicious even if you don't baste your chicken every ten minutes, but I think it is so much better and has more flavor if you do. I also pound my chicken with a meat mallet to make it more tender and absorb more sauce. I also think lining your pan with foil is smart, because if you don't it makes a sticky mess.

text:
YUM. This recipe tasted similar to a recipe that my mother used to make.  I don't have her recipe, but I know her recipe uses honey. Well, I'm on the Atkins diet and only had to substitute the sugar for Splenda, and voila, GREAT low carb recipe. The flavor is great. I would advise those with high blood pressure to use low sodium soy sauce. I love salt, and to me, the saltiness was just right. I dumped the cornstarch/water combo in the pot and it immediately thickened the mixture, so make sure you have a whisk nearby so you can whisk it before it clumps. This made it a perfect glaze consistency...  Simple recipe, perfect flavor!

text:
Absolutely wonderful!!!! This is probably the best chicken I have ever cooked. After a couple times of making this recipe, I tried to experiment with making thai "money bags." Those too are great! After baking the chicken, shred it. Add a little bit of the sauce and mix with diced onion, cilantro, jalepeno, etc. Take wonton wrappers and put about a tsp. of the filling in each. Take corners and pinch and twist like little money bags. Fry at 365 degrees until golden brown. YUMMY!

Yum, yum, yum!!! Doubled sauce recipe, cooked it, cooled it, and then marinated (2) 20 oz packs of boneless skinless thighs for 3 hours, turning once.  I poured the chicken and marinade into the foil-lined pan. Changes per other reviews: Used 3/4 brown sugar and 1/4 white, low sodium soy sauce, added equivalent of 4 garlic cloves, lined baking pan with foil, sprayed foil with non-stick, and cooked covered with foil at 400 degrees for 30 min. and uncovered for 15 minutes.  Sauce good on rice too.  Next time I might put a little less vinegar.

Display Name:
Erin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/46210.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good! This sauce could easily be used for a Teriyaki stir fry (add sauce from saucepan to a sautee pan with cooked chicken, shrimp, pork, etc. with veggies and cook for approx five minutes). Would also work great on Kabobs on the grill! I followed the advice of reviewers & doubled the sauce (but not the vinegar). I also lined and covered the pan with foil for baking; easy clean up & no black, smokey mess. No need to brush or turn chicken if you use boneless breasts in a shorter, deeper dish as doubled sauce will nearly cover chicken. The cook time suggested is too long for boneless breasts though; 30/40 minutes is plenty. Served over wild rice with sauce as "gravy" over rice. Nice recipe! Possibilities are many! P.S. used 1/2 cup brown sugar & 1/4 cup white. Not at all too sweet!

I added 3 tbsp of water to even out the taste. Marinated the chicken overnight in some of the sauce... baked next day and it came out juicy and incredibly flavourful. Excellent teriyaki chicken recipe!

I can not say enough good things about this recipe.  My only changes were to substitue Splenda for the requested sugar (I'm low-carbing and this made it allowable!), and I omitted the ginger (due to personal preferences only). This was soooooooooooooooooo good that when my husband came home from work the next day, the first thing he asked for was left over chicken and he wasn't too thrilled when I told him I had taken some for lunch :o)--trust me, my husband is very finicky and he has asked me to make this regularly!!  This is officially a staple in my recipe box. FYI:  12 packets Splenda=1/2 cup sugar and you won't even notice the difference. Excellent sweet tangy taste!!  No after-taste (and I used regular Splenda, not the "for baking" splenda!) Thank you soooooooooo much for such a quick and yummy recipe that I will be sure to pass down to my kids!

text:
Excellent Teriyaki sauce! Followed the recipe exactly (alert the media!), but doubled the sauce recipe and marinated the chicken pieces in some of it for about an hour. Instead of cooking in the oven, we threw the chicken thighs outside on the grill and slow-cooked them, basting every 10 minutes with the sauce until they were done. Awesome flavor and gives a great carmelization on an outdoor grill! The next time I make this, I might toss in a few crushed red pepper flakes for a little extra kick to see how that turns out...can't wait to try basting burgers and ribs on the grill with this! This was a pleasant surprise - I have to admit that the vinegar smell was pretty strong throughout the house while it simmered, but there was no overly strong vinegar flavor at all in the end. Just sweet, tangy perfection!

text:
I forgot that I cooked this once before using thighs and basting like crazy. It turned out great. This time I took others' advice and used the crockpot. I don't recommend that. Well, that or b/c I used boneless breasts rather than thighs. My chicken came out fairly dry and not too tasty. The sauce is great which is why I rated it as such (its super yummy on rice). And I know the recipe works, just not for me using breasts & a crockpot. I think the sauce takes awhile to cook though personally, so its not a 5 minute prep for me. I don't want to burn it so it takes awhile to boil and get thickened, like maybe 20 minutes or so after I get all the ingredients in. Oh yeah, I think there is a little bit too much vinegar in it (I only had garlic rice vinegar) and I will not put the entire amount in next time. I had to pour extra (low sodium) soy sauce in to balance out the taste. I'm going to try this on pork chops and chicken wings next time.

It wasn't as good as I expected from all the great reviews, but it's still tasty. Definitely double or even triple the ingredients for sauce - more for vegetables, rice, and just extra flavor generally. But could reduce the cider vinegar and soy sauce because it is a little bit on the salty side. Also reduce the sugar. I felt the recipe was missing a key ingredient: SESAME OIL!!!! Add 2 tablespoons or so will definitely make it a lot better. The final product came out tasting good, but very commercial. I was hoping for a more gourmet teriyaki recipe! Also I used breast tenders and it came out very dry, next time I will definitely try chicken thighs instead.

userID:
1519113
Display Name:
KB
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
58
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used about 10-12 chicken tenders for this, because I wanted to make teriyaki chicken skewers. I followed the directions for the sauce, marinated for 8 hours, then cubed the chicken. I put 4 or 5 pieces of chicken on each skewer, along with some pineapple chunks. Set the oven to broil, lined a cookie sheet with foil (crucial!), and poured 1/3 of unused marinade on top. Broiled for 5 minutes. Turned, added more sauce, and broiled again. I ended up cooking these for something like 20 minutes. I served them at a cocktail party, but I got distracted and left them in the oven too long. I was afraid they'd be tough or dry, but people literally devoured them. I wish I'd made more--10 chicken tenders made about 20 skewers. Be sure to marinade for at least a few hours, so the flavor will really get intot the meat.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-01-27T18:22:43.657
helpfulCount:
1

text:
I used chicken thighs with skin (only about 4-5) and put them in a loaf pan instead. I made the amount of sauce needed for 12 pieces of chicken and didn't turn the chicken over but kept it baking for an hour. It ended up to be WONDERFUL! I would suggest doubling the sauce if you actually make the 12 pieces, having the chicken 'drowning' in the sauce makes it very very tender.

Followed the ingredients exactly....However instead of brushing the sauce on I dipped the chicken in the sauce to coat then place it on a foil lined baking pan and poured the remaining sauce over it and marinated it for about 6 hours then baked covered in a 400 degree oven for 30 mins then uncovered for another 30 minutes.  It was very good.  Although hubby said it tasted like BBQ Chicken as opposed to Teriyaki.

country:
None
text:
I used skinless thighs.  They didn't crisp as they would have if they were with the skin on.  Don't cry of there's too much sugar or salt.  You have enough time to taste the baste before you start marinating the chicken.  I always use fish sauce with these kinds of recipes but remember, don't exceed 1 tsp; it is a very strong flavoring ingredient.  I cut some very thin slices of cabbage to lay the chicken onto, which intensifies the flavor by nullifying the pungencies but pushing the texture.  YUM.

text:
everyone loved this dish. i used chicken breasts, and marinated them for about an hour. then baked at 375 for 30 minutes and at 400 for about 15 minutes more. they were drier than i'd hoped, so next time i will skip the last 15 minutes at a higher temp and just cook at 375 the whole way through. there was enough sauce for everyone (but we didn't use it on the rice). i used rice vinegar and brown sugar, plus a bit more ginger. thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this a few days ago and I modified it, not much though.  I changed the sugar to 1/4 cup and used teriyaki sauce instead of soy sauce.  I boiled it up to let it thicken and then poured it over my cut up chicken breast in large chunks, broccoli, match stick carrott sticks and thin sliced onion in a foil oven bag and baked it on 325 for about 45 minutes to an hour.  Served it over thin spagetti.  It was to die for.  Great recipe.  Thanks.

Delicious and easy!!  I made the sauce earlier in the day, used a whole cut up chicken, and marinated it for a few hours in the fridge.  Also, since I was out of ginger, I used some candied ginger slices that I diced very fine...it worked wonderfully.  I baked it in a clear glass 9 x 13 dish...and it really wasn't that difficult to clean since I let it soak while we were eating this yummy chicken!  This is definitely going into the rotation.  Thanks so much for sharing and making me look like a good cook!

text:
Holy Salt!  Def need to use a low sodium soy sauce.  I doubled the sauce which I made in the afternoon and poured about 3/4 of it in 13x9 inch pan and put 8 boneless chicken breasts in.  I let that marinate in the fridge for a few hours with some pineapple slices on top.   I took out of fridge 1/2 before baking and baked uncovered at 375 for 30 minutes and they were perfect.  Didn't really need the extra sauce I reserved.  Next time I will also add 1/2 the ginger as well because I'm not a huge fan of a strong ginger taste.   As a side note-the sauce does take a good 1/2 hour to thicken and bubble.  Will def try again with minor adjustments because it was good!

text:
The only reason I give this recipe a 4 is that my husband has yet to believe it is supposed to be Teriyaki sauce! We really like the taste, but he always says it tastes more like a barbeque sauce to him. So, if you're looking for a very tasty recipe, try it, just be warned that you may not find this to be a real "Teriyaki" recipe.

text:
This came out perfectly.  I used 1 lb of chicken breast, and took the advice of other reviewers to double the sauce - it was a bit much for so little meat, but now I have leftover that I can use for a stir-fry or something.  I also cut back on the soy sauce, and used 1/2 c brown & 1/4 cup white sugar.  Served this over rice with broccoli, green peppers, and snap peas. Great leftover too. Thanks Marian!

this recipe turned out really well the first time i tried it.  i'm impressed with how easy and simple it was to make.  marinated the chicken with the sauce for an hour before baking.  cooking time only took 30 minutes (15 minutes each side) instead of 1 hour.  didn't need to brush with sauce every 10 minutes as i had placed extra sauce in the baking dish.  only brushed more sauce on once after 15 minutes when chicken pieces were turned.  overall, great recipe.  did find the taste a little bit too sweet/sour but will adjust next time i try it again!

text:
Yummy! I thought I could only buy teriyaki sauce in a bottle! I used the EXACT ingredients the recipe called for. Very easy. I heated the sauce in the microwave until it bubbled and thickened. I only stirred once. It’s fast because of the sugar. I didn’t do thighs. I injected the sauce into a whole chicken and roasted it, basting it with the remaining sauce 2 or 3 times. I roasted the whole chicken according to the per lb. directions on the wrapper. You might want to double the sauce recipe if you have a really big roaster. It was very moist and delicately flavored. Real restaurant quality - fit for company fare. The chicken came out picture perfect brown, as good as any I’ve ever had rotisseried from the deli. I WILL make this again.

I found this to be an easy and great tasting sauce.  Didn't change a thing.  Took about 30 minutes to make the sauce thicken, left it simmering as the chicken cooked, was really thick by the end. No more store bought teriyaki sauce!!! Thanks for sharing Marian!!

text:
This was a success at my house. My kids like pineapple so I wanted to add some sliced pineapple on top of my chicken breasts.  I also poured a little pineapple juice in the teriyake sauce.  I poured the sauce over the chicken and made sure each piece was coated on all sides.  Midway through cooking, I turned each piece and made sure each was coated in more sauce.  I was too lazy to brush them every 10 minutes, and they turned out fine.  A few minutes before taking them out, I put a slice of pineapple on each one.  This was great with rice pilaf.

The second time I made this recipe, I did everything exactly the same as before but I used one of those oven bags.  Much easier to coat the chicken and easy clean up too!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nothing special.  
The sauce was similar to bottled varieties...which has both pros and cons.  Pro, you can adjust flavoring to taste, and only fresh ingredients are going into the sauce.  Con, why spend the time making something that's inexpensive and readily available at the store?
As far as the cook time, the constant basting left a pool of sauce on the bottom of the pan, which burned while cooking, leaving a lingering "burnt food" smell in the kitchen.  It also left a sticky mess on the bottom of the pan.  I highly suggest lining your pan with heavy duty foil, grease it, then place the chicken.  In the end, I wasn't impressed by the sauce.  I thought it was very generic.  My husband said it may go well with grilled salmon.  That may be true, but until I find a standout teriyaki recipe, I'll stick to bottled sauce.

I love the fact that I can now have teriyaki sauce, homemade, hence the 4 stars. I made this with cut up wings and drumsticks, which I marinated overnight in the fridge. This was so-so, it really wasn't as great as I had hoped.  

I trippled the sauce recipe and added some green onions and pineapple to the leftover sauce to make a teriyaki topping for the chicken, and that turned out good!

If you modify this recipe at all, watch out for the ginger!  Use less and less ginger the more you double the recipe.  It can take over.

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a "must" recipe if you love teriyaki chicken. I doubled the sauce recipe, used chicken breasts that I had pounded out thinner, and also did as others suggested and used foil on the bottom! of the pan. I baked them at 400 degrees and it only took about 40 minutes because of the thinner breasts. In a small skillet I sauteed some green oinions and diced red pepper until soft, added pineapple tidbits with a little juice, some of the teriyaki sauce and cornstarch and cooked it until it thickened and then put it on the chicken just before serving. This is wonderful eating....try it you'll like it. Thanks, Marian!!

text:
I have cooked this several ways now.  I have found following the recipe and basting every ten minutes to be the best way.  The sauce gets caked on the chicken instead of running off of it.   I used a glass dish to cooked them in.  Makes a mess of the dish but just let it soak for a few hours or overnight.  Edit: still making this years later.  We love the sauce!!!
Michele k, cambridge ontario

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others have said, I doubled the recipe.  For mine, I put foil in a 9x13 pan and then put about 6 thighs (I made two pans), poured half the sauce over each pan, and cooked for 20min.  After 20 min, I flipped the chicken over and added diced bell pepper, mushrooms, carrot slices, snow peas, pineapple, and fresh green beans to each pan and poured sauce over them.  Continued cooking for an additional 20min.  Turned out fantastic.  Served with rice. and spooned the sauce from the pan over the entire bowl.

text:
I made w life soy sauce and doubled the sauce. I kept the sugar amount as is. However, the dish was overwhelmed with chicken grease that we couldn’t enjoy the sauce. When I make it again, I’ll bake chicken in 1/2 the sauce until done, then I will remove chicken from the pan it was baked in and transfer it to a different dish where I will then Add the other half of the sauce to it so the final dish isn’t so greasy.

Display Name:
Ms. J.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7100548.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used boneless skinless breasts cut into strips so there was more surface area to soak in the sauce. The recipe amount of sauce is perfect for 3 breasts IF you put them into a small baking dish. If you spread this out in a big dish it'll smoke and burn because of the high sugar content. I rolled the chicken in toasted sesame oil before pouring on the hot sauce. Also added 2 Tbsp cooking sherry and 1 Tbsp oyster sauce to add depth. And of course fresh ginger and garlic grated on a rasp! (If you don't have one of these you should get one ASAP.) Baked them for 35 minutes at 400°, turning in the sauce halfway through. Served over rice with roasted cabbage wedges and toasted sesame seeds strewn on top. EASY and DELICIOUS!

text:
This was good, better than okay, but not delicious.  I used chicken breasts and that could have been why I didn’t think it was five stars.  I doubled the ingredients because I baked 10 chicken breasts and made the chicken in disposable aluminum pans.  I baked them at 375 for 20 minutes and turned them over and baked them for 20 more minutes and rotated the pans as well.  Clean up was easy and the sauce didn’t stick to the disposable pans. Like other reviewers I recommend adding more cornstarch to thicken the sauce. I will make again and use dark meat and if using white meat marinating them before baking or grilling them.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The sauce was delicious! Definitely would double the sauce next time especially if you like it thicker. I had to use a lot of cornstarch to thicken it...i marinated the chicken with the sauce before cooking. If you want thicker and sticky  sauce  on the chicken, cook chicken with covered with foil , HOWEVER wait till the very end to coat the sauce on the chicken, and then cook briefly uncovered. If you cover the chicken back, the thicken sauce will become liquid. I cooked the chicken uncovered for too long and it became a bit dry.

text:
This is one of my favorite chicken dishes.  Followed the recipe as written first time and was impressed.  In my spirit of trying to make it my own and working off suggestions from family and friends, I have made the following changes.  Reduced the white sugar to 1/4 cup, added 1/2 cup brown sugar, 2 cloves minced garlic and 1 tsp fresh minced ginger to help add a bit of a kick.   I usually also double the sauce recipe and whatever isn't used is put into a squeeze condiment bottle and stuck in the fridge (tbh, i love the sauce recipe here just by itself)

text:
So glad I read reviews.  Adjusted the recipe like many suggested.  Doubled the batch of sauce, didn't use as much sugar and what I used was brown sugar.  Used fresh garlic and ginger and used more than suggested.  With all the adjustments it turned out wonderful.  So thankful someone mentioned using aluminum foil.  Probably saved my dish.  The aroma of the sauce burning  onto the aluminum wasn't pleasant, but the taste of the chicken was AMAZING.  Didn't have but 5 large thighs so I used a chicken breast sliced in half for the balance of meat.

country:
None
text:
Notes for myself: Used 3 chicken breasts, doubled sauce, used 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar, sub'd 1/4 white vinegar. Set oven to 375 degrees. Lined pan with foil, 15 mins, flip, then 15 more mins. Removed some watery sauce, re-covered with remaining sauce reserved on stovetop.

I noticed chicken was chewy and bland, so i sliced it up into strips and put it back in the sauce. Was yummy over white rice, topped with scallions.

(Next time, just cook in the covered skillet, rather than bake.)

text:
This is a good teriyaki chicken recipe. I would advise as others did to use 3/4 of the amount of sugar and soya sauce that was called for. I also added extra ginger and doubled the sauce recipe. Don't cover it in the oven as others have advised. If you do there will be too many chicken juices which will make the sauce very watery. My husband and I will make this again!

text:
Making this recipe for the third time tonight I just love it so much! I have made a few adjustments and have found the PERFECT cooked chicken! I doubled the recipe for the sauce, and used 1/2 brown and 1/2 white sugar. Lined a 9x9 pan with tinfoil, and dumped the sauce on the chicken, prior to cooking. 400 degrees for 20 minutes, then flip and cook for another 20 minutes. I LOVE the texture it adds to the chicken.

text:
This is easy and delicious. Out of pure laziness I followed the tip of another reviewer and just dumped the sauce over the chicken. I also lined my pan because sugar based sauces will get thick and sticky and burn into your dish so again, out of laziness, line with foil. I also used boneless skinless thighs because A) I had them and B) Speed. Cooked all the way through in maybe thirty minutes. Turned them once about 2/3 of the way through. Tender, flavorful, I didn’t mess with the sauce because it’s a pretty standard mix ratio for soy and sugar based sauces. It’s adhered so well to the chicken! Great recipe for school night dinners!

text:
This is close to my aunt's "Japanese Chicken" recipe, for which I use a combo of white and brown sugar and white vinegar, additional water instead of all soya sauce, plus no pre-boiling the sauce and uses all the pieces of a whole chicken. For today I followed this Teriyaki recipe and baked 9 boneless, skinless pieces with the sauce in a casserole dish. I made extra sauce per the reviews, but it wasn't necessary as my baking dish was smaller. I also kept a lid on until near the end, and only baked for about 40 minutes at 400 degrees. Even my picky kids loved it!

I must admit I made two changes to the recipe- I used brown sugar, not white, and I seared boneless skinless breasts in the skillet, then made the sauce and threw the chicken back in. Overall this was incredible- very easy, family loved it. I definitely want to try the baking method this recommends. Also I will add chopped green onions for garnish.

text:
Okay, I never do reviews on recipes (or even to remember to save them) but this was delicious. My 1 year old ate until we got tired of sitting at the table, and then licked his fingers and stuffed the piece in his mouth he found in his bib. My husband claimed it's the best teriyaki chicken he's ever had. Subbed rice vinegar for the acv because that's what we had, & used the full amount of sauce for half the chicken. I flipped it after 20 minutes so I could start basting it every 10 and pulled it out after about 40-50 minutes once temp was right (>165F). The sauce was thick and thickened even more as it cooked, which made it stick really well & kept the chicken juicy. Way easier than I expected, and so good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it as written.  My husband and I loved it.  One nice thing about this recipe is you can flex either the Ginger, Cider Vinegar or Sugar to get the flavor that fits your pallett.  For example, the second time I made this I wanted it to be slightly less sweet and more vinegar so I dialed the sugar back from 1/2 cup to 1/3 cup and left the vinegar as is.  It was perfect. 

I also tried, the second time I made it, tenderizing the chicken using a tenderizing tool while my sauce was heating and that worked nicely.  At 425 degrees my cooking time was 10 minutes per side and thus a total of 20 minutes - less than what the recipe calls for as is.

Finally, Trader Joe's sells a wonderful low sodium soy sauce that I use to keep the sodium in check.  It's a wonderful flavor I prefer over the Kikkoman low sodium soy sauce.  (I have no affliation with Trader Joe's, Kikkoman or whoever the supplier is that makes this product.  I just enjoy the Trader Joe's product for this dish.)

text:
Wow, really good! I made a few changes to this recipe. I had 6 small thighs. First I used 1 1/2 Tbls of corn starch because I wanted a sauce that will stick to the chicken. It took a while to thicken, so be patient! I used  1/4 c. of brown sugar and 1/4 of white sugar.  I preheated the oven at 400. I did not cover the thighs with aluminum foil. . I cooked one side for 25 minutes. Then after brushing the sauce on the other side, I reduced the oven to 375 and cooked for another 20 minutes. Delish! Thank you!

I'm in LOVE with this recipe! Doubled it because I wanted to have some leftover. I have teens and a toddler who are picky so I used chicken breasts cut up in bite sized pieces and let those suckers swim in the sauce in the oven at 375° for 30 minutes. My husband says there can never be enough garlic so added a tad more for him. Served with rice and veggies and edamame. I'm not ashamed. I licked my plate. Thank you for such a great family meal! YUMMMMMM! For those of you who don't like to scrub that dish, let it soak right away in some soapy water, sit down and have a glass of wine, relax, and it will rinse out just fine!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this recipe a few times, first the way it was written which turned out delicious. My only gripe was that the leftover sauce gelatinized and couldn’t be reused. I tried everything to resurrect it, but to no avail. The second time I dumped all of the ingredients into a ziplock bag and threw in chicken. I let everything marinate for about five hours and then put the chicken onto the BBQ. It turned out beautifully. The flavors were still there, along with the dark color and crusty outside. It saved me some dishes too.

This is a keeper ! Easy and quick. I used honey in place of sugar and liquid aminos in place of soy sauce. Used the sauce,  but made this in the slow cooker. Put chicken thighs and sauce in cooker, then cooked on high for 4 hours. Then added pineapple chunks, bell pepper, celery and carrots and cooked for about 45 minutes more. Served over rice with an Asian slaw for dinner. We loved it! BTW doubled the sauce, so we had plenty for the rice. The chicken was fall off the bone tender with great flavor. Thanks for the recipe. Will definitely make again.

Delicious!  I used chicken breasts and cut them into chunks so it would cook faster.  Done in 20 minutes with a convection oven at 425 (lucky me!).  I paired this with Carrot Rice (recipe on here) and it was a lovely dinner and leftover lunch.  Careful when baking - the sugary sauce will burn up around the chicken, but if you flip chicken and add more sauce every 10 minutes, you can keep it under control.

userID:
1694800
Display Name:
Tamela Workman
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
42
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3950284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I curt the recipe down to 1/3 because I didn't need 12 servings. I also used boneless, skinless thighs because that is what I had on hand.  It turned out great!  I cooked the thighs in the oven, basting  and turning them every 10 minutes. When they were almost done, i removed them from the pan and poured the liquid in the pan into the pan I used to make the sauce and boiled it for a few minutes to thicken it up a bit.  I returned the chicken to the baking pan and dumped the thickened sauce over the thighs and popped it back into the oven for the last 10 minutes.  I toasted  hamburger buns and served these as a sandwich.  They would have been great with some rice.  I think this recipe would be good also if you  added some pineapple, green pepper and onion to the sauce, cut the chicken in bite-sized pieces and baked it in the oven and served it over rice.  I am going to try that next time! Great recipe!
Review:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy to make and a great sauce for Teriyaki! I let the sauce simmer a little longer to get it to thicken more, resulting in a perfect balance of sweet to tangy. I used 6 boneless/skinless chicken thighs and baked for less time called for in the recipe (about 25-30 minutes at 425 F, basting every 10 minutes and flipped after about 15 minutes).  I did not scale down the recipe and made the sauce as written, which means I technically doubled the amount of sauce. The only reason I'm giving this 4 stars is because some of the sauce burned horribly and set off my smoke detectors. We still had some sauce left, but would have liked more. I'll make this again for the sauce alone, but in my wok as a stir fry instead of oven baked. Again, super easy recipe to make and will be a repeat here! Thanks for sharing the recipe! The sauce is very good!
Review:

text:
I had seen a video on FB of four different teriyaki bowls and couldn't find it for the life of me.  So I turned to my reliable friend (the reviews on AllRecipe) and found this one.  It was very easy to make, had great flavor, and I love that I could have this baking while I made the fried rice.  I used what I had on hand, so instead of soy sauce, I used teriyaki sauce... I had chicken thighs not breasts, but everything else was the same.  The flavor was fantastic, just right as far as sweet/salty goes.  The bake time for me was less, I cut mine into smaller pieces so we wouldn't have to cut it later, and they turned out great.  I was asked by my husband to make this a "keeper" recipe so in the recipe book it goes.  Thanks!

Recipe was good I did make a few changes I kept the chicken covered for the first half of cooking about 30 minutes I flipped all the pieces of chicken over and removed the aluminum foil uncovered it and baked it another 30 minutes I took the teriyaki sauce that was in the bottom of the baking dish when done and boiled on the stove till it was the thickness that I would like about 5-10 min and I broiled the chicken in the oven about five min I used low-sodium soy sauce and I added honey to the recipe it turned out wonderfully

country:
None
text:
I thought this was good. I made no changes to the sauce. It was sweet and tangy and salty all at the same time, if that makes sense. I would make it again with a little less sugar and reduced sodium soy sauce for a more mild flavor. I could see using the thickened sauce itself for dipping chicken strips into or for a stir fry. I would imagine it would be good with salmon as well. It was simple and quick to put together. Just a little too sweet but I can make adjustments next time.

text:
Awesome!!! Only changes were that I doubled the sauce, used boneless breasts (left them thick and unpounded out), lower sodium soy, 1/2 brown sugar/1/2 sugar in the raw and cooked uncovered at 425 for 30 and 400 for 20 basting every 15 minutes, reserved half the sauce for mid-way through  the cooking and a quarter for the last 15 minutes. Served with brown rice that I sautéed with a little bit of the reserved sauce, Asian salad and a veggie. MY FAMILY ABSOULTELY LOVED THIS RECIPE!!!!

text:
So I made the sauce exactly as it said. I however used boneless skinless chicken breasts. I cut them in three as they were so big.  Then I baked it but not at the high temp it called for because my family was going to be late for dinner.  I poured all the sauce on the chicken then I rotated them to cover them well and did so about 2-3 more times while cooking.  There was lots of sauce in the end.  I poured a little over my steamed veggies near the end of the meal.  Next time I plan to use the sauce and turn it into a sort of stir fry.  The sauce was very good.  Guess I didn't give it 5 stars because I used the breast.  I think legs or wings would be better and cooked at a high temp. I am not partial to thighs. Too much fat.  Reading other reviews I can not imagine why anyone would think the sauce needs MORE sugar.  There was also more then enough sauce to cover 4 VERY large frozen chicken breasts I buy at Sams Club in those large bags. Those breasts are HUGE.  Just saying and the sauce was more then enough.

text:
Very, very good!  The only thing I changed was the preparation of the chicken; I flattened it with a mallet and then only baked for 20 min each side.  Some other thoughts:
*Definitely line the pan (I used no stick Reynolds foil).  
*Using all of the sugar was good for us
*I didn't cover the chicken with foil because I wanted the sauce to get thick and sticky gooey, which it did!  Delicious!  
*I can see where doubling the sauce would be a good idea so I'll do that next time. 
*Oh there will definitely be a next time!  Maybe with salmon!

text:
This was super easy to make in the crock pot instead!  Tastes really good.

I made one and a half times the sauce, because I started with like 16 chicken thighs. Toward the end of cooking it on high for like 5 hours, I took some of sauce out and added about a half a cup of cornstarch to make a rue I added to thicken it up.

I will surely make it again! Next time, I may add some sesame seeds and a tiny bit more ginger.

text:
This is an easy recipe to make.  I made it all in a wok or a pan on stove.  I used chicken tenders or cut up chicken breast.  I brown the chicken on the pan and then I add all the sauce ingredients in a bowl, mixed and then added to the pan with cooked chicken.  Let it all simmer until thick and served with rice.  Perfect for a quick weekday meal.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe. I did double the sauce keeping the sugar at 1/2 cup. I used blonde organic coconut sugar. Next time I might use minced fresh ginger. I used a cup of tamari (gluten free) but to cut the saltiness next time I will probably use half tamari and half coconut aminos. If you aren't using the sauce over rice or stir fry vegetables you don't necessarily need to double it. It's plenty  for the chicken alone. I made stir fry vegetables as a side (onions, julienne red peppers, carrots, snow peas, and savoy cabbage) and wanted to use the extra sauce for that. This is a good one and I will make it again.

text:
I sort of made it, but with modifications.  I used rice instead of pasta; and I seared the thighs, then brushed them often as they  baked in an electric skillet.  I'm 76 and chose the skillet as a way to avoid the up/down of baking in the oven and removing from the oven to brush.  I served with oriental veggies.  The carnivores in the family loved it.  We are a "mixed" family (I'm Nana, d-in-law, 2 teens, and son, 3 carnivores and 2 mostly vegetarian).  My 4 stars is about my need to modify, no problem otherwise.

um.. yeah.. this was really good.  I made a double batch of the basting sauce (based on other reviewers), but really didn't need to double it.  I made with 8 good sized thighs in a roasting pan lined with foil.  I used mostly low sodium soy with a little regular soy sauce. Kids really liked it and I plan to make it every other week.

It reminded me of a dish I had in the army  many years ago. I think they called it five spice chicken and it was soy and teriyaki based chicken. I used a boneless chicken breast because that's what I had on hand at the time.  I had been planning on flattening the breast out, marinating it in teriyaki before placing it over some coals, then topping it with chopped green peppers, chopped onion and cheddar cheese. It’s really good! I agree with the rest to double the sauce. I used 4 chicken thighs / legs in a 9x13 dish. Baked at 400F for 30 mins and at 370F for another 30 mins. Lined the dish with foil for easy cleanup and didn’t cover the top with foil as suggested by another user to prevent it from being watery. Baked chicken teriyaki was juicy and tender. This recipe is a keeper!

userID:
21937899
Display Name:
corylaura
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family and I absolutely love this recipe. However, I can only make it on nights when I can be home during the entire cooking period to do the basting. This can be difficult as my kids are involved in many activities requiring a lot of chauffeuring & late nights. Tonight I made it in my Insta Pot and was very pleased with the results! Doubled the sauce, added an extra tablespoon of water. I let the chicken thighs marinate in the sauce for 20 min, removed them & used the sauté (more) setting to bring the sauce to a boil. I put the chicken back in, set a steam team on top and a bowl of rice on top of that (1 cup rice, 1 cup water). Then 6 minute pressure cook time with natural pressure release.  After pressure released, I removed the chicken to a baking pan, basted with the sauce & broiled it for about 3 minutes while I re-sautéed the sauce to thicken it.  With all the time involved for prep, pressure time & broiling, it was probably a 40 minute meal, but only about 12 minutes hands on!  7 up front and 5 on the back end.

text:
This is a delicious recipe and I have no clue why I never made it before tonight. I did make a couple small changes though. I doubled the recipe and used half white sugar, half brown sugar as suggested by other reviews. I also used gluten free soy sauce and for the other half water due to the complaints of saltiness. I brought to a boil on low and then cooked for 5 minutes then stirred and then let it simmer for 5 more minutes. Then I removed from heat and allowed it to sit for 20ish minutes before preparing the chicken. I did use bone in chicken thighs but I removed the skins and extra fat and baked at 400 for 1hour.

text:
Very good! Made the amount the recipe calls for even though I was only making two large chicken breasts.  I used all the sauce! Used low sodium soy. Cooked at 425 for 20 minutes, flipped chicken, then cooked at 375 for 20 more. Perfect. I did baste the liquid over the chicken every 8 -10 minutes or so. Sauteed chopped red, yellow & orange peppers and mixed in with the sauce and poured over meat at the end. Served dish over long grain wild rice. Delicious, tender meat. Not too sweet OR salty! Great recipe.

text:
I used the recipe as shown except for using six thighs instead of 12. I think if I were to use 12, then I would have to double the sauce. Brushing them every ten mins seemed like too much work for me so as another reviewer suggested, I just put all the sauce on and saved a bit back to pour on mid-baking. For 30 mins I cooked them covered in foil, and then removed the foil for the last 30 mins. They turned out tender and delicious. Next time I would like to try using honey instead of sugar.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really delicious teriyaki recipe, and it's fantastic served over brown rice.  However, there  is a problem with one part of the recipe.  The recipe calls for baking the skinless chicken thighs for a total of 60 minutes, which would only be suitable for bone-in skinless chicken thighs.  Boneless skinless chicken thighs only need to be baked for about 25 minutes depending upon the thickness of each chicken thigh.  It would be helpful for the recipe to specify the times for both boneless and bone-in skinless chicken thighs.  

Marinating the chicken thighs in the teriyaki sauce before baking enhances the flavor of the finished product.  I was able to successfully substitute the half cup of white sugar with a quarter cup of Truvia, which is a sugar / stevia baking blend.   Also, I used reduced sodium soy sauce.  Thank you for such a flavorful teriyaki chicken recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4

My family hates bottled Teriyaki sauce and so do I. I was hesitant to try this but figured since it wasn't bottled I would give it a try. WOW! Everyone raved over it! Now they want me to put this sauce on everything! I used reduced sodium soy sauce since we're all on a low-salt regimen. Use real garlic not the dried stuff. We will be making this over and over again!

text:
Awesome sauce!  I used chicken tenders and cooked on the stove.  I only seasoned chicken with some garlic powder, onion powder, paprika and cracked pepper.  Cooked those in a little olive oil until just about done.  Then I just poured the sauce into the pan (that I had made this morning before going to work) and let it bubble and cook for about 10 minutes or so longer.  Delicious and easy!!  For the sauce, I did not double.  I used 1/4 cup each white and brown sugars.  I doubled the garlic and added a pinch of pepper flakes.  The uncooked chicken tenders are from a bag you can find at most stores, 2lbs I think.  Thanks for this.......looking forward to trying with wings in oven!

This was very good. Double the sauce but keep the sugar and soy sauce the same. (I used lite soy sauce to cut the salt.) I also used brown sugar instead of white sugar. I suggest putting foil on the bottom of the pan so the sauce doesn't burn. Try dipping the chicken in the sauce (I used boneless and skinless thighs) then pouring the remaining sauce over the chicken before baking. This is my family's favorite recipe.

I did 8 thighs & doubled the sauce per many other reviews & I did not completely double the sugar but the extra amount added I did use brown sugar. I also didn't double the vinegar but having an orange tree in the backyard I did the zest and juice of a medium sized orange. Came out PERFECT! I have a Ninja cooking system which is the best thing ever! Did it for about 45 mins total cooking time. 25 mins on first side then turned for another 20 mins (reduced heat slightly after turning). Bone in thighs, no skin and cooked to perfection.

text:
This was very good, but I did change it a bit, so 4 stars instead of 5.  I used only 1/3 cup brown sugar, and it was plenty, and I added about 2 tbsps fresh minced ginger and 3 garlic cloves.  I used lower sodium soy (less than the recipe called for), and 1/4 cup water.  Like other reviewers, I covered the pan with foil for 30 minutes and took off the foil for the last 30.  The chicken and sauce came out delicious--the chicken was tender and flavorful, and the sauce thick, tangy, and caramelized.    I'll definitely make this again, and I'll use a little less soy next time to mellow the flavor.

text:
I made this last night. I doubled the sauce, but also added about 6 more thighs (6 people, plus leftovers). I used boneless, skinless thighs, therefore, you don't have to cook as long. I cooked 30 minutes (turning at 15 and removing some of the juices, and adding more marinade, as mentioned in some of the reviews, and then broiling for 10 minutes). I used the low sodium soy sauce, which everyone recommended. I also didn't add as much ginger as it called for, as I wasn't sure I would like it - but I did. The sauce took a bit to get thick on the sauce pan and it didn't get too thick on the meat, but it was still delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for the family last night and it was AMAZING!  We have another chicken teriyaki recipe that we enjoy that is made in the crockpot but this recipe beat that one hands down.  After the meal we all rated it on a scale of 1 to 10 and all 5 of us that ate it gave it a 10.  The best part was that it was super simple and pretty common ingredients.  I doubled the sauce as per recommendations but I also  did about 1/2 again as much meat.  For the doubled recipe I used 2 tsp. fresh ginger and 4 cloves of garlic and I used 3/4 c. white sugar and 1/4 c. brown sugar.  I also used 1/2 soy sauce and 1/2 coconut amino acids.  When I tasted the sauce before brushing the meat and baking it I was skeptical, it was very vinegary and I am not a huge fan of vinegar but we decided to try it anyway and we are so glad we did.  This will definitely be a new family favorite that we make regularly.

I  used 4 large Chicken thighs  and made the sauce exactly as recipe stated. I did baste the thighs every 15mins and did NOT turn them over. They had a beautiful glazed color. I used the rest of the sauce in the pan and sauteed some green onions, mushrooms and carrots and then mixed that with some cooked Chinese noodles. Or you could use rice if you prefer. I served the  chicken thigh over the noodles and it looked and smelled great.     The chicken fell off the bone, was very juicy and tasted great! Will definitely make it again!

text:
Delicious! I always read reviews before making any meals, so I made double the recipe, used low-sodium soy sauce, and cut back on the sugar (used a little over 1/2 cup since I doubled the recipe.) I also used 4 skinless chicken breasts, poured all the sauce on top, left uncovered, and baked at 375 for 30 minutes. The chicken was already cooked, maybe a little dry but there was plenty of sauce to moisten it up.:) At first it sounded like way too much pepper and I thought it was a misprint, but since none of the reviews mentioned too much pepper I went with it. Glad I did cos I think that's part of what makes this so good! Definitely my favorite teriyaki sauce to date and will certainly use again. Will probably try it with shrimp too. I finished off the meal with a side of sautéed onions, mushrooms, zucchini and yellow squash. Great meal!

Thank you for this easy and excellent recipe. All 5 of my kids and husband enjoyed it. The only changes I made were to double the sauce recipe, and I seasoned the chicken with salt, pepper, and garlic before I poured the sauce over the chicken. I rolled the chicken pieces in the sauce, covered the pan with foil, and baked for 30 minutes. I flipped the chicken and cooked for 30 more minutes. Then, I uncovered the chicken and cooked for ten more minutes. I served it with steamed white rice and steamed veggies.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2016-11-22T02:25:55.16

text:
This is a great recipe.  I sub 6 chicken breasts, usually use mirin instead of the apple cider vinegar (because my husband likes a sweeter teriyaki--this is very good with the cider vinegar), and cook it in the oven covered with aluminum foil for about 30 minutes.  I put all the sauce on first, slather it all over the chicken, then turn it over half way through the cooking time.  We eat it with jasmine rice, and I have sesame seeds with mine.

I altered the recipe a bit I subed 1\2 the sugar foe slenda did nor had cider vinigar so I used balsamic vinegar 1\4 cup then made up the right amount with white vinegar crushed garlic not clove then I put in crushed garlic, ginger and chilli all in one jar cooked as directed I also subed the meat for pork ribs then put the sauce on every 10 mins after 1\2 and draining the liquid from pan

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
the only changes I made were using brown sugar, added a splash of orange juice to the sauce, and used chicken legs (that's what I had). So many reviews suggest putting all the sauce on at the beginning but by  brushing throughout cooking adds the layers and builds the sauce on the chicken through cooking. I did not cover - I was a little worried at first - but everything turned out wonderful. served with rice seasoned with turmeric. I had exactly enough sauce that still was sauce-y enough to put on the rice. My rice hating husband went back for seconds just to put the sauce on the rice. He even swiped the last piece of chicken from me

userID:
18211245
Display Name:
Ribs
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
216
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Flavourful! 
As others suggested, I used low sodium soy sauce. Halfed sugar and used a mix of brown and white sugar. Others suggested to double sauce but I found I had too much left over when I did that.
Marinate meat. Used 4 large chicken breasts cut in thirds.
375* for 20 mins each side. Baste every 10mins. 
Pan cleans up well if I soak immediately once I remove chicken. 
Next time I won't bake on cookie sheet but in a medium/small casserole dish. One a cookie sheet it gets ever so slightly dry, so I rather have chicken cook closer together in the sauce. 

Next time:
Can use sauce on chicken, beef, pork or salmon (for fish bake less, until it flakes)

text:
Mods that I made:  Based on feedback from this recipe and others...I reduced white sugar to 1/4c and added 1/8c brown sugar, added red, green and orange bell peppers, an extra onion, fresh snow peas, water chestnuts, can of pineapple chunks (drained) and a splash of white wine.  I quadrupled the sauce, and used four large chicken breasts...cut into bite-sized pieces.  Baked off in two 9x13 baking pans.  We had enough for 8-10 servings over rice.  It was delicious!  Next time, I'll reduce the sugar even a bit more, use even more veggies - maybe thin sliced carrots (softened in micro first), or toss in some steamed broccoli or fresh spinach at the end.  Everyone loved it!

userID:
3290039
Display Name:
Elise Morris
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
28
favoritesCount:
135
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6052093.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so so good! I doubled the ginger and garlic in the sauce. Used half brown sugar and half white sugar. I think you could (and should) cut down on the sugar a little bit (maybe only 3/8 cup), but it was good! I also did about 5-6 shakes of red pepper flakes! I only had 6 boneless chicken thighs so I made this recipe as stated but with only half the amount of chicken. (Essentially doubling the sauce).  If you made this with 12 thighs then you would need to double the sauce for sure so you could have a little leftover to pour over veggies or rice! Also because there was more sauce I believe there is absolutely no need to baste every 10 min.  I just lined the entire pan in heavy duty aluminum foil and then covered the thighs with foil while they cooked (following directions on cook time of 60 min and also turning the thighs over after 30 min). SO much easier this way! Another tip: Make sure you cook the thighs (or whatever you use) whole and THEN slice them up. Don't slice before you bake, so that they will remain juicy!  I am thinking I will be making this regularly in our house! Thanks for a DELICIOUS recipe!

text:
Made this last night for the second time and it was much better than the first time I made it. I followed the ingredients but doubled the sauce. Reserve some sauce in a separate bowl in case you want to add extra sauce to the cooked chicken when serving it.
Instead of brushing the sauce on the chicken, I dipped each piece of chicken into the sauce, put them on the pan, then covered the chicken with one layer of foil. I baked the chicken (without brushing additional sauce) for 30 minutes, flipped the chicken, brushed on more sauce (just this one time), uncovered it and baked for 30 minutes. It turned out juicy, delicious, and tender!

text:
Fabulous! I always use low sodium soy sauce so I used it here. I followed the recipe (doubled the sauce) but used squeeze ginger instead of ground and took the advice of other reviewers and used brown sugar instead of white. I also had the idea of adding 2 T. of frozen OJ just to give it that "orange chicken" or "General's chicken"kind of flavor. Amazing! Cooked 6 thighs in the oven covered with foil. 400 degrees for 25 minutes. Served with rice and broccoli. Will definitely do again, so tasty and so easy.

text:
This was very, very good! I made it for my son and his family and served it with rice and a veg and salad. I doubled the chicken and quadrupled the sauce and had lots left over to put into the freezer for another meal for my hubby and I. It was very easy and yet bursting with flavour. I think it's worth it to use the fresh ginger and maybe add a bit more than called for according to your taste. If it doesn't thicken quite to your liking add a bit more cornstarch and thicken it on the stove. No worries! Just remember to add more cornstarch to the recipe next time you make it.

text:
I make this recipe every couple weeks! I make with the ingredients as the recipe says, dip my chicken thighs (6-8) in the sauce, put them in a foil lined 8x8 and dump the remaining sauce over it. Bake for about 45 mins. I serve it with broccoli and rice. It's a win every time!

Pretty close to perfect. The only change I made was I used 1/3 brown sugar instead of the white sugar. I prefer brown sugar for marinades and sauces. I baked 4 boneless thighs at 400 degrees for 25 minutes. I think I'll try to adapt this for a stir fry next time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy recipe and great alternative for bottled Teriyaki sauce.

Definetly use aluminum foil to line the roasting dish for easy clean up.  Will use double or triple layers next time,  it tore when I turned the chicken.

Changes made were:  1/2 cup of white sugar , fresh ground ginger and low sodium soy sauce. After cooking it and getting it slightly thick,  I pored it all on the chicken.  I made a  combination of  chicken thighs and boneless chicken breasts  since my son likes chicken cutlet only.  Next time will try using the sauce to cook the breasts on the stovetop to avoid overcooking as thighs are perfect at receipes cooking temp but breast weren't but that was my mistake.  The thighs were fantastic! 

Once The chicken was cooked I poured the sauce from the rosting pan into a pot and cooked until reduced to a thicker consistency and pured on the chicken.  

Can't wait to make the sauce again and try it on salmon & shrimp!

text:
This is the second time I made this recipe. Followed it as written, with the exception of the sugar. I only used 1/4 cup. It was terrific again! I did leave the skin on a few of the thighs and thought I would crisp them in the broiler, it didn't work out and they are so flavorful without the skin, I wont bother again. Having covered the chicken for the first 30 minutes, there was a lot of juice, I removed the chicken and poured the juice into a saucepan. I cooked it down and bit to thicken and used it to pour over the rice that I made with this dish. Very good, quick and easy recipe with wonderful results.

text:
Boyfriend and kids loved this! I followed the recipe exactly except I only had 6 chicken thighs, and had just enough sauce for the chicken and a couple of sausage links (see note below), so I definitely recommend doubling the recipe if you're making 12 thighs.

I didn't have as much chicken on hand as I thought, so I also basted a couple of hot Italian sausage links with the sauce, and that got rave reviews as well. The sweet and spicy together were a great combo!

I used skinless boneless chicken thighs and covered with a loose layer of aluminium foil on top to prevent burning/drying out.

text:
Wow!  I will definitely make this again.   I was amazed at how much my child of 'discerning taste' :) enjoyed this - she kept asking for more!  I did double the sauce, and ended up with plenty left over. 
I did change a few things (some of which were based on earlier reviews).  I had chicken tenders on hand, which were cut in half.  I used half brown sugar, half white sugar.  After preparing the sauce, I dropped the chicken pieces in the saucepan and coated them all before dumping the whole thing into my foil-lined pan.  Baked it  covered at 375 for 15 mins, turned the pieces over, then baked it (still covered) for another 15 mins.
But I am rating this based on 1) how much my family liked it and 2) how easy this was to prepare.
Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I've made this twice now; first time I made it with extra ginger and garlic, second time I used organic sucanat (dehydrated sugar cane juice). Both times it was excellent, though you won't need the cornstarch and water when you use sucanat. The heat will caramelize the cane juice sugar allowing the sauce to thicken quickly over the stove.

Display Name:
imrachel

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! I doubled the sauce and it was the perfect amount. To cut calories I used Splenda-- 1/4 cup of the brown sugar blend (for the doubled amount) and a little less than 1/4 cup of the white Splenda for baking. I also used 2/3 c. of reduced sodium soy sauce instead of the 1 c. of regular and 3 cloves of garlic.
For the chicken I used 3 (2 lb. total) large boneless skinless chicken breasts cut in half so I had 6 smaller pieces. I poked holes in the chicken with a fork and covered with half of the sauce. I baked for about 18 min at 375 deg then poured off the chicken juices flipped the chicken, covered with the remaining sauce and baked for another 12-15 min. I served with brown rice and steamed broccoli. It came out perfect and there was plenty of sauce left in the baking dish.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a 4 star dish, but it is a 5 star dish (DELICIOUS) with modifications. I used lite soy sauce AND cut it in half. I also used 1T fresh ginger, minced, for the ground ginger. That gave it the zing that really put it over the top. I used less sugar than it called for (about 3/4 the amount), and substituted brown sugar for half of that. The sauce was absolutely fantastic with these modifications, but it really needed to be doubled for our tastes.

Also, the chicken ended up swimming in water. I'd either bake it most of the way and then drain it BEFORE putting on the sauce OR put it on a greased rack to bake. 

With those modifications, this would be wonderful! We served it over rice with steamed veggies and a salad.

A lot of reviewers said to half the amount of sugar but I tasted it and felt I needed to add more but not the whole amount. Since I doubled the sauce, I used 1/2 c. brown sugar and 1/4 c. white sugar. I lined my pan with heavy duty foil then poured most of the thickened sauce over bone-in thighs (skin removed) and some boneless breasts but reserved a little. Cooked, covered with foil for 30 minutes, removed foil, poured remainder of sauce over and bake another 20-30 minutes. Wow. Really good!

Display Name:
NoOnions

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5973352.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You do NOT need to double the sauce. I repeat! Do NOT double sauce.  You aren't poaching the chicken, it is just for brushing!  DO NOT DOUBLE!  I did and I have more than twice as much as I need. Changes:  Always use light soy sauce or it is just way over powering.  I added a bit of orange juice, because we like that, and I cut the sugar by 25%. All Teriyaki recipes have equal soy and sugar, so there must be a reason...but still I cut it.  And I did use brown sugar.  I also added about a TBS of sesame seeds, because I had them. The sauce can't be used for gravy, it is far too intense.  It's like 30x concentrated.  Maybe because I accidently had regular soy and not light.  But, generally speaking, I liked the recipe, my kids ate it and I will make it again (Since I have all this sauce left)  Oh. I baked 45 mins at 400 and brushed sauce every 15.  For the last 15 I poured out all the residual liquid, and kicked up to 425....good browning of the sauce then. (we like dry chicken...I know, but hey)

text:
My family really enjoyed this dish. An important thing I noted was to mix the cornstarch and water before adding to the sauce. I used a little less sugar, almost 1/2 C; regular soy sauce; 2 garlic cloves, but could have used another. I wanted to used fresh ginger, but ran short on time and used powder. It was still good. As someone else suggested, I poured most of the sauce over the thighs (bone up), covered and baked 30 min. Then I removed the cover, turned the chicken and poured the remaining sauce on and baked for another 20 min.  It was very good with a side of stir fried veggies.

text:
Made some basic changes based on other reviews here ( used breasts pounded and cut into 1/3rds, baked at 350 for 30 min, doubled the sauce).  I always use low sodium soy, so also made that substitution.

I'd like to see more of a crisp or carmelization of the sauce on the chicken.  Next time I might try brushing the tops of the breasts with sauce, and searing them a bit for color.

Flavor was good, we both liked it.  BF commented on how nice the presentation was - rice, chicken, a drizzle of extra sauce, and a sprinkle of green onions with a side of carrots, shrooms, and onions sauteed in sesame oil and naan.

Nice simple meal for a work night!  I'll make it again, for sure.

I was cooking for only my husband and myself, so I just threw our two chicken breasts on our little indoor grill to cook them. But I made the sauce per this recipe, and it was great! text:
I doubled the sauce and had more than enough.  I used a whole cut-up chicken (we raise our own) and it filled a big roaster pan.  Our birds are big! (6-7 # dressed) This made dinner for 2, another dinner for 2 and 2 lunches with rice, broccoli and carrot salad.  Yumm!!

I did not have any ginger, so I used Chinese 5-Spice in the sauce.  Great flavor.  This recipe is a keeper, and pretty quick to make.  My bird took about 1 1/2 hours, but just because of the size and some of the pieces were not completely thawed.  I did not baste, but just turned the pieces every 20 minutes.
