text:
Great recipe.  I use tamari sauce rather than soy sauce so that it's gluten free.  I double the recipe, skip the water, and  make the sauce a day ahead of time so I can marinate the chicken (thighs or breasts both work fine) in the sauce for a day before baking.  I also don't cover the pan with foil as I want the sauce to thicken slightly as it cooks.  I serve this with rice to soak up the extra sauce.  I get requests to make this dish!  Thanks Marian!

text:
Good recipe but a little too salty. Next time I will use light soya sauce as I didn't have any this time. I ended up using 1/4 cup white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar instead of all white. After the sauce thickened I tasted it and was too salty so I added 1/4 cup water and a tbsp more brown sugar and tasted a lot better. I also switched out 4 boneless skinless chicken breasts(cut into halves) instead of the thighs, spread in a 13x9 dish and poured all the sauce on top. Covered with foil and baked at 400* for 35 minutes. Served over rice. The husband loved it!

text:
This was outstanding. My husband (the ultimate grill master) is against baking chicken, says there is no way to do without it coming out dry - this recipe changed his mind.  I followed the recipe exactly (did not double the sauce like many said - don't do it - you are just making it unhealthier, it's not necessary) and it came out fantastic.  I did cook at a lower heat with foil on for the first half hour. Did not have the issues that others did with the pan being any harder to clean than normal (but I bet that's because they doubled the sauce and/or didn't grease the pan enough). THE FLAVOR of this dish is outstanding. It took awhile for the sauce to thicken, but it was worth it and I will make it again.

I doubled the sauce, I used fresh ginger and some crushed red pepper for heat, marinated chicken in it for 6 hours. It was not thick 
put chicken in long pan with foil on the bottom .
Boiled the sauce as I marinated the chicken in it. 
It took around 20 min's and than thicken. Than cooked the chicken with some of the thick sauce. TIME IS WAY OFF ON SAUCE
 I cooked it on 400 for 30 min's half way I turned the chicken and put more sauce on
Than at the end of 30 min's put the oven on boil to get them nice and brown.To me, this was the key.

text:
This was sooo very good. The only thing I did differently is that i  pureed a pint of my fresh canned pineapple grown here in hawaii. There is a difference in how the pineapple tastes here than on the mainland. I would never use canned pineapple unless it is canned fresh at home. If you are able to get a whole pineapple where you live then just puree approx 1/4th of it. You will be amazed! Everything ele i followed the directions to a T. The natural fresh sweetness from the pineapple fixed the saltiness of the soy!

userID:
2243724
Display Name:
Janey81
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
134
favoritesCount:
441
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good! When I first made this a few weeks ago, I made it just as written and it turned out great, but I thought it was a little tedious basting so often. To simplify the cooking process on my second go around, I went ahead and prepared the sauce (do not cook it) and set aside, then took the chicken thighs and cut into small pieces. I cooked the chicken in two batches using about 1 tsp oil until the chicken had a nice golden color and was slightly crisp on the outside. After all the chicken was cooked, I put it all in the pan together and started adding in little bit of the sauce each time and stirring until it caramalized. Perhaps this method sounds more tedious but actually it's pretty simple and cut the cooking time in half. I also halved the sugar to 1/4 cup and used brown sugar instead. This recipe is a winner and this is one I would be proud to serve to our guests for dinner!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-10-08T08:40:51.797
helpfulCount:

userID:
16128509
Display Name:
Romen
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The SO didn't say this was the best chicken I had ever made; he said it was the best he had ever eaten! What I think is important is that the recipe was written for bone in thighs. While, of course, it can be adapted to any cut, as soon as you change that you must change time and temperature. The temperature is so high (425) because you are supposed to baste every ten minutes. Opening the oven this often results in the necessity of a higher temp. I set my timer in ten minute increments, basting each time and flipping after 30 minutes. The results were flavorful, tender, and juicy. People who lowered the oven temperature (and used a bone-in cut) couldn't possibly have followed the technique of basting in the recipe because the chicken wouldn't have cooked thoroughly. You thought it was tasty before? Try it the way it was written! Yum!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-09-09T19:08:35.37

text:
A winner!  I used low sodium soy sauce. Double the sauce, but instead of doubling the white sugar, I used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar.  I lined my pan with heavy duty foil then poured most of the thickened sauce over bone-in thighs (skin removed). Cooked, covered with foil for 30 minutes, removed foil, poured remainder of sauce over and bake another 20-30 minutes.

I thought this had a great taste! A little tangy for me but my family loved it. I doubled the recipe and used a few chicken breasts cut up into strips. Then I just mixed the sauce with the chicken strips in the baking dish.  I was being lazy and didn't want to have to do a lot of brushing, turning etc. Cooked it one hr at 400 and BAM.....happy family! My mother in law tasted it and said it was the best she ever had. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was pretty tasty and 4 of my 5 kids ate it, which is a big deal in this house. My husband said it was so so, which is not unusual for him. The recipe called for 12 skinless thighs but I used 9 legs and removed the skin before cooking. The flavor was good but the meat wasn't "fall off the bone". I think this could be remedied by cooking the chicken in the crockpot for 4-6 hrs and THEN baking for 30 min, basting with the glaze every 10 min. The original recipe calls for baking 30 min, basting every 10, then turn over and repeat for another 30 min. It's an easy recipe but not one to make last minute.

text:
"Killer over the top" was my husband's comment. I would give it a six if I could. I followed the recipe but followed some of the review suggestions. I doubled the sauce (thank goodness!!), used 1/2 c. brown sugar, and because I had so much sauce, I layered 1/2 of the sauce onto my foil-lined pan, put in the thighs, then poured the rest of the sauce over it. I don't like cleaning my brush. I cooked at 375 degrees, skin side up, for 30 minutes, turned it, cooked it 20 minutes skin side down, then turned it for 20 more minutes. It was beautiful!!!!! Thank you so much. ~ Linda

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will admit, I was a bit skeptical about this recipe at first. As I began cooking the sauce,I honestly thought it smelled horrible. But as it turned out, it tasted FANTASTIC! I used 1/4c. white sugar and a little less than 1/4c. brown sugar as another reviewer suggested. I also put foil on the pan for easy clean up, and covered it for half an hour and uncovered the other half hour. I basted both sides of the thighs before i put them in, again after a half hour, then after 15 minutes, and then when I took them out. I served it with homemade garlic mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli. Turned out awesome, and everyone loved it! Definitly a keeper!

text:
Excellent flavor and extremely juicy!  I lowered the temp to 375 and doubled the sauce.  I reduced the sauce just a bit and then poured part over the chicken before covering and baking for 15 minutes.  I finished reducing the remaining sauce, uncovered the chicken and basted every 5-10 minutes for another half hour or so.  Great recipe to make a very inexpensive cut of chicken into a wonderful meal!

text:
I triple the sauce,  throw it all into a skillet  and mix it.  I turn it on medium low, Then after I cut up 6 boneless skinless chicken breast into bite size pieces I toss it in to the bubbling sauce and let it simmer until the meat is cooked.  I serve this with 3 Cups white rice a bag of steamed veggies and a box of Tai pei spring rolls. Everyone loves it !

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy and really good. I was not willing to bake for an hour because we were really hungry so I browned the chicken and then mixed the sauce in a measuring cup and brought it to a boil and simmered it with the chicken until the chicken was cooked. The sauce was nice and thick and there was plenty to serve over the chicken, rice I made and there will was extra sauce for leftovers. Instead of thighs I cooked up about eight chicken tenderloins because that's what I had. That's probably why I had so much sauce but I like extra sauce for rice and so my leftovers aren't dry. If you're using breasts or tenderloins this is plenty of sauce for 8-10 tenderloins or equivalent chicken breasts and rice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very good and easy. Chicken stays juicy and flavorful. You could really tweak the sauce any way you want. I used boneless chicken breasts, poured the sauce over top and baked it at 400 degrees for 35-40 minutes, basting every so often. I also add a about a 1/4 cup of apple juice to the sauce and use half soy sauce, half water instead of the full amount of soy sauce. If there are more than 3 chicken breasts, I double the sauce. Serve with rice and snap peas.

text:
This recipe is wonderful!!! The teriyaki sauce is incredible. I used low sodium soy sauce, and two chicken hind quarters I had at hand. I removed the skin and deboned them. Baked them in the toaster oven for 30 minutes, basting and turning half way through. I served it with rice and a side of green beans with vinagrette. I added a few drops of sesame oil to the left over sauce and refrigerated it for future use. Both, my husband and son asked me to make this dish more frequently.

text:
I used the same recipe except with brown sugar instead of white and 3 tbs flour instead of cornstarch. I also only used 4 chicken thighs instead of twelve. There is lots of sauce to go around and because it basically surrounds the meat I only flip it at 30 mins and don't have to check in on it and it comes out perfectly. The only thing I would say is maybe marinate the chicken in this over night cause the outside was flavorful but the insides were a bit bland.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so great! I am not much of a teriyaki fan but my husband loves it so I decided to give it a shot! I am very pleased with the result and the ability to customize the flavor.

I doubled the sauce, as suggested, and only used brown sugar. I did use low sodium soy sauce, as well. I poured most of the sauce over boneless breast tenderloins. I baked them in a foil covered dish at 375 for 30 minutes, flipped them over, and poured on the rest of the sauce and baked for another 15 minutes. I turned the broiler on for about 5 minutes to caramelized the top a bit, too.

I served this with fried rice and broccoli and it was so yummy and so easy!! I have a new perspective on teriyaki thank you!!

I thought it was good. My husband thought it was great. My three-year-old ate it--WITHOUT KETCHUP--so I'm deeming this one a hit. I assume you could find a bottled version of the sauce but it would probably have a billion preservatives in it so I like to make my own. 
The sauce that touched the sides of the pan burned and made my kitchen smell something awful, but the sauce on the chicken and that we used to coat the chicken was delicious and not burned at all. 
We don't eat ANY sugar at all and so I used honey instead. But other than that, I stuck to the recipe exactly.

region:

country:
None
text:
We cooked this last evening.  I used boneless skinless thighs.  I doubled the sauce recipe and I used about a one and a half inch piece of fresh ginger which I minced.  I also doubled the garlic.  Like other reviewers, I used 1/2 white sugar and 1/2 brown sugar.  I cooked the sauce for a few minutes in a saucepan to blend all ingredients, then put half the sauce in a crockpot with the chicken thighs.  I cooked it for 5 hours on high. It was watery, so I removed the chicken with a slotted spoon, served on top of brown rice with a side of stir fried vegetables.  I ladled the remaining sauce (which was now very thick) on top of the chicken and garnished with chopped scallions.  There was a lot of food on the serving plate and it was totally gone!  This is probably the BEST teriyaki recipe I've ever had!  My husband loved it!  I'm a very picky eater, everything I eat has to be very flavorful and robust and the recipe really fit the bill!  I think everyone would love this and you will never ever want bottled Terriyaki sauce again!

userID:
4259406
Display Name:
Janis
isPro:
False

32

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time yesterday. As always, when making a recipe for the first time, I followed it exactly-well almost exactly.  I truly intended to, but forgot the vinegar & didn't realize it until I was putting the chicken in the oven. I also accidentally used my 1/3 measuring cup for the sugar instead of my 1/2 cup & put the sauce on the chicken all at once. I inadvertently marinated it for 30 minutes as I was distracted by being on the phone and/or got confused by reading so many different reviews. 

I used regular soy sauce & we did not find it salty at all. I didn't  salt the breasts. It was a little sweet but I am sure if I had added the vinegar it would have cut that down.

In any case the sauce was really good, I love the stickiness of the glaze and will definitely make it again but double the sauce. I am sure that if I pay attention & follow it exactly it will be perfect next time. I did sprinkle with sesame seeds as a garnish but don't consider that changing a recipe. Definitely line the pan with foil!

My oven is convection & bakes a bit hotter than normal.  When I set the temperature at 425 it automatically dropped to 400 so that is what I cooked them at. I used two skinless, boneless breasts that were quite large so I cut them in half lengthwise. I turned them over & basted at 10 minutes & then again at 20 minutes.  Chicken was done at 30 minutes & very juicy. Enough for two people & still had one piece of breast left over.

Thanks for sharing Marian!

text:
VERY good and a hit with the kids! I stuck very close to the recipe ingredients but I did use 1+ tsp grated fresh ginger (powdered ginger is better for baked goods like gingerbread). I also used boneless chicken thighs and a BLSL breast to keep the calories lower for me. Using boneless cut the cook time in half. The chicken thighs were more flavorful and moister than the breasts. This was a very easy recipe to make- a keeper!

country:
None
text:
Love this recipe!  The chicken turned out really juicy and tender, not dry at all like baked chicken often is for me.  I used boneless skinless breasts cut into large pieces, and per some of the reviews here, I baked at 375 for 20 minutes, flipped them over, then 20 more minutes (basting along the way).  I also broiled for a few minutes at the end to brown them a bit.  I also doubled the sauce, and reserved some to use over rice and broccoli (though there's enough at the bottom of the pan to use that way, too).  Delicious with steamed broccoli!

This really is a great recipe!  I used 12 boneless, skinless chicken breasts and used suggestions from other comments to replace the cider vinegar with pineapple juice and the white sugar with brown sugar.  I also used low sodium soy sauce as that's what I had on hand.  It was very tasty and my kids (3 and 5) loved it!  I doubled the sauce and would do the same next time even with less chicken because it was good as a sauce for rice and extra juice for dipping the chicken in. Thanks for another tasty recipe!!

text:
Made this last night for the family.  Like most of the "most helpful" reviews suggested, I doubled the sauce (using a combo of brown and white sugar).  Hubs said when I had his taste the sauce, "YEP, that's Teriyaki sauce!".  I think next time I'll cut back on the sugar (in the double sauce version) using 1/4 c of white and 1/4 cup of brown. I think I'll also cook down the sauce even more next time.  Once my chicken/sauce done baking (400deg for 30 minutes), I added the contents to a sautee pan, 1 bag of stir fry veg, and stir fried up some rice noodles. Delish!

This is a fantastic recipe! I followed another commenter's advice and subbed real minced ginger for the ground, and added more garlic. I had 6 boneless, skinless chicken thighs that cooked at 425 for 60 mins total (30 mins with foil on top; 30 mins without). I also just dumped the mixture on top and didn't worry about continually glazing it. Turned out perfect! This chicken was so juicy and tender, and the marinade so flavorful that I could not stop eating! Served with basmati rice... it was a real treat!

text:
Delicious! Everyone liked it. I baked 2 split breasts and 2 wings in half the sauce, sans cornstarch, and then added the rest 20 minutes before it was done, basting and turning so the chicken would be thoroughly coated. That way I did't have to wash as many dishes (I didn't cook the sauce on the stove, first). My husband thought it was a tad too sweet, but I thought it was perfect!

text:
The Teriyaki sauce is amazing! We had just had baked chicken the night before, so I ended up cooking the chicken in the skillet, addded a bag of frozen stirfry veggies and made a stir fry with it instead. This was so simple to make and had much more flavor than store bought teriyaki sauce. We are big fans of stirfry, so we have found our new sauce. I did add some extra water (maybe 1/4 cup to the sauce as it had a very strong flavor. I waited to add the extra water over the stirfry and not when the sauce was thickening though.) This was a hit in our house! We will make it again.

text:
It's a perfect recipe as is, but I made two adjustment to make it perfect for the two of us. I tried this first as is with the minced garlic, I just think my mincing skills are sub par because the little pieces of garlic just seemed to stand out against what otherwise would be a perfect meld of ingredients. I found the sauce to be saltier than I would have liked too. So the next time (and all the times afterward) I've used powdered garlic (1/8th teaspoon) and low sodium soy sauce and it is just the most beautiful silky sticky sauce and incredibly delicious!

text:
I've made this a couple of times now and love it! I use 6-7 chicken thighs instead of 12. For the sauce, I omit the tablespoon of water and instead add the grated rind and the juice from half an orange. I make 4 servings of white rice while the chicken is cooking. When the chicken is finished, I remove it from the pan and stir the rice into the sauce. I then serve the chicken on top of the rice and top each serving with some sliced green onions.

I just lived this recipe and it truly was delicious!! I did like a reviewer before me had and added 1/4c of white sugar and 1/2c of brown sugar. I didn't have any clove garlic so I substituted it with simply garlic powder.My plan was to put half into the pot with chicken and the other half during its duration, but I ended up, by mistake pouring it in there all @ once. My bf rarely eats a lot of chicken but it really liked it and even had it for breakfast the next day. Great recipe indeed. Thank you

text:
I have a hard time finding yummy allergy free food that me and my family can eat.  Fortunately this was one of those delicious recipes I was able to make with one adaptation and it worked exceptionally well for my family.  I am allergic to corn and can not have any of the teriyaki sauces from the store, but this one was better than any sauce I tried.  I substituted the cornstarch with potato starch and it was absolutely delicious.  The entire family enjoyed this dish.  Even my son who is tired of eating chicken enjoyed it.  This recipe is a keeper, thank you Marian!

country:
None
text:
I used only 1/3 cup soy sauce and replaced the 1/2 cup white sugar with 1/2 cup brown sugar.  I boiled it a little longer to make sure the sauce was thick.  I put it over three thinly sliced chicken breasts and baked for 30 minutes altogether, turning at the half-way point to make sure the sauce completely covered the chicken.  Because the sauce was thicker, I wasn't able to baste, but this wasn't a problem.  I found it to be still too salty, but not bad.  Next time, I will cut the soy sauce down to 1/4 cup and see how it goes.

Very yummy and easy! I was lazy and just poured half the sauce on top of the chicken and then cooked for 25 minutes at 375. None
text:
This was delicious!! I served the chicken over white rice.  This recipe made just enough sauce to allow me to put a couple tablespoons of the sauce on the rice which I like to do.   I recommend placing the chicken skin side down first so that when you flip it at the half way point the skin will be up for the last 30 minutes of cooking.  Doing so results in a crisper skin when serving.   Thank you for sharing.

userID:
3801183
Display Name:
Queen Bee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect! I was going to give this 4 stars but I gave it 5 stars just because I'm glad Marian shared this, Thanks. This recipe wasn't flawless but with a little tweaking, it's great. The sauce would have been too salty with the 1/2 cup of soy sauce. No need to run buy low sodium soy, just cut the soy in half and replace the remaining liquid with water. This recipe will turn out tough via the cooking method recommended in this recipe. I personally did not want to stand over chicken and marinate every 10 minutes(this is why it takes so long and ends up tough) so I doubled the sauce to have enough to cover all of my chicken tenders (a WHOLE bag). I put them in a glass dish, covered with foil and baked for 40 minutes at 350 degrees. PERFECT! If you like to have thick glaze on top, save some of the glaze and after baking the chicken, increase oven temp to 425 and take the tenders out of the original dish and place them on a cookie sheet. Brush chicken with glaze and put them in for 5 minutes. Turn chicken and brush marinade on and cook for another 5 minutes. This way they turn out tender and saucy. This recipe is a keeper! My crew cleaned the entire dish!!

I made it a second time just today but used brown sugar instead of white and added a half cup of sliced green onions. Nothing at all wrong with the original but I really liked this recipe when I marinated the meat over night!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was good as a base to build on.  I ended up using a mix of 6 tablespoons dark brown sugar and 2 tablespoons honey instead of white sugar and using rice wine vinegar rather than apple cider vinegar.  I also cut the soy sauce to 6 tablespoons. As far as the preparation was concerned, I blended the soy sauce and sugars and brought them to a simmer.  I created a slurry of 2 Tablespoons cornstarch and 1/4 cup cold water and dumped it into the simmering soy sauce and sugars.  It thickened up nicely and turned out to be an excellent sauce over boneless skinless chicken breasts.

text:
Very nice rendition. There is a suggestion I'd like to make. Use your leftover chicken and finely chop it and make either spring rolls or egg rolls with it. I make Teriyaki meats at intervals and just chop and freeze it then thaw overnight in the fridge and create something else with it. Also don't forget it works wonderfully well in a stir fry or a fried rice. So many ways to keep it Asian style inspired and use this for the week and of course freeze it too!

text:
It was delicious.  My husband, who's very hard to please and often thinks dishes with sugar in them are too sweet, loved this dish and said it was "really great."  I made this with the restaurant style fried rice and some asparagus.  My thighs were boneless and skinless, since that's what they had at Pavillions.  This cut my cooking time in half to a total of 30 minutes.  When i make it next time, I'll drain some of the juices out of the baking pan at the 15 minute mark.

The fact that I always have chicken on hand because it's cheaper and I get bored with eating the same thing all the time, unlike my husband, I'm always looking for recipes and I searched and found this one.  My entire family loved it, especially my youngest, who only likes chicken if it's fried.  The only thing I noticed when preparing the sauce was that it was a little too sweet. text:
This was absolutely delicious. My 6 year old ate everything off of her dinner plate and that's a rare thing. I took the advice and doubled the sauce. I used low sodium soy sauce and it still was a bit salty but not terrible... so please use low sodium. I also used a total of 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 1/4 cup of white sugar for the doubled recipe as recommended by another review. I poured the sauce on one side of the chicken and let it bake for 30 min and then poured the rest on the next side for the remainder of the baking time. I used a Enamelware/graniteware roasting pan. The lid helped to maintain the moisture. This recipe was totally worth it! Thanks!

I absolutely loved this! So did my 1yr old...He had seconds. My husband have it an 8 out of 10. So I made this just like the recipe but used chicken tenders instead of thighs and I cooked it at 375 15 minutes covered, turned the tenders over and cooked 15 more minutes uncovered. Instead of just basting the chicken with the sauce, I poured the sauce in the dish almost submerging the chicken. My sauce never really bubbled or thickened much but it was still delicious!

text:
Amazing! I loved the simplicity of this recipe, especially since my house is very limited with ingredients! I followed the suggestions of other users in using brown sugar instead of white, pouring the sauce over the chicken instead of brushing, and covering the entire pan with foil before placing it in the oven. As a result, the chicken was very moist and the sauce just had the right amount of sweetness. Oh, and it smells wonderful! I can't wait to try this recipe again!!!!

text:
This was a great dish....did make a couple of changes like other reviews. I doubled the recipe and on a skillet simmered 3 leg quarters. I used less than half of the vinegar since that is very strong. I stay with the amount of sugar for one recipe but used regular dark soy sauce.  Next time I will take the advise of low sodium soy sauce since it was a bit on the salty side. instead of cooking the sauce first I decided to marinate the chicken in the sauce for about 2hrs. I did have to add more corn starch at the end since it does come out kinda watery.  Will try again with some modifications.

text:
We have used this recipe on every kind of meat, pork ribs marinated and basted on the bbq, chicken breasts and thighs done casserole style, meatballs in the crock pot, even chicken thighs marinated, basted over the fire....yum! It's always a hit with our family of 6, its a quick easy weeknight dish! We always double the sauce, use whatever kind of vinegar we have in the cupboard and use fresh grated ginger to enhance the ginger taste. I've passed this recipe onto family and friends and it's become a regular in all households.

text:
Hubby is a picky eater, but liked this okay. I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts and followed the instructions for the recipe, only baking about 45 mins instead of the full hour. It was good, but just didn't wow us. Great for a go-to meal, if you have the time to baste the chicken every 10 minutes like the recipe calls for. If not, I would either marinate the chicken in this sauce over night, and pour over the chicken and cover it with aluminum foil while baking, or skip this recipe altogether.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was super easy to make, and the family loved it. I couldn't image not doubling the sauce, its a must. I served the chicken with a fried rice and french bread. It made an amazing dipping sauce. My only concern was how spicy it turned out. I used fresh ground black pepper. Next time I may cut it in 1/2 but the family likes the extra heat. I also added 1/4c pineapple juice. I cooked at 375 for the 1st 20 mins then put the temperature to 425 to finish it off. The chicken came out so moist and delicious. I cant wait to make it again!

text:
THE best teriyaki chicken recipe - period. No need to look further. I never knew it was this easy and simple to make such a delicious teriyaki sauce. It could easily be restaurant quality taste! I have made this at least 10 times now and it is always a hit. Children love it as well as adults. It's so easy to double, triple the recipe, that I once made it for my son's 4th birthday party for about 20 kids and they just kept coming back for more. I had Moms asking for how to make it and some though it was restaurant bought! The only thing I don't necessarily put in is the ginger - only because I don't always have it on hand, and it still turns out great. It's definitely one of my staple recipes that I can whip up if there's a small gathering that's easy, but doesn't look or taste like a half- @**ed dish, but one that took effort!

i put this in the crockpot. i added two cups of water, tripled the cornstarch/water mixture, plus added flour. i wanted lots of thick sauce.
i doubled all of the spices and added onion powder, garlic powder, and minced garlic.
i also used brown sugar instead of white, i like the taste of brown sugar better!
because it was in the crockpot the chicken shredded instead of just one piece, but it was really good. 
i've made this a few times and love it!

text:
Great for the whole family!  I made this stove-top rather than in the oven.  Just a little olive oil in a large saute pan over medium to high heat.  Browned both sides, then turned the heat to medium.  Added more sauce as in the directions for baked, then added the rest of the sauce at the end to heat it with the chicken before serving.  Agree with other reviewers that you need to double the sauce. I made the sauce as per the instructions, but had half the number of chicken thighs. Easy and delicious.

text:
I tried this recipe because I had gotten the hindquarters really cheap... and wasn't sure what to do with them. The only thing that I had issues with is the baking temp and time! I started out at 375 with the chicken covered by foil. I let it go 30 minutes and then uncovered it... and let it go another 30 minutes. It still was not done. I bumped up the temp to the 425 and let it go another 15 minutes and it was finally done.  I think the next time I make this... I will do what the original recipe called for. Oh yeh, I will also use low sodium soy since I could hardly bend my fingers they were so swelled in the morning. :) Really Yummy!

This was possibly the best teriyaki I've ever had. The meat was moist and fork tender, and the sauce had substance. My boyfriend said it was as good as any restaurant would serve. The only thing I did differently was to reduce the temp to 375, and it took 40 minutes to cook (I used boneless thighs.) I also broiled it for 3-4 minutes at the end to make the glaze really stick. Next time, the only thing I would change would be to use reduced sodium soy sauce.

Good basic recipe - it was a little heavy on the salt and ginger for my taste.  I will use less ginger, lite soy sauce and some sesame seeds next time.  Other than that the chicken was tender, tasty and made a great lunch the next day.  I did use boneless/skinless chicken breasts because I don't like dark meat and cooked for less time.  Hubby and kids liked it as well.

text:
This recipe has the capability to become a great mainstay teriyaki sauce. The cider vinegar in here makes it different, & gives it some excellent tang. 

I felt it had too much sugar, although if I had grilled it I think it would have helped the sugar in the sauce to burn out more and reduce the sweetness. Next time I use it for baking, I'm planning on reducing the sugar to a couple tbsp. The recipe as it comes is still really good, it should just be used sparingly over any steamed rice or veggie sides

I took this recipe pretty much straight, the only changes was I used brown sugar instead of white and increased the garlic as per taste. I also used bone in breasts instead of thighs. I basted it about every ten minutes and had it in the oven at 375 for 40 minutes. The only thing that kept it from a 5 star recipe is this tastes more like a rib glaze then something you'd put on chicken, although it was pretty good. I would use it for ribs not chicken.

userID:
1942734
Display Name:
Heather
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tripled the sauce so I would have some left over for a marinade. I used a mix of brown and white sugar, using more brown than white. !/4 cup less soy sauce, 1/2 tsp. chili sauce for heat and I used boneless skinless thighs. I also added extra crushed garlic. Basting every 10 min seemed like a pain and a heat waster so instead I just poured the sauce on the chicken. I coated it well and just turned a couple of times during cooking. It cooked in less time due to no bones and no loss of heat from the oven. The chicken was tender and moist. I served over jasmine rice, poured some additional sauce from the pan, and topped with chopped cilantro. The unused sauce that I didn't put in the oven I put  in the fridge to use as a marinade for pork later in the week. My family loved it and so did I!! This has already been requested again and for birthday dinners as well. Thank you for submitting this recipe!!

I wanted to make a terikayi sauce to use on pre-cooked chicken strips. This recipe was perfect, I had this in a chicken teriyaki sandwich wrap. Delicious. country:
None
text:
Very very VERY good! Great flavor and everyone loved it! Brushing it with the sauce every ten minutes caused the flavor to soak through really nicely. I give it 5 stars for presentation too. Would be a great recipe to serve to guests. Just cook the chicken presentation side down first, use the juices the chicken cooked in as a sauce, and sprinkle with Italian Parsley as a garnish! The only changes I made was I used Blue Agave all natural sweetener instead of the sugar. The ratio of sweetener to sugar is 1:1 but I used about 3/4 c. sweetener instead of just 1/2 c. Also the chicken only needed 30 minutes on one side and about 15-20 minutes on the other and it came out perfectly juicy and tender! I will definitely keep this recipe and make often! *To prevent the burnt mess in the pan, coat the WHOLE pan with a good layer of butter.

Absolutely the best flavor ever. Reason for the low rating-i ruined one of my best pans with the impossible to remove thick black mess this left behind. I soaked the pan immediately afterwards for 3 days, still wouldn't come out. Would have been nice for the recipe to mention putting foil down first for inexperienced cooks like me. I used light soy sauce as well, simmered everything until the chicken was placed in pan then just poured it all on.

text:
One of my favorite recipes when I need a tasty meal requiring no marinating time.  The sauce is so thick and yummy that it easily coats each piece of chicken.   I usually use party wings and chicken breast sliced into strips.  It takes 30-40 minutes at 425 to bake since the size of my chicken pieces are smaller.  I do double the sauce recipe but am usually left with a lot left over.  I reserve some for dipping (the kids like this).   For a quick meal serve this chicken with rice, steamed broccoli, and sliced tomatoes.  It's a hit each time even with my 8 and 5 year olds.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is wonderful! I made both thighs and chicken breast in the same dish. The secret I think is to baste the chicken first with somewhat liquidy sauce and then cover it and bake on 425 for 20 min. And then I thickened the sauce with more cornstarch until it became a glaze. I glazed the chicken and then baked for another 45 min, taking it out every so often to flip and glaze again. Last step I broiled the chicken on low for about 3-4 mins.  Made with garlicy mashed red potatoes and it was spectacular. The gravy went perfectly with the mashed potatoes.

text:
I love this recipe. Unlike my previous teriyaki recipe, this one doesn't require marinating, yet the flavor is still just as good.  I didn't have cider vinegar, so i used regular vinegar and added a little less. When the sauce thickened, it was a little strong, but perfect for basting. The left over was too strong to use as a side dipping sauce, so I added water and used flour to thicken it. It came out great. Everyone loved it.

You have got to try this!  I will never buy bottled teriyaki sauce again!!  Changes I made were I used 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar, used lite soy, and added a little red pepper flakes to give it a tiny bit of kick! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent, the best teriyaki I have ever tasted, and it was so easy to make. I doubled the sauce per other reviews, used fresh ginger instead of ground, and boneless skinless thighs. I poured half the sauce on and covered the pan with foil for the first half hour, basting with the same sauce every 10 minutes.  Then I removed the foil, turned them over and started to baste with the other half of the sauce from the pot.  This kept the thighs nice and juicy.  In the future, I think I will marinate the chicken in some of the sauce and then bake it uncovered, basting every 10 minutes like the original. My family was extremely pleased with this one.

Display Name:
melodee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very, very yummy with these changes: Double sauce. (even with small amount of skinless chicken pieces, i.e. drumsticks or thighs) Here's my own take on the sauce: 2 T cornstarch, 2 T water, little less than 1/2 cup white sugar, little less than 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup regular vinegar, 1 full tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp ground ginger, 1/2 tsp black pepper. Pour half the sauce on the chicken and cover and bake half an hour. Uncover, pour rest of sauce on chicken, bake 15 min, then baste chicken with sauce in bottom of pan and bake 15 more minutes. Comes out PERFECT this way! Can use chicken breasts and bake at 400 for half an hour.

text:
This was delicious but I had hoped the flavor would penetrate the thighs more.  I only used 10 thighs because that is what was in the package.  The sauce took about 45 minutes to thicken and I think I will double it the next time.  I only had enough to baste and none at the end for dipping which I like.  I left out the ginger because I didnt have it.  I cooked the boneless thighs covered for 25 minutes at 400 degrees. I drained most of the liquid from the pan, then baked uncovered for an additional 20 minutes at 425 degrees.  They were very juicy.  I served them with Pinapple Fried Rice II from this site.  Yummy!

text:
Love this recipe! So convenient that you can whip up the sauce and get cooking right away - without having to plan for time to marinate like most of the teriyaki recipes on this site. I cut the sugar down a bit based on other reviews, used low-sodium soy sauce, and used 1 T fresh ginger. I also baked at 400 degrees for 1 1/2 hours based on my usual chicken recipe. I let the chicken bake for a half hour and started basting every 20 minutes after that. It turned out perfectly. I have also made this successfully on the grill.

The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that I wished the sauce was thicker.  I'll probably try adding a little more cornstarch next time to see if that helps thicken it up.

Wonderful, easy marinade. I doubled the recipe, used a little less sugar and used freshly grated ginger.( I refrigerated 1/2 of this marinade to use again.) Instead of baking, I marinated about 6-7 skinless, boneless chicken breasts(Costco) for about 4 hrs and cooked them on the bbq, basting a few times. The marinade creates a beautiful golden glaze on the poultry.

text:
I just hate it when 1800 people love something and I feel ho-hum.  The key issue to me was the sauce - I found it salty (used reg version of Kikoman soy sauce) and garlic and ginger didn't shine through (probably needed to add more as others have suggested).  When I tasted the sauce, I decided to add a splash of pineapple juice and about half a cup of drained crushed pineapple to cut the saltiness.  That worked fine, but I still wasn't sold on the sauce.  My problem may be that I once took a Japanese cooking class and have memories of a wonderful homemade teriyaki sauce we made.  Unfortunately I no longer have the recipe so I will continue searching.  Glad so many of you have found this to be a crowd pleaser, my vote is "just OK" - certainly not offensive but not 5* WOW.

region:

country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I substituted brown sugar for white, and red wine vinegar for cider vinegar (only because i didn't have the required items in my pantry).   It still turned out very good. I made it with a slightly different method. First I sliced my chicken breasts into strips, and fried in olive oil until fully cooked. While I was doing this I cooked the sauce in another pan, and let sit over low heat until it thickened. When it reached my desired thickness, I just tossed the chicken strips in the sauce, and served over rice.  Very easy and very yummy!   ** Also, I did not double the recipe and found it was enough to coat 4 chicken breasts that had been sliced. There was extra sauce too which I drizzled on top before serving.

text:
Great!! I followed most of the suggestions and baked it at 375- covered for 25 mins and uncovered for 15 mins. I didn't brush with the sauce, just dumped the sauce in pan. I also used 2 T flour because I didn't have cornstarch, 1/2 c brown sugar instead of white, and halfed the soy sauce. I lined the pan with foil and sprayed it with Pam and the chicken came off no problem. Also if you cover the pan with the sauce it heats up very quickly! Great chicken! Everyone loved it over rice!

text:
This is great! I made it for guests, and they loved it! I cooked it in my crockpot while I was at church. I used drumsticks and bone-in thighs and served it over rice The sauce was a bit too runny, but tasted delish. I put in the recommended amount of sugar, approximately. I warmed the chicken up in the oven at 400F for half an hour and then left it in the crockpot on high for 3 1/2 - 4 hours and it was just done. If possible , it should be in for a bit longer. Anyway, it's a keeper!

text:
This was absolutely delicious BUT...with people commenting on the sauce burning and having to double the sauce....I made the sauce exactly as is...but before I put the chicken in a 375 degree oven for 1 1/2 hour (no burning sauce and there was plenty to serve with the chicken), I removed all the skin from my legs and thighs and put the chicken in a bowl and bathed it in olive oil and seasoned it with salt and pepper as I do with my rosemary chicken and it came out moist and fully cooked and delicious...thank you for this recipe.

None
text:
Great recipe!! I have been making this for over 2 years now and everyone (even my picky eaters) LOVE this. My husband requests this very often. We have used the sauce for every meat imaginable and have used it as a marinade, a grilling sauce, a stir fry and fried rice sauce, and a dipping sauce!!! The only thing I substitute is sometimes I use the equivalent of dried ground garlic and ginger or the fresh stuff...whatever I have on hand. I would also suggest doubling (or even quadrupling) if you want to also use sauce as a finishing sauce as well. I have also made this sauce in the microwave and it still turned out excellent! 5+++ stars!!!

text:
I followed a lot of recommendations here like doubling the sauce and baking at 375 degrees F.  I used foil pan and greased the pan with cooking spray (because I needed to use the foil for something!).  I added celery seeds seasoning to the sauce mix, and it tasted fresh.  I had to use a lot of sugar than what is called for in 10 servings (I have a huge family, and we love leftovers), so I basically sampled the sauce each time I added more sugar.  Also, I may use more brown sugar next time.  Overall, my family enjoyed it.

text:
Slow Cooker version w/ tri tips!  Made the sauce doubled, little less sugar and without the cournstarch and water.  Seasoned the steaks with a bit of salt and pepper and seared in hot olive oil.  Placed in slow cooker, poured sauce over and let cook on low all day.  Put steaks in baking dish, poured sauce into saucepan and thickened with water and cornstarch.  Poured over steaks and broiled for a few minutes on each side.  Wonderfull and easy!

text:
This is a great recipe. My family requests this weekly and is very easy to make. Definitely double the recipe. I use an electric skillet -400 degrees- slice 4-5 chicken breasts, 1/4 C brown sugar, throw everything else in and let it cook for about 30 minutes (until chicken is no longer pink) and serve over Jasmine rice. YUM! Left overs are even better the next day.

text:
Delicious! Like some of the other commenters, I doubled the quantity of everything. I was glad that I did, because we served this with unseasoned brown rice and there was enough sauce to mix some in with the rice. Yum!  Like some of the other commenters, I reduced the total amount of sugar by about a third and used packed brown sugar instead of white. I also doubled the garlic.   Next time I might add some fresh pineapple or some veggies. The sauce is quite salty because of all the soy, so it paired well with plain unseasoned brown rice.  Great recipe!

text:
Had made some minor adjustments. I used Garlic Wine Vinegar instead of cider vinegar (it was what I had in the cupboard). I also didn't have a brush, so I just spooned the sauce on the chicken. Since, I was spooning the sauce, I didn't not have enough sauce to continue applying every 10 minutes. I applied at the beginning of course, but only applied at the 1st 15 minute mark and then just let it bake for the remaining 45 minutes without turning.... ABSOLUTELY FABULOUS!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quite tasty!  I loved how easily it came together.  I used ~3/4 the sugar and only had pomegranate-infused red wine vinegar on hand.  It turned out great and we made it twice in one week.  I doubled the sauce, so I didn't need to turn them, as they were well-covered already.  Served over rice.  Thanks Marian!  *UPDATE* Tried this in a crockpot with disappointing results, possibly all my fault.  I added fresh pineapple after 4 hours on low.  The sauce was very diluted and gravy-like.  I think a lot of the liquid was from chicken juice and the pineapple juice destroyed it.  I ended up pulling the meat off the bones and remaking the sauce to drizzle over.  It was certainly passable, just disappointing.  Might try it again, but will stick with the oven!  Thanks Marian!

text:
This recipe is delicious and VERY college student friendly! I don't mind a complicated recipe but after a long day sometimes tossing a bunch of stuff together and throwing it in the oven is all I can handle. I used 3 large, pounded boneless skinless chicken breasts and baked 40 minutes at 400F in an 8x8 dish lined with foil. Hardly any mess left over, and the chicken was perfectly tender and drowning in sauce. I served it with basmati rice and steamed broccoli and I am SO satisfied. To think, I used to pay $15 for the same dish at a Japanese restaurant! Never again, all of these ingredients are cheap and ALWAYS lying around somewhere!

text:
This was a great basic sauce. I slightly modify it to our family's tastes by dividing the sugar into one part white and one part brown, adding a dash of red pepper flakes, and using low sodium soy sauce. I also double the sauce to ensure there is plenty for basting and pouring over rice/noodles. I cooked 8 skin-on thighs at 425 for 50 minutes, turning and basting as stated, and they turned out beautifully -- tender and moist. I think this recipe would be even better if used on grilled chicken!

userID:
2223426
Display Name:
Toasty Mama
isPro:
False
followersCount:
34
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
160
favoritesCount:
1007
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/397593.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times doubling the sauce and subbing with lite soy and we absolutely love it!  I had a whole roaster chicken so I decided to try the sauce on it.  Doubled the sauce reserving half.  With the remaining sauce I put some in the cavity with some sliced onion and the rest between the skin and the breast/legs.  Then I brushed the bird with olive oil and sprinkled with black pepper.  Chilled in the refrigerator for about 4 - 6 hours cooked in the oven at 350 degrees for about 2 1/2 hours.  I used the reserved sauce to baste the chicken every 20 min to half hour or so.  The chicken had SO much flavor and the drippings made a wonderful gravy to put over white rice.  Will definitely make again!

text:
This recipe was DELICIOUS!  I doubled the sauce as others instructed and used some brown sugar.  I also reduced the soy sauce by a bit. I added sliced pineapple and swiss cheese on the top.  I also did the chicken breast at 400 for 30 minutes.  I flipped the chicken a few times then added the pineapple at the 15 minute mark.  I added the cheese right before I pulled it out and let it melt before removing it from the rack.  One of my guest had been insisting he had the best Teriyaki sauce recipe but he walked out with this one! FABULOUS!

text:
This would be a 3 or 4 star recipe if the cooking times had been accurate.  I used boneless skinless thighs and it took only about 30 minutes to cook.  One hour was way too long.  Was the cooking time supposed to be for bone-in thighs?  The teriyaki glaze (called "tare" in Japanese) resembles the tare that's popular for yakitori at Japanese restaurants in the US.  I would recommend making the tare and brushing it on chicken breast pieces alternated with pieces of green onion skewered on bamboo sticks, and placed on a grill.  It's called "negima" and it's delicious...

text:
This turned out amazing!  My entire family was very pleased and asked for me to make this again.  I did modify the recipe a tad.  I used a little over half of the sugar.  I did a combo of light brown and white sugar.    I used the regular soy sauce, although others claim that it is too salty, I thought it was perfect.  When you are making the sauce on the stove top it will taste VERY salty, but don't worry it cooks right down in the oven.  We also bacon wrapped our chicken breasts (I would highly recommend doing this).  Then, dumped all of the sauce on the chicken in a disposable aluminum pan.  Cooked at 375 for 40 minutes.  Came out juicy and very flavorful!

This was yummy. I used brown sugar splenda instead of white sugar and I didn't have cider vinegar so I used rice wine vinegar. I made the sauce and then tosseed the raw breasts in it and let it mariante overnight in the fridge. The next day, I tossed it all into a pan, covered with foil and baked. The sauce was pretty runny when I first took it out of the oven from all of the chicken juices, but thickened up as it cooled. Very tender chicken.

text:
Really good.  I don't normally like anythihng Teriyaki because it is so sweet, but this was really good.  I used 1/2 the sugar (I actually used splenda) the recipe called for, and low sodium soy sauce.  I put thighs in a foil pan, poured the sauce over the top and turned the chicken in it a few times, covered with foil, baked for 25 minutes, turned thighs, returned to oven for another 25 minutes uncovered and they were great, skin was crispy and meat was tender.  I served these with fried rice.  I doubled the sauce as mentioned by so many viewers, but I don’t think it was necessary.

text:
This was good - not wow, but good.  I like to follow recipes as exactly as possible the first time I try them.  In this case, I wasn't able to brush on more sauce every 10 minutes because I ran out after the first round.  It still came out flavorful, but the cooking time/temp is off.  I have a gas oven, so I adjust accordingly.  Actually, I brought the temp down by another 25 degrees.  It was more than done when I took it out after 40 minutes.  I did cover with foil for the first 20 minutes, but other than that, the recipe was executed as-is.  Like so many other reviewers suggested, I'll double the sauce next time.  On the whole, this is a good routine meal I'll be repeating.  EDIT:  I doubled the sauce this time, which allowed me to use the basting process.  So much better this way!!!  I wish we could rate recipes by half-stars, because this still wouldn't be a five-star, but I would raise my rating to a 4 & 1/2

This recipe was so delicious! I also doubled the sauce and pre-marinated my chicken a bit. I did not have low-sodium soy sauce so I only used half regular soy sauce and half (extra) cold water. The sauce thickens up so nicely by the time it is done and is really good over fried rice! All the flavours melded wonderfully. Yum!

userID:
3360000
Display Name:
Nanita
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a starting point. For a little more kick, I added 1/2 tsp. of Thai Kitchen roasted red chili paste  and used less sugar. To make it more Hawaiian style, I used Japanese rice vinegar for half of the vinegar and used a mix of brown and white sugars. 

  I get my dry ginger in the bulk spice area of a busy local food coop, so it's very fresh and flavorful.  This recipe would be good with fresh grated ginger in it, too.

In going for a gooey, glazed surface to the chicken, I ended up overcooking the chicken slightly. I don't have a lot of patience for repeated basting, but it might be worth it to get that glaze!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-12-06T16:43:02.793

text:
I'm usually not a big fan of chicken thighs, but we had some extra and I decided to try this recipe based on the rave reviews. I'm glad I did! 

The thighs were moist and the flavor was rich and deep; I did slather some of the sauce under the skin before I cooked it and I believe that added some of the flavor to the meat itself.

One thing I wish I would have done was either oil the pan a little better or put a foil liner in it and up the sides; the sugar in the sauce burned to the glass in a few places and I'm still scrubbing!

Notes: I followed the directions to the letter and changed nothing. I even basted every 10 minutes, which was time consuming but worth it.

userID:
2418603
Display Name:
sonnet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6578350.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family LOVES this recipe, it is one of the best just as is and SUPER quick and easy!

My suggestions (I will probably be repeating several, sorry!) Use boneless skinless chicken breasts rather than bone-in thighs to save on time. True, they have a lighter flavor. But they're a bit healthier and so much faster to cook. As written, this sauce is delicious, but really salty. I like salt, but this is too salty for me. Now just cutting back on the soy sauce would kill the flavor, so it's best if you can find reduced sodium soy, really. That will save you the flavor and kill the over-salted effect. I don't keep cider vinegar in the house, so I usually mix regular white vinegar with a splash of wine - works great! And a huge ditto to the many others who have said you MUST double, triple or quadruple the sauce depending on how much chicken you are making and how much sauce you like (ie, do you want extra to eat on rice.) As written, this recipe makes about a cup of sauce. That's enough to marinate a couple of chicken breasts well, but not enough for 12 thighs, or for people who like extra over rice. Just a FYI!

Do try it, it's really tasty and good, plus the sauce takes about 3 minutes to boil together. Et voila, you look like a fancy schmancy cook for putting it over chicken and rice! Yay!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-10-17T13:00:49.933

text:
I thought this was great, especially since I'm on a gluten-free diet.  I just used my wheat free tamari (soy) sauce, and ended up with a wonderful teriyaki sauce!  I followed the recipe for the sauce exactly, but I used chicken tenders instead of thighs.  I marinated the chicken for about 3 hours before cooking.  I've made this a few times now, and have baked it and grilled it on the bbq - both are great (although I think I prefer the grill).  I usually heat up the sauce that I marinated the chicken in (until it is 180 degrees so I don't have to worry about raw chicken in the sauce) and serve it over the chicken and some rice.  I'd been craving a good teriyaki chicken and rice dish since being diagnosed w/ Celiac disease. This definitely satisfied my craving!

text:
I made this sauce without the cornstarch and water and put my chicken thighs in it overnight to marinate. When I cooked it, I put it on the grill instead on low heat for almost 40 minutes. The sauce I put in a small saucepan on the grill, brought it up to a boil, and basted my chicken with it every 5-10 minutes when I flipped it. I was told this was the best chicken I've ever made in my life. Plus, I had hardly any cleanup! No sticky baking pans for me! Try this method!

Next time need to make sure I have rice or something to use up the yummy sauce!

text:
This was very tasty! I did make a couple of minor changes. I used boneless skinless chicken breasts instead of thighs and, therefore, only baked them for 35 mintues. I substituted low sodium soy for the regular and used 4 tbl of honey instead of the 1/2 cup of white sugar. I agree with previous posters who suggested the sauce wasn't enough and after baking it half way through, I ended up making an additional batch of sauce to baste on the second round of baking and to have some for pouring over the finished chicken. I also agree that you should definitely line your baking pan with foil since this did make a burned on mess with the sauce on the bottom of the pan. I served this with roasted green beans and mushrooms which baked along with the chicken. I will definitely make this recipe again.

country:

text:
I made this for my Hawaiian Mai Tai party last night, and it was a big hit.  I followed other suggestions posted by reviewers, including cutting down the sugar a bit, but splitting between brown and white.  I made extra sauce and didn't have time to baste every 10 minutes, so just covered for the first 30 minutes, then turned and removed the foil for the second 30 minutes.  Juicy, carmelized a bit on the top, and great sauce to pour over rice.

Oh, and for those of you who know people who are gluten-intolerant, this is a great recipe provided you can find a substitute for soy sauce, which I did at our local Fry's.  It's a bit saltier, so I cut it down, but followed everything else and was able to serve a dish made separately to a dear friend, who said it was fabulous.  

Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I took the advice of other reviewers and doubled the sauce, but in my opinion, that was just too much!  Most people cut the sugar in half, but I used 2/3c which was perfect, but no matter what I did, the soy sauce overwhelemed the dish!  My fiance and I both almost gagged eating it.  In my own opinion, I would definitely cut the soy in half rather than the sugar.  I used half the sauce on the chicken thighs, covered with foil, baked at 400* for 25 min, and then I poured the other half of the sauce on the thighs, and baked another 25 minutes.  The chicken itself was perfect!  Very tender and juicy!  I will definitely try this again, just not so much soy!

userID:
2266185
Display Name:
Naxxramas
isPro:

followersCount:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/91027.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great!! I used 2 skinless boneless chicken breasts, an 8x8 pan, and 1/2 sodium soy sauce. I set aside most of the teriyaki sauce to use during and after baking. I baked the chicken in a preheated oven at 375 degrees fahrenheit for 30 minutes.

Before I put the chicken in the oven, I put a little bit of water in the bottom of the pan, and poured some of the teriyaki sauce over the top of the chicken. I baked the chicken for 15 minutes. Upon taking out the chicken, I drained off some of the liquid. Then, I flipped the chicken and poured some of the reserved teriyaki sauce over the chicken. After that, I put the chicken back in the oven for 15 more minutes. When those 15 minutes were up, I poured the remaining reserved teriyaki sauce over the chicken and served. 

The sauce tasted great, and the chicken was very tender. The chicken went great with chopped pineapple and grilled veggies on the side. Thank you so much for this wonderful recipe! Now I can make teriyaki chicken myself instead of buying it at a Japanese restaurant. :)
Review:
Rating:
5

The sauce came together beautifully - DELISH!  The only changes I made were I used boneless skinless thighs, I used half white and half brown sugar, and I dumped the entire pot of sauce over the chicken all at once.  The only mistake I made was that I rinsed the chicken without patting dry; so when I added that beautiful thick sauce it became quite watered down.  Didn't matter - this was still a 5 star recipe.  It's a keeper!

text:
Excellent!  Scaled the sauce down to 4 servings and used for 2 boneless chicken breasts.  Baked in a 8x8 lined with foil and just poured the sauce over the chicken and turned a few times to coat.  Covered with foil and baked for 30 mins @ 400 degrees, spooning sauce over the chicken a few times during baking.  Only modifications I made to the sauce was that I used garlic powder and brown sugar instead of white.  This is definitely a keeper!  Not too salty or too sweet.  Way better than the bottled stuff and easy to make as well.

Really 4.5 stars. country:

text:
These were really good.  I made a little extra sauce, and used thn boneless breasts. They cooked in 20 mins, so that didn't give me many bastings. I did line the pan with foil, but I don't know if I'd do it again; I know it helps in cleaning up (and how!), but the juices accumulate more when a pan is lined, and that dilutes the sauce. I added about a teaspoon of toasted sesame seeds to the sauce, and that worked really well. Might add tahini next time for an added flavor boost. I think this sauce would work REALLY well on salmon, and probably beef, too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed this recipe a bit and got it to taste like the chicken they serve in the mall and my picky husband loved it. I added more sugar, a tad more ginger and some orange juice along with adding more corn starch in the beginning to make it a thicker sauce. I used chicken breasts and the thing I think that made this recipe was coating the chicken with the sauce every ten minutes like the recipe calls for. I did put the foil underneath the chicken to save my pan otherwise you will be scrubbing! Next time I will cut the chicken into smaller pieces then bake and coat as this will make the chicken even more like the mall chicken. I think I didn't cook it as long as it calls for but when your coating it every ten minuets then you can really see the progress and take it out once it's done. This was so good and it will go on my rotating menu since we loved it so much! Thank you for this recipe!

text:
I was super excited to try this one out! I followed the advice of others and lined the pan!  Great idea!  I also followed and doubled the sauce. I'm not a beginner cook, but I messed something up! I used apple cider vinegar, because that was the only cider vinegar I could find. I used a lite soy sauce. I did something WRONG!!  I used chicken breast- thick ones- and it only needed to cook for 40 minutes. Was very tender and juicy. But the sauce WAS Nasty!! I salvaged this by getting a paper towel and getting as much sauce off as I could. The whole time it was cooking my house smelled Nasty!  I would love to know what I did wrong. My family did like it, but only after I got as much sauce off as I could. Good luck!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-03-11T16:51:20.55

text:
Delicious! Followed the recipe for the most part. I used 9 drumsticks in a round glass casserole dish. Whoever recommended lining the dish with foil instead of greasing...I love you. That would have been the biggest mess in the world to scrub out of my pan. But with the foil. 1-2-3 and clean. Thanks. Also, I found the hr. recommended was perfect. I used a glass lid to cover my chicken the entire time to stay moist. And I found since it was covered, the sauce was thick enough to coat, cover, but never evaporated enough moisture to overly thicken. It was perfect and easy.

text:
This was really easy! the way I make it on the stovetop is i first sautee chicken breast completely on on side. When I turn it to the second side, i only let it get brown and then immidiately add the teriyaki sauce. Cover until the chicken is cooked through. To make the sauce thicker, I just remove the lid about half way before the chicken is completly done.

text:
Made this a few weeks ago and used the electric grill. I simmered up all of the marinade together, and marinated 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts along with 1 tablespoon of sherry in a ziplock overnight. I did bake it at first, but after 30mins, the chicken was still not cooked in the middle and not looking very nice on the outside. That's when the electric grill came out. They took about 10mins to cook through on the grill and they were absolutely delish! SO moist and juicy.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-11-11T22:47:48.797
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
2473431
Display Name:
Candice
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
81
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/140759.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!! Very Simple as well. 

Like others I made a few alterations. 

I had 1.36lb of chicken thighs. (thighs will make for a tender chicken)

I practically doubled the sauce:
2TBSP cornstarch
2TBSP cold water
1/4 cup white sugar (if you are worried about too much sugar I think you could cut this altogether) 
1/2 cup light brown sugar 
1/2 cup of low sodium soy sauce (kept this the same since a lot of reviewers said it was too salty)
2cloves of garlic
1TSP ginger
1/2 TSP of ground pepper

In the large sauce pot that I made the sauce, after letting it cool a bit I placed all the chicken into the sauce and let it soak for a while. Maybe 10-15 minutes while letting oven heat up. ( I bet letting it sit overnight in a ziplock bag in fridge would be great too) 

375 for 30 MINUTES

I placed chicken on foil lined pan and brushed with more sauce on both sides. I place another piece of foil on top and close the sides and corners making sure it was nicely wrapped. 

Every 10 minutes I would take out of the oven and re-coat both sides and flip the chicken to the opposite side to cook, re-wrapping the foil. 

Served with seasoned broccoli. 

Fantastic!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-11-10T11:10:10.7

text:
Fantastic recipe. I'd give it 6 stars if I could. I made it twice so far. First time I didn't have ginger and second time I did. I liked it more without the ginger. Per some others, I added water chestnuts and chunck pineapple.  I used light soy sauce and used breasts instead of thighs but sliced them to make them thinner.  I lined the pan with foil making cleanup a breeze. I served it with brown basmati rice along with mushrooms. I'm definitely going to serve this for my "Christmas Buffet" that I have with friends a Saturday just before Christmas.

text:
My husband loved this! I only had a little less than 1/4 cup soy sauce left so that's all I used but I think that I would do it the same way next time. Also, I used red wine vinegar since that's what I had. I did not cook the marinade on the stovetop the first time I made this, I didn't realize I was supposed to, when I made it again I did bring it to a boil but we didn't like it as much like this. Next time I will mix the marinade and just pour over chicken right before I put in the oven. Usually teriyaki chicken has too strong of a soy sauce taste for me. I made the sauce ahead of time and threw it in the fridge. This was a nice easy meal to make with 2 small children demanding most of my attention.

userID:

Display Name:
Mystonique

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I followed the sauce directions to a tee, plus added a teaspoon of sesame oil like another user recommended. It tasted way too vinegar-y - until I let it cool in the fridge overnight when I marinated the chicken in it. The taste mellowed out it and was perfect.

Following other users' suggestions, I put foil over the pan for the first 30 minutes, and then dumped off the juices from the drumsticks. When I put the drumsticks back into the oven, I took off the foil and put more sauce on top of the drumsticks and kept basting every ten minutes until the hour was up. The meat was incredibly tender and my friend couldn't believe the sauce was made from scratch.

But yes - the pan is a mess. I must remember next time to line the bottom with foil!

edit: I made this for my coworkers. They loved it so much they asked for the recipe.

text:
I dont know why but this sauce didnt carmelize on the chicken like it was supposed to.  It may have been because I used chicken breasts and it wasnt cooked as long but I saw other reviewers who used chicken breasts and they said that theirs coated well.  Mine basically was runny from the start.  I added a little more cornstarch to it to thicken it a little more but maybe there needed to be more added.  I might try to make this one more time just to see if it turns out.  Overall it tasted good but Ive had better tasting teriyaki sauce before.  This in my opinion tastes almost like the bottled stuff which im not to fond of.

text:
Great recipe! I started by pouring 1/2 the teriyaki over the chicken.  I then used the rest to bast it a few times during cooking (I thought every 10 minutes was too labor intensive).  The underside that was sitting in the teriyaki was very moist and flavorful but not carmelized like the side that was just basted - so I can see the point of only basting it.  But either way it was very good. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
My picky 3 year old took one bite and said "UMMM... this is SOOOO good!"  You can't get a better recommendation in my book.  I made this without reading the reviews and next time I will line the pan with foil.  I made a half batch of the sauce since I only had 1/2 the soy sauce and I only cooked 1 full chicken breast, cooked for 40 minutes.  I recommend doubling the sauce also.  I don't even normally like Teriyaki, but this isn't too strong and the ckicken is very moist.  I marinated it for about 2 hours.  Can't wait to try it on the grill.

text:
This was a very tasty recipe and the preparation was a breeze.  I used chicken tenderloins and baked them for 15 minutes at 375, flipped them and covered the pan with foil (to prevent them from drying out), and baked for another 15 minutes at 350.  Also, lining the pan with foil as one reviewer suggested was a great idea.  Clean up was super easy.  Next time I might use lite soy sauce as the glaze was a bit too salty.

text:
Everyone from my picky husband to my super-picky 5-year-old was impressed with this recipe!  

I did make two small changes... I used low-sodium tamari rather than soy sauce because I like the taste of tamari better.  (Trust me, whatever you use, you want to make sure it's low sodium.)  And I used chicken tenderloins, cooked them at 350 for 20, basting every 5 minutes.

So.  Yummy.

832014
Display Name:
MAINEMOM
isPro:

30

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! What a great recipe, and simple, as well. My husband said it tasted like the teriyaki chicken at our favorite Japanese restaurant, and even my kids liked it. I used light soy sauce, and found the saltiness exactly right. I also added about a tsp of sesame oil and a shake of onion powder, plus lots more than one clove of garlic. I used other reviewers suggestion of 1/2 brown & 1/2 white sugar. I didn't bother w/basting, but ladeled 1/2 the sauce over the chicken (turning each thigh to coat well), then added the rest of the sauce at the 30 minute mark. Since I used boneless, skinless thighs, I just cooked for an additional 20 mins -- perfect. My only problem was not enough sauce -- I'll double it next time! Soooo yummy over rice.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
